title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SILK Its called taking silk: the merit-based appointment of a British lawyer as Queens Counsel, which confers the right to wear a specially designed silk gown in court (and, for ceremonial occasions, a large wig). And Martha Costello, a sharp-witted defense barrister in London played by a crackling Maxine Peake, above, wants to take silk  badly  in this Masterpiece Mystery! series created by Peter Moffat, inspired by his own experiences. Already stretched thin, Martha strategically overloads on cases that could bolster her reputation and tutors an ambitious if occasionally bumbling pupil (Tom Hughes). But she has competition in her quest for justice and professional prestige: Clive Reader (Rupert Penry-Jones), a fellow barrister at Shoe Lane Chambers whose skill set is heavy on cunning and charm, which he uses to bed his own pupil (Natalie Dormer). In Episode 2, Martha defends a teenager.

title: Hayao Miyazaki, Japanese Animator, Said to Be Retiring
description: The Japanese animation director Hayao Miyazaki will retire from filmmaking, according to a report on Varietys Web site. Mr. Miyazaki, 72, has directed 11 animated features over 34 years, including My Neighbor Totoro, Princess Mononoke and Spirited Away, which won an Oscar for best animated feature in 2003. Koji Hoshino, who is the president of Mr. Miyazakis production company, made the announcement on Sunday at the Venice Film Festival, where Mr. Miyazakis latest work, The Wind Rises, was shown. Miyazaki has decided that Kaze Tachinu (The Wind Rises) will be his last film, and he will now retire, Mr. Hoshino said. More details are to be revealed at a news conference in Tokyo next week. The language of the announcement does leave the door open for Mr. Miyazaki to work on shorter projects.

title: Lohan Skips Venice to Focus on Health
description: Lindsay Lohan has spoken up to dispute reports that she ditched the premiere of her latest film, The Canyons, at the Venice Film Festival. In a post on her personal Web site, Ms. Lohan said that she was never confirmed to appear to promote the film and instead wanted to focus on her health, The Associated Press reported on Sunday. Paul Schrader, the director of The Canyons, said in a news conference on Friday that he was a free man, adding: For the last 16 months Ive been hostage, by own choosing, to a very talented but unpredictable actress. She was supposed to be here today; she said she would be, but she is not. In her statement, Ms. Lohan, who completed her latest court-ordered rehab stint in July, said that she would have enjoyed attending the festival. But, she said: My focus is on my health and well-being. Plain and simple, it is of the utmost importance.

title: Dancing in the Eternal Present, Before Harsh Reality Intervened
description: It was supposed to be the bigger, better party. Electric Zoo 2013 was the fifth annual Labor Day weekend of electronic dance music on Randalls Island, and its promoter, Made Event, had expanded it by adding another stage with additional headliners. But after two concertgoers died, apparently from using MDMA (known in different formulations as Molly or Ecstasy), Made Event followed the recommendation of the mayors office and abruptly canceled Sunday, the third day of the festival. Last week, the House of Blues in Boston closed temporarily after drug overdoses following a show by Zedd, who would have been one of Sundays Electric Zoo headliners.

title: Two Plans for Safety at Bangladesh Factories
description: North American and European-led retailers and apparel brands created separate plans to try to inspect and improve workplace conditions in Bangladesh, with significant differences, as this side-by-side comparison shows.

title: Riot Grrrl Back From the Brink
description: Donating her file cabinet, full of old journals, letters and zines to New York Universitys Fales Library archive was a bittersweet move for Kathleen Hanna. A singer and founder of the riot grrrl band Bikini Kill and the feminist electro-pop act Le Tigre, Ms. Hanna had been a den mother to contemporary-girl culture for a generation, but she was still only a midcareer artist, too young to grapple with archiving her work. The donation helped legitimize the riot grrrl movement.

title: Fast and Flawed Inspections of Factories Abroad
description: Inspectors came and went from a Walmart-certified factory in Guangdong Province in China, approving its production of more than $2 million in specialty items that would land on Walmarts shelves in time for Christmas.

title: Ballet and TV Make Uneasy Pas de Deux
description: Breaking Pointe, a reality-television show about Ballet West, is breaking my heart. So You Think You Can Dance is as feckless as ever. And Amy Sherman-Palladinos wise, snappy Bunheads was canceled. When it comes to dance on television, the best move is to reach for the remote.

title: History Aside, Obama Bets on Congress
description: WASHINGTON  In President Obamas telling, Congress plays host to an endless parade of distractions and political posturing. It is the challenging place where his second-term agenda meets Washington gridlock, forcing him to issue executive orders and make appeals to the public to get anything done.

title: Bullpen Collapse Costs Yankees Sweep After Effective Start by Pettitte
description: For days now the Yankees have made the point with grave certainty that they no longer have any room for mistakes. They are trailing in the chase for a playoff spot, and one pitch, one faulty swing, a base-running mistake or a fateful decision by the manager could doom them.

description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released this week includes construction spending for July and the Institute for Supply Management index of manufacturing activity in August (Tuesday); the United States trade deficit for July, the Federal Reserves beige book regional economic report, and the Challenger, Gray & Christmas report on job cuts in August (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, ADP employment for August, and factory orders for July (Thursday); and the United States unemployment report for August (Friday).

title: Gilmar, Pels Last Line of Defense, Dies at 83
description: Gilmar dos Santos Neves, a goalkeeper for Brazils national soccer team when it won its first World Cup title in 1958 and when it successfully defended the title in 1962, died on Aug. 22 in So Paulo. He was 83.

title: Thai Protester Killed at Blockade
description: BANGKOK  One protester was shot and killed and another seriously wounded in southern Thailand on Sunday at the site of a blockade by rubber farmers who are protesting a sharp fall in rubber prices.

title: Campaign Journalism in the Age of Twitter
description: In Timothy Crouses seminal campaign book, The Boys on the Bus, the crusty political reporters settle on the story that they will tell the world at the end of the day.

title: Walker Cup Returns to Roots, With a Twist
description: Nearly a century later, the Walker Cup matches are returning to where they originated, the National Golf Links of America in Southampton, N.Y. The National, as its known, is one of golfs cherished antiques, the site of the 44th duel Saturday and Sunday between an amateur team representing the United States and one representing Britain and Ireland. Its fabled course, designed by Charles Blair Macdonald, the father of American golf architecture, is virtually unchanged since it opened in 1911. New tees at the 7th, 14th and 16th holes have stretched it to 6,995 yards, only 122 yards longer than when Bobby Jones, Francis Ouimet and Chick Evans  three of golfs revered names  won the inaugural cup matches there in 1922.

title: Big Screens That Not All of Hollywood Adores
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood Bowl has survived the Beatles, Bill Clinton, Liberace and Leonard Bernstein, not to mention reconstructions, earthquakes, coyotes and the thump-thump-thumping of helicopters crossing the night sky, inevitably at the most pianissimo of moments.

title: Williamss Skill Speaks Volumes in Easy Victory Over Stephens
description: It can be challenging to wade through the pleasantries offered between professional tennis opponents, and get at the heart of whether they can actually stand each other. Most are complimentary to a fault, tiptoeing as gingerly as possible around potential controversy or insult.

title: No Clear Winner in Debate Between Merkel and Challenger
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel and her Social Democratic rival, Peer Steinbrck, fought each other to a virtual draw in their sole television debate of the German election campaign on Sunday night. The face-off was a mostly decorous 90-minute affair that commentators had cast as Mr. Steinbrcks last chance to show his mettle and overcome earlier stumbles.

title: Jets Claim 3 Players Off Waivers
description: Alex Green, who started four games at running back for Green Bay last season, was among three players the Jets claimed off waiversSunday. They also added offensive tackle Ben Ijalana (Indianapolis) and linebacker Scott Solomon (Tennessee). To make room, the Jets cut running back Kahlil Bell and linebacker Danny Lansanah and placed linebacker Josh Mauga (back) on injured reserve.

title: Japans E-Reader Industry Struggles to Keep Up as Amazon Takes the Lead
description: TOKYO  When Rakuten, Japans leading e-commerce company, introduced its Kobo e-reader in Japan in July 2012, the companys chief executive, Hiroshi Mikitani, presented a gift to Yoshinobu Noma, the president of Kodansha, Japans largest publisher.

title: Surprising Friend of Gay Rights in a High Place
description: The San Francisco Gay Mens Chorus sang Give Em Hope for a revered and in some ways surprising guest who shared a California stage with them last month: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.

title: Opening a Door to the Burmese Past, and the Present, Too
description: BAGAN, Myanmar  In a delicate operation here, specialists gingerly eased a priceless, 1,000-year-old national treasure  a Buddhist bronze casting in the shape of a lotus flower  from its perch in a museum showcase.

title: A Roof Is Planned, but Its a Waiting Game for Fans and Players
description: With ominous daggers of lightning on the Weather Channels Web site, dark clouds scudding across the sky and rumors of cloudbursts in the vicinity, most people at the United States Open cannot help but obsess about Teflon flaps covering the main stadium and the reassuring plock-plock-plock of tennis being played.

title: Lottery Numbers
Amid Struggles, Nationals Win One Against Mets
description: WASHINGTON  The Nationals expected to play meaningful baseball in September. Their roster was brimming with the essential components for another playoff run. They had pitching and hitting. They had clubhouse chemistry and a seasoned manager, whose imminent retirement was sure to provide inspiration.

title: Subcontractor Servitude
description: THE words guest workers and strike are not often seen together. Yet twice this summer, members of a group of more than 150 Jamaican guest workers who clean luxury Florida hotels and condos walked off the job. The workers came to the United States in April anticipating a summer of hard work and decent earnings to send home. Instead, they encountered the black hole of labor subcontracting.

title: Morsi and Muslim Brotherhood Leaders Charged With Inciting Murder
description: CAIRO  Egypts chief prosecutor ordered former president Mohamed Morsi and other Muslim Brotherhood leaders on Sunday to stand trial on charges including inciting murder, the state news media reported. The order seemed to extinguish hope of a political resolution that would bring the Brotherhood out from underground and back into the political process.

title: Storm Clouds at U.S. Open Are Untimely but Not New
description: The last five years, rain pushed the mens final at the United States Open to a Monday, prompting more calls for a retractable roof to be built at Arthur Ashe Stadium. Plans for that roof, and another on a new Louis Armstrong Stadium, have been made, but bad weather at United States championships is hardly a recent phenomenon. The Open media guide devotes three pages to Rain and the U.S. Open in its historical highlights section, citing 18 times the event was extended because of the weather and instances when the Open finished on time despite lots of rain. Here are some notable examples:

title: When City Elections Were Fun
description: IN 1969, in the midst of devastating strikes, rising racial conflict, sinking finances, terrifying crime rates and an expanding, dysfunctional city bureaucracy, the pugilistic writer Norman Mailer made a quixotic bid for mayor of New York. The columnist Jimmy Breslin campaigned alongside him for City Council president. Far from being a gimmick, the pair electrified the electorate with bold plans and even bolder political theatrics.

title: 6 Boys Killed While Swimming in Northern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six boys were killed on a swimming outing in northern Afghanistan, apparently the victims of fishermen who fired a rocket into a river, according to Afghan officials and relatives of the victims.

title: A New Kind of Union
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  THE financial challenges low- and middle-income Americans face are daunting. But the poor and middle class are in an equally serious, if less well recognized, political predicament: the government has become almost entirely unresponsive to them.

title: Garca Finds Much Light in the Darkness
description: NORTON, Mass.  Working as long and hard this Labor Day weekend as lifeguards, some golfers will spend Monday at the Tournament Players Club of Boston trying to save their seasons.

title: Love for Labor Lost
description: It wasnt always about the hot dogs. Originally, believe it or not, Labor Day actually had something to do with showing respect for labor.

title: Chasing JPMorgan Chase
description: Not too long ago, JPMorgan Chase and its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, were celebrated for navigating the 2008 financial crisis, which brought other big banks to their knees. Now this one-time darling of federal regulators, long thought to be the best managed of all the big banks, is in trouble or apparently headed there on multiple fronts. While the outcome of the various investigations into the banks dealings remains unclear, they raise the obvious question of whether banks have become not only too big to fail but too big to manage.

title: A Saner Approach on Drug Laws
description: The Justice Department took an important step toward sanity in the enforcement of drug laws last week when it announced a trust but verify approach to states permitting the growth, sale and possession of marijuana.

title: Reality Intrudes Before the Kickoff
description: In a chilling prologue to the professional football season, the National Football League has agreed to pay $765 million to more than 4,500 retired players who claim long-term damages from the violent concussions that are part of the game. The payment settles a pending lawsuit but hardly resolves the continuing threat to players from the traumatic hits  bell ringers in the sports jargon  that mounting research shows are linked to brain disease in athletes later years.

title: The Turning at Labor Day
description: Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness  well, not quite yet. It is still a little early to have John Keatss autumnal words running through your head. Yet no matter how desperately you cling to summer, its almost impossible not to feel the changes that begin to gather around Labor Day. On a warm, muggy day, they are not very evident. Only the shifting of the light at evening suggests the changing season. But when the wind is fresh and the temperature falls a little, it is hard not to imagine the season leaping ahead of itself, even as summer lingers.

title: On Obamas Plan, a Message Emerges in Israel: Stay Quiet
description: JERUSALEM  Since reports surfaced of an apparent chemical attack outside Damascus, Israeli leaders have called for an American response, both on moral grounds and as a warning to Iran over its nuclear program. But on Sunday, after President Obama said he would delay a military strike to obtain Congressional approval, a new message emerged from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus government: Do not say anything.

description: Four people were killed early Sunday when their car veered off a highway in Westchester County, slammed into a bridge abutment and burst into flames, officials said.

description: Serena Williams takes her losses very seriously, and her memory is long. Consider how Maria Sharapova has fared against Williams in the last several years, since Sharapova beat Williams in the Wimbledon final. In last years Olympic final, Sharapova barely got one game in a drubbing on Centre Court. Like any great champion, Williams hates to lose, and she shows up to play anyone with a recent win over her with a steely-eyed resolve that makes her even more formidable.

description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  Even by Florida standards, the arrests of three suburban Miami mayors on corruption charges within a month were a source of dismay, if not exactly a surprise.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE STORY OF FILM: AN ODYSSEY Turner Classic Movies begins a 15-week festival of 119 films and dozens of short subjects representing 29 countries and 6 continents, and centered on Mark Cousinss 2012 examination of the birth and evolution of cinema, and the innovations in storytelling, style and technology that resulted in its current form. Mr. Cousins, a film critic from Northern Ireland, aims for comprehensiveness and coherence, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this 900-minute movie, presented in eight chapters. He wants to tell the whole story, from Genesis to Revelation, as the saying goes, but he also wants this vast chronicle to have a shape and a point: themes and patterns amid the names, places and images. He succeeds to an impressive extent. The results of his dogged research, compulsive travel and hard thinking are exemplary, useful and sometimes thrilling. Mr. Cousins and Robert Osborne will introduce each Monday episode, which begins here with movies from Thomas Edisons New Jersey studio, at 8, and the Lumire brothers French studio, at 9:30, and Birth of the Cinema (1900-1920), the first episode of Mr. Cousinss film, at 10. Georges Mliss short Trip to the Moon (1902), follows at 11:15, and Alice Guy-Blachs shorts Falling Leaves (1912), Canned Harmony (1912) and A House Divided (1913), at 11:30. The lineup concludes with three silent films: Oscar C. Apfels Squaw Man (1914), about a wrongly accused Englishman who escapes to Wyoming and takes an American Indian bride, at 12:30 a.m.; D. W. Griffiths Civil War epic, The Birth of a Nation (1915), at 2; and his Orphans of the Storm (1921), above, starring Lillian and Dorothy Gish as sisters struggling to find each other during the French Revolution, at 5:15.

description: HONG KONG  The China Minzhong Food Corporation, whose Singapore-traded shares lost half their value last week after it came under attack from a California short-seller, said on Monday that it had received a timely takeover offer from its biggest shareholder, an Indonesian food company.

description: The lessons learned from the summer of 1988 when fires burned nearly one third of Yellowstone National Park continue to shape the way we fight wildfires raging across the West today.

description: BERLIN  A 92-year-old man who served as a border guard in Adolf Hitlers elite Waffen-SS troops went on trial on Monday on charges that he shot and killed a Dutch resistance fighter in the final months of World War II. His prosecution is part of a German effort to bring aging Nazis to justice before it is too late.

Angry Birds, he said in an of course tone, choosing the one shirt in his wardrobe that was completely contrary to my image of what a well-parented child would wear.

title: Whac-A-Hack
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The Museum of Power was open for 12 days before the police raided it and shut it down. This was the first most people had heard of it, even in the Russian art world. The grandly named museum was really a small gallery in what used to be a communal apartment. It claimed to be the only museum devoted to people who rule us and influence us on a daily basis. It professed adherence to no particular movement in politics or art. It did not appear to be a particularly serious effort at an art gallery.

(MoreMax) MAGIC MIKE (2012) In a role loosely inspired by his stint as a stripper in Florida, Channing Tatum, above center, stars as the gyrating main attraction at the Xquisite dance club, in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called Steven Soderberghs funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream. Alex Pettyfer plays Adam, a college dropout who is pushed onstage at Xquisite. At first Adam is resistant. Then Madonnas Like a Virgin begins to throb. What happens will be familiar if youve ever seen one of those variations on the fallen-woman movie, Ms. Dargis wrote. In the past, the movies were very much preoccupied with the moral regulation of women, but here, the stress is on Mikes struggle to succeed as he juggles his part-time gigs (dancing, auto detailing and construction) with his desire to build custom furniture. She added: The collaboration between Mr. Soderbergh and the relatively untested Mr. Tatum is itself a gamble, one that has brought out the best in each. What could have been an embarrassing misfire hinted at by the movies misleading trailers is instead a smoothly distilled collaboration that balances Mr. Tatums heat and charm  and ambitions that are as transparent as Mikes  with Mr. Soderberghs cool, cinematic intelligence and ongoing preoccupations.

The power grid failed, toilets overflowed, stench-filled corridors went dark. Diesel generators gave partial electricity. Hospital staff members smashed windows to circulate air. Gunshots could be heard, echoing in the city. Two stabbing victims turned up at this hospital, which was on life support itself, and were treated.

title: Curators Chosen for American Pavilion at Architecture Biennale

In 2011, the Vatican found Rev. Karadima guilty of the abuses and ordered him to retire to a life of prayer and penitence. A Chilean judge dismissed criminal charges later that year because a statute of limitations had expired, but he also described the accusations as truthful and reliable.

title: The Global Elites Favorite Strongman
description: Paul Kagame, the president of Rwanda, agreed to meet me at 11 a.m. on a recent Saturday. Kagames office is on top of a hill near the center of Kigali, Rwandas capital, and I took a taxi there, driven by a man in a suit and tie. Whenever Im in Kigali, I am always impressed by how spotless it is, how the city hums with efficiency, which is all the more remarkable considering that Rwanda remains one of the poorest nations in the world. Even on a Saturday morning, platoons of women in white gloves rhythmically swept the streets, softly singing to themselves. I passed the Union Trade Center mall in the middle of town, where traffic circulates smoothly around a giant fountain. There was no garbage in the streets and none of the black plastic bags that get tangled up in the fences and trees of so many other African cities  Kagames government has banned them. There were no homeless youth sleeping on the sidewalks or huffing glue to kill their hunger. In Rwanda, vagrants and petty criminals have been scooped up by the police and sent to a youth rehabilitation center on an island in the middle of Lake Kivu that some Rwandan officials jokingly call their Hawaii  because it is so lush and beautiful  though people in Kigali whisper about it as if it were Alcatraz. There arent even large slums in Kigali, because the government simply doesnt allow them.

Still in her swimsuit, she leaned on her best friends shoulder, and with a swollen tongue and lips told the world never to write themselves off because of old age or give up on their dreams.

title: The Liberation of Knoxville

The town was until recently a rebel stronghold, the last in northeastern Tennessee. Yet in a letter home to his wife he remarked: I wish you could see the delight of the people  such loyalty to the Union I have never seen in my life before. We dont know at the North what loyalty means. Indeed, their long march over the Cumberland Mountains culminated in scenes of wild celebration as citizens of all ages greeted the liberating Federal army. A lithograph in Harpers Magazine portrayed General Burnside riding among the crowd, elevated like a savior. Long a symbol of defiant Southern Unionism, the city of Knoxville, Tenn., was, at last, liberated from Confederate control.

description: Nashville has spent the past few years slowly cultivating a more hipster-friendly identity, not unlike that of Austin, Tex., its spiritual compadre to the west. In the trendy Gulch neighborhood, the architect Nick Dryden has helped lead the transformation, designing hip spaces for clothing designer Billy Reid and for the denim mecca Imogene + Willie. Drydens latest endeavor, the 404 Hotel & Kitchen, which opens in October, is in an old garage next to a bluegrass landmark, the Station Inn, and preserves many of the original structures rustic charms: loftlike rooms with exposed ceiling beams and concrete floors (404 12th Avenue South). Then theres Benjamin and Max Goldberg, the brothers behind the much buzzed-about restaurant the Catbird Seat. Next month theyll open Pinewood Social  part restaurant, part bar and part hipster country club, with vintage bowling lanes, an outdoor pool, bocce-ball courts and karaoke rooms (33 Peabody Street). To end, Mr. Dank and Ms. Lee played Stravinskys formidable four-hand arrangement of The Rite of Spring, a tour-de-force account of a stunning piano piece.

title: Questions of Policy and Leadership Dog Obama Before Meeting in Russia
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Not even a month ago, President Obama canceled a planned summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, citing Russias decision to grant asylum to Edward J. Snowden as evidence of a broader deterioration of relations. We werent going to have a summit for the sake of appearances, the presidents deputy national security adviser, Benjamin J. Rhodes, said then.

title: Gerard Mortier Undergoing Cancer Treatment
description: Gerard Mortier, the opera impresario with a penchant for shaking things up in some of Europes most storied opera houses and music festivals, is being treated for cancer, the Spanish newspaper El Pas reported this week.

title: No Strings on a Piano, but the Tone Is Grand
description: There are some things you just dont expect to read about in a column about electronics. Gluten-free waffles, for example. Ferrets. Moist towelettes.

title: General Grant Takes a Spill
description: On Sept. 2, 1863, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant arrived in New Orleans for the sort of event he usually avoided  a full-dress military review, to be staged in his honor two days hence by Gen. Nathaniel Banks. Still savoring the fall of Vicksburg in early July, Grant was also anticipating a forthcoming campaign against the Confederate general Braxton Bragg that fall in eastern Tennessee. A victory there  especially at the vital city of Chattanooga  promised to open the way to Atlanta.

title: Taking On a Role She Grew Up With
description: Mary Bridget Davies, a 35-year-old actress and blues singer from Cleveland, has spent much of her career channeling Janis Joplin, one of her heroes, and will do so again, on Broadway, when A Night With Janis Joplin begins previews on Sept. 20 at the Lyceum Theater.

title: Syria and the Constitution
description: After President Obamas surprise weekend announcement that he would seek congressional approval before ordering a strike on Syria, there was a flurry of commentary praising the president for taking a step back on the march toward ever-more-expansive executive power. It may well be the most important presidential act on the Constitution and war-making powers, wrote Walter Shapiro, since Harry Truman decided to sidestep Congress and not seek its backing to launch the Korean war. Dan McCarthy suggested that the president has chosen the occasion of a war that over 50 percent of Americans oppose to teach a civics lesson, that this partial self-limiting is perhaps the best thing hes done as president, and that a Congress that voted down the Syria authorization would be serving notice to the public and to future administrations that Article I, Section 8, Clause 11 of the U.S. Constitution is still in force.

title: Their Next Big Thing Is Actually Small
description: When the stage director Doug Fitch and the filmmaker Edouard Getaz speak about their collaborations, they inevitably touch on matters of scale  ways of making tiny objects seem huge, and sometimes the opposite.

title: Student Killed and 3 Are Hurt at Houston-Area High School
description: SPRING, Tex.  A fight, possibly gang related, broke out at a suburban Houston high school early Wednesday, leaving one student dead of stab wounds and three other students injured, the authorities said.

title: Let Us Now Praise Infamous Men
description: The male hero, once in ample supply, has entered a period of steady decline, and today our most iconic men are more likely to inspire cynicism than reverence.

title: V.A. to Provide Spousal Benefits to Gays, Administration Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday escalated its effort to dismantle federal barriers to same-sex marriages, announcing that the Department of Veterans Affairs would immediately begin providing spousal benefits to gay men and lesbians despite a federal statute that limits such benefits to veterans spouses who are of the opposite sex.

title: Katy Perrys Roar Dethrones Robin Thicke
description: On the music charts, summer may be ending with a Roar.

title: Verizons Deal Financing Moves Quickly, as Debt Markets Remain Open
description: Verizon Communications blockbuster deal to take full control of its wireless unit may seem dauntingly large. But for the two banks leading the arrangement of its $61 billion financing, its possible to pull off.

title: Pennetta Stays Focused on Opponents Weakness
description: Flavia Pennetta gained her first Grand Slam semifinal with a straight sets victory over Roberta Vinci, outplaying her Italian compatriot with superior consistency and an intelligent use of power. Pennetta worked over Vincis one-handed slice backhand tirelessly, playing her two-handed backhand crosscourt with depth and penetration. When Vinci ran around to play an inside-out forehand, Pennetta stepped in and laced a backhand down-the-line winner.

title: Weinstein Lands a Big-Name Executive Producer for Finding Neverland
description: The Broadway producer Barry Weissler (Pippin, Chicago) has signed on as an executive producer of Finding Neverland, the first big-budget stage musical from the filmmaker Harvey Weinstein, who is aiming the recently overhauled show for a United States premiere in 2014 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass. Given Mr. Weisslers track record of success, his involvement increases the odds that Mr. Weinstein will extend his powerful producing hand into theater in New York and London with Finding Neverland.

For anyone who buys both kinds of books, myself included, the service, which Amazon calls Kindle MatchBook, raises a simple question: What took so long?

description: THE INTERSECTION of fashion and art has produced some strange bedfellows over the last decade (Richard Prince purses for Louis Vuitton; Cindy Shermans Chanel series), but Kris Van Assche, the Dior Homme designer, takes a straightforward approach to art appreciation. He hires artists to create pieces for his stores, like the poetic Robert Montgomery light sculpture that hangs in the SoHo store.

title: Beauty in the Eye of the Dreamer
description: IF FASHION IS SPINACH, as the clothing designer and critic Elizabeth Hawes proclaimed 75 years ago, then beauty is mesclun salad: a sprightly, ever-changing mix that we continue to gobble up even though its probably overpriced.

title: Rene Fleming to Sing Streetcar at Los Angeles Opera
description: Woody Allen brought a reimagined Blanche DuBois  in the form of Cate Blanchetts Jasmine French  to the streets of San Francisco this summer in his film Blue Jasmine. Another Blanche is heading to California next spring: the Los Angeles Opera announced on Wednesday that Rene Fleming would reprise the role, which she created, in three semi-staged performances of Andr Previns opera of A Streetcar Named Desire.

description: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

title: A Macabre Mystery: Poe Ballantine Talks About Memoir and True Crime
description: For several years, Poe Ballantine has written essays about his life in the small town of Chadron, Neb., for The Sun magazine. His new book, Love & Terror on the Howling Plains of Nowhere, is part memoir and part true-crime story. In it, Mr. Ballantine writes about his own life  his chronic wanderlust, the many low-paying jobs hes held, his rocky marriage to a Mexican woman and the challenges of raising an autistic son. He also chronicles a gruesome event that shocked his quiet corner of Nebraska. In December 2006, Steven Haataja, a math professor, went missing from Chadron. In March 2007, his body was found on a ranch south of the town, bound to a tree and severely burned. Police eventually and unofficially considered the death a suicide. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Ballantine discussed his belief that Mr. Haataja was murdered, his approach to writing about his own life alongside Mr. Haatajas death, and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: For Fashion Models, Quirk Is In
description: A decade or so ago came Gisele Bndchen and the Brazilians, with their va-va-voom bodies, golden tans and sun-streaked hair. Then there was a flood of Eastern bloc models, led by Natalia Vodianova, with ethereal, almost feline features.

title: In an Unknown Territory With a Sense of Mission
description: Tarbaby opened its first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night in search-party mode, warily poking around uncertain terrain. The pianist Orrin Evans was the first on the scene, his sparsely darting intervals evoking the trace of a flashlight beam. He was soon joined by the others: Eric Revis on bass, Nasheet Waits on drums, Oliver Lake on alto saxophone. After some formless preamble, they locked into the slinky syncopations of Rolling Vamp, by Mr. Lake. It led them down a trail without giving up any secrets.

title: As Mets Season Winds Down, Audition at First Gets Started
description: ATLANTA  Once again, the dog days of August have become the dog days of September for the Mets. The club is playing irrelevant games, as far as the standings are concerned, and the ambience for the outsider does not look very inviting. The teams two biggest stars, pitcher Matt Harvey and third baseman David Wright, are injured, and the quest for a .500 season is nearly a fruitless cause.

title: Choosing Emotion Over Virtuosity
description: Pianists blessed with formidable technique are often tempted by programs that show off virtuosic extremes. In his solo recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening, Soheil Nasseri went in search of other extremes in a selection of works that demonstrated the pianos ability to reflect the whole gamut of human emotions. From the playfulness of Brahmss Capriccios and the Punch-and-Judy humor of Beethovens Sonata No. 16 in G to the bitter anguish of two powerful new pieces by Michael Hersch, Mr. Nasseri revealed a sure eye for drama and the psychologically telling detail.

description: A PREVIEW of the A-list dinners, parties and live shows during New York Fashion Week. Party photos at nytimes.com/fashion.

description: BERLIN  Samsung Electronics unveiled on Wednesday its highly anticipated digital wristwatch that can snap photos, track workouts and use an array of apps  gadgetry that the company hopes will catapult it into a market of smart portable devices that leave cellphones in users pockets.

title: They Make Nice Neighbors (and Good Belts)
description: Location, location, location, they say in real estate, but timing is important too. And the timing of the house hunters in Destination Americas new real-estate show, Buying the Bayou, couldnt be worse. They are settling into their freshly purchased waterside getaways just as mutant alligators are marching out of the swamp with blue tongues, spike-shooting tails and really bad tempers.

title: Green Eggs and E-Books? Thank You, Sam-I-Am
description: Dr. Seuss books, those whimsical, mischievous, irresistibly rhymey stories that have been passed down in print to generations of readers, are finally catching up with digital publishing.

title: A Couple, Into Themselves, Make Room for One More
description: Stop me if youve heard this one before. Theres this self-centered, seemingly shallow, young(ish) woman (or, in a pinch, man), who is totally devoted to her career and/or personal pleasure. Suddenly, out of that left field where comedy writers grow their plots, a life-changing new arrival enters this narcissists life. Why, its a little stranger, forced by circumstance into a mnage that is hardly child-friendly.

title: Abundantly Wealthy, But Not Living It Up
description: The story of how the book Empty Mansions came to be, in the words of Bill Dedman, one of its two authors, begins with an exercise in American aspiration. And when Mr. Dedman, a journalist, embarked on that exercise, he could not have guessed how right that phrase would be. In 2009 he and his wife were looking for a house outside New York City. Just for fun, Mr. Dedman Googled real estate listings in the astronomical range. He found a markdown in New Canaan, Conn., a house that had gone from $35 million to $24 million and had one very unusual feature, even more unusual than its room for drying draperies. The place had been unoccupied since it was purchased. In 1951.

title: Feeling For | A Customizable Collection From Tods
description: With a nod to the brands original name, the new J.P. Tods Sartorial Touch collection allows you to customize monk-straps, wingtip loafers, unstructured briefcases and even its iconic driving shoes in a choice of fine leathers and hand-burnished patinas.

title: The Instruments Are Typical, but the Sound Is Far From Cookie Cutter
description: Dawn of Midi is an instrumental trio from Brooklyn that makes something like minimal dance music using piano, acoustic bass and a drum kit with a high-hat but no other cymbals. Its music is all rhythm, more or less, and all composed. The individual contributions can be small, as little as one beat or note per bar, but they are cumulative, and constructed in tandem. One player completes anothers rhythmic phrase, or one players precise rhythmic cycle produces friction against anothers. The music keeps growing and changing, through distinct but unbroken episodes; it becomes a network of bones with very little meat.

title: A Live Google+ Conversation with President Carter on Global Health
description: For my second Google+ Hangout of the day, I spoke with former U.S. President Jimmy Carter about global health and how to eradicate disease.

description: Diana B. is grateful to  Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, she tells viewers. Through his innovative programs, weve been able to cut crime to its lowest level in decades in her native borough, she says.

title: Mira Nakashima: Not Far From the Tree
description: Mira Nakashima worked in the shadow of her legendary furniture-maker father, George Nakashima, for two decades. But when he died in 1990, many clients canceled their orders or demanded a discount because the pieces wouldnt have the signature of the master. For a time, his daughter, who holds two degrees in architecture, thought she would have to shutter the family business.

title: Sure, It Purifies Air, but Can It Save the Galaxy?
description: With its rectangular white body, round black eyes (a control and vent, really) and stubby feet, the Patrull air purifier from Ikea has been compared to a Star Wars robot. Part of Ikeas collection of home-safety products (patrull is Swedish for patrol), the appliance was introduced in Europe a few years ago, but has finally arrived in the United States. The unit, made of plastic, is said to be vigilant in filtering pollen, dust, dust-mite allergens and tobacco-smoke particles. Relatively small (it is a foot high) and easily portable (it weighs 11 pounds), it has three fan settings and a replaceable filter. It runs on low power (8 to 32 watts) and at a low volume (30 to 45 decibels), a plus for sensitive sleepers. Patrull is $96 and is available in Ikea stores only.

title: Tap on the Surface to See if Its Ripe
description: In 2011 Chen Chen and Kai Williams, who met as industrial design students at Pratt, opened a studio in Brooklyn after a few years of working independently. (Mr. Chen, born in China and raised in the United States and Canada, was on the staff at the design emporium Moss. Mr. Williams, the son of the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, had started a digital fabrication company.) Today they are known for their freewheeling use of materials. Their new planters and bowls shaped like cut fruit, for example, are made of Rockite, a cement often used to anchor bolts into walls. The designers make rubber molds from actual fruit and line them with the material, which hardens in place; no firing is needed. In the past year weve been working a lot in resin, but we wanted to use something not so toxic, Mr. Chen said. The cantaloupes shown here are $28 each. Information: chen-williams.com.

title: Portraits and Keepsakes of Coco Chanel
description: Coco Chanel was fiercely protective of her lifes narrative, omitting less savory details involving her working-class roots and, where revisionism fell short, outright destroying personal documents and other records. And so it is both intriguing and fortuitous (at least for those interested in demystifying her past) that in her final years, Chanel befriended the privileged and unguarded artist Marion Pike, a third-generation Californian who had already traveled throughout much of Europe by age 16 and studied at Stanford University. Pike meticulously preserved telegrams, clothing, photographs and other mementos of the duos time together. These keepsakes, along with five acrylic portraits of Chanel, are the subject of the exhibition Coco Chanel: A New Portrait by Marion Pike, which opens tomorrow at the Fashion Space Gallery in London.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) HEREAFTER (2010) Clint Eastwood imagines what happens after people die by braiding together three story lines, each involving a collision between the living and the dead. In San Francisco, George Lonegan (Matt Damon, above), who receives messages from the deceased loved ones of anyone he touches, chooses a life of obscurity instead of exploiting his gift. In London, Marcus, a solemn boy, feels the presence of his twin, Jason, whose violent death has left Marcus adrift. (The brothers are played by George and Frankie McLaren.) And in Paris, Marie Lelay (Ccile de France), who nearly died in the 2004 tsunami in South Asia, is convinced that she has seen a metaphysical reality the world is determined to ignore. Persuasion is not really the point, though if anyone could make me believe in ghosts, it would be Clint Eastwood, A. O. Scott said in The New York Times of this film, written by Peter Morgan. What does seem new  newly strange, newly beautiful  is what Hereafter makes of the here and now, Mr. Scott added. It is a curious movie in both senses of the word: an unusual experience and an open-ended inquiry into something nobody can really claim to understand. It leaves you wondering, which may be the most fitting way of saying that its wonderful.

Behind the scenes, server-based gaming now enables managers to rapidly alter payouts, raise or reduce betting minimums, even change games themselves. (In just minutes, a bank of slot machines styled for dance clubbers can be rethemed to appeal to church ladies on a Sunday afternoon.) title: A Catalog for All the Worlds Viruses?

title: Robert Rauschenberg and the New Realists in New York
description: To the restlessly inventive Robert Rauschenberg, an art material could be anything in sight. A stuffed goat, a torn shirt or tie, a wheelbarrow and even his own bed  all became fodder for paintings or sculptures, which would later incorporate sound and electronics as well. Rauschenberg had a counterpart in the Swiss-born Jean Tinguely, who had his debut at the Museum of Modern Art after arriving in New York in January 1960. The show consisted of a gigantic motorized sculpture assembled from bicycle wheels, a piano, a bathtub and other detritus, which was designed to self-destruct in flames before a live audience. Rauschenberg made an ad hoc contribution to the piece with a toaster that spit out silver dollars. That collaboration spurred a lifelong friendship that would embrace other bricoleurs of the French New Realist group then living in New York: Arman, Martial Raysse and Tinguelys future wife, Niki de Saint Phalle  all artists who subscribed to Rauschenbergs belief in closing the gap between art and life. This month, the Sperone Westwater gallery brings the group together again with Radio Waves: New York Nouveau Ralisme and Rauschenberg, an exhibition of 13 rarely seen scrap assemblages and drawings from the artists personal collection (Sept. 17 to Nov. 2).

description: THE Advertising Council and Feeding America, a domestic hunger relief organization, introduced a public service campaign on Thursday to tackle childhood hunger.

description: When Zack Wheeler takes the mound against Scott Kazmir on Friday night in Cleveland, the Mets hopes for the future will collide with one of the more embarrassing moments of their past.

title: How Amanda Lindhout Emerged on the Other Side of a Nightmare
description: Every morning before Amanda Lindhout gets out of bed, she goes through the ritual  a thought experiment of sorts  of forgiving the people who have hurt her, and also forgiving herself. Its a strategy she developed after being kidnapped when she was on the way as a journalistto visit an internally displaced persons (I.D.P.) camp in Somalia; held captive in that country for 460 days, she wassubjected to torture, starvation and repeated sexual abuse. Lindhout decided that when others harmed her, it was an indication of their own suffering  without this way of thinking, she says, she would have been so filled with fury and hopelessness that she never would have survived.

title: Months After Storm, Mennonites Stay and Rebuild
description: Within days of Hurricane Sandys arrival in New York, Frank Hoover started coordinating vans full of Mennonites to repair homes ravaged by the storm. His impromptu crews finished their farm chores in Pennsylvania Dutch country in the middle of the night and left for Staten Island or Far Rockaway, Queens, by 3 a.m. They worked 8 or 10 hours, then drove back to Lancaster County.

title: Elegantly Functional Furniture From Herms
description: For its latest collection of furniture, Herms has teamed with the up-and-coming French designer Philippe Nigro. Les Ncessaires dHerms consists of eight versatile pieces, rendered in Canaletto walnut and leather, and incorporates the elegance and whimsy  what Nigro calls the refined humor  for which the French luxury brand is known. For instance, the delicate Table  Cachette has a hidden tray that pivots out from under its top, while the Cheval-dArcons bench, which is based on the form of a pommel horse, has concealed drawers at each end as well as at its center. The point was to design really functional objects, Nigro said, but the function shouldnt be so obvious.

title: New Yorker Festival Sets 2013 Lineup
description: You know its a banner day in publishing when Billy Eichner and The New Yorker find a way to work together. Mr. Eichner, the exuberant comedian and host of the Fuse game show Funny or Dies Billy on the Street, will serve as master of ceremonies for An Evening With Funny or Die, one of the events on the lineup for this years New Yorker festival. This years annual gathering of artistic talents and contributors to The New Yorker magazine will be held from Oct. 4 through 6, its organizers said on Thursday.

title: New York Dismisses Criticism of New 911 System
description: Struck by an out-of-control driver fleeing the police, a 4-year-old girl lay dying on an Upper West Side sidewalk in early June. Officers immediately radioed for an ambulance, and one arrived about eight minutes later  an eternity to those waiting on the street. The girl, Ariel Russo, was declared dead at the hospital less than an hour later.

title: An Unusually Crowded Summer Box Office, in Charts
description: Hollywoods summer season officially ended last weekend, and overall box-office revenues were up even after adjusting for inflation. Yet there were also a lot of high-profile flops and disappointments (Lone Ranger, Turbo, R.I.P.D., White House Down, and so on). What gives?

title: Scene Partners Step Into the Void
description: The insinuating manservant would have you know that these are classier digs than youre used to. Youre in the home of a man of means, a man of achievement, says the thuggish character called Foster (at least sometimes) in Harold Pinters No Mans Land, which is being revived on Broadway this fall in a production at the Cort Theater starring Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart.

title: Lasting Lessons of a Rosh Hashana Amid a Naval Buildup
description: U.S. Adds Forces in Persian Gulf, a Signal to Iran. I surveyed this headline on the New York Times Web site in July 2012 with concern. News like this had always felt comfortably remote during my childhood on the Upper East Side and my undergraduate years at Yale, and I had assumed that would continue when I began my studies at Hebrew Union College to join the Jewish clergy.

title: Bold Experiments in Stage Chemistry
description: Great performers have always been one of the signal attractions of the theater, and in our star-besotted era they are undoubtedly the biggest draw. But nobody wants to watch even an able actor perform in a void. Pick up a stage memoir from almost any era, and the writer will likely opine that he or she did the best work when acting with equals, or with actors whose particular personas created an instant, indefinable spark when they were onstage together.

description: According to the Centers for Disease Control, 31,672 people were killed by firearms in America in 2010. Slates gun-death tally, which we include at the end of each post, has recorded 7,897 deaths since the Newtown massacre last Decemberalmost three times the total killed on Sept. 11, and nearly double the number of U.S. soldiers killed over the course of the nine-year-long Iraq War.

title: Her Job Now Includes Reeling in Money
description: For the new Broadway musical Big Fish, Susan Stroman isnt just the director and choreographer. She is also a rainmaker, leveraging her reputation as a five-time Tony Award winner for hits like The Producers and Contact to persuade investors to finance the $14 million show. She has talked up scores of potential backers at a dozen cocktail parties, dinners and receptions over the last two years, as well as at workshops and rehearsals. While she fields any and all questions, including oddball ones like her choice of lipstick for one actress, her primary role is to reassure.

title: Volvo to Recall Nearly 7,800 New Vehicles for Electrical Problems
description: Volvo will recall almost 7,800 of its 2014 models because a computer problem could cause electronic malfunctions, including a problem similar to what many will remember from Detroits malaise era where the windshield wipers operate continuously when the ignition is on, according to a report from Volvo posted Thursday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Web site.

title: Lasting Tributes Meet Early End in Bankruptcy
description: GARDEN GROVE, Calif.  The inscribed granite stones that form the Walk of Faith outside the Crystal Cathedral here were supposed to last forever, sustained in perpetuity by the thousands of dollars churchgoers paid for them. Or so parishioners were told.

title: Veterans Benefits for Same-Sex Spouses
description: The Obama Administration announced on Wednesday that the Department of Veterans Affairs would immediately begin providing benefits to gay or lesbian spouses  a welcome move, and one that followed similar decisions by the Pentagon and other federal agencies in the wake of the Supreme Courts Defense of Marriage Act ruling.

description: Most Americans say they believe the law is inadequate in protecting their privacy online. The e-mail or social media accounts of one in five have been broken into. And most American consumers take great efforts to mask their identities online.

description: BUDAPEST  There are many ghosts that walk the streets of Hungarys capital, but none is more alive than that of Ferenc Puskas.

title: A Dim Sum Outpost Far From Chinatown
description: Dim sum is undergoing a resurgence in New York, but there are not many places to get a good version of the bite-size treats in Westchester  Aberdeen in White Plains is the only restaurant that comes to mind. Now, aficionados who acquired a taste for the food in, say, Lower Manhattan can satisfy their craving at the end of a pleasant drive north of the county line. Dim Sum Go Go, an outpost of the Chinatown restaurant of the same name, opened in Beacon in April. The Dutchess County spot offers about 40 fried, steamed or baked dim sum for both lunch and dinner. In addition to being rare for the area, much of the fare is delicious  from fried shrimp balls and spring rolls with plum sauce to nearly translucent rice roll crepes, filled with, for example, simple steamed shrimp or roast duck and served with intense homemade condiments like spicy mustard and dumpling sauce.

description: I fell in love with the reopened Ryland Inn because of how we were greeted. It was a miserable, rainy night, and we were a half-hour late for our 6:30 reservation. As if she had nothing better to do than wait for us all day, a woman wearing a simple dress and cardigan approached our car, umbrella in hand, and escorted my companion and me out of the rain and into the restaurant.

title: New York Theater Ballet Is Seeking New Home After Building Is Sold
description: The New York Theater Ballet, a small company with an outsize reputation for staging classics and the work of emerging choreographers, is desperately seeking a new home, says Diana Byer, the founder and artistic director. The company has until Sept. 30 to vacate its studio and office space in Murray Hill because the building has been sold. Since 1980 the company has been at 30 East 31st Street, on the fifth floor of the parish house of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church.

title: The Short Life of a Rock Star in Offbeat Glasses
description: The actors in Buddy: The Buddy Holly Story at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport are fine musicians  no one has to pretend to play an instrument, and most of them double as the shows band. Those who impersonate recognizable people  like Holly and other stars of the era  bear a reasonable resemblance to them, even if a few look too old for their roles. But good acting? That isnt required of anyone in this production, which is directed and choreographed by D. J. Salisbury in a cartoonish style that heightens the heavy-handed exposition in the musicals book, written by Alan Janes.

title: Rise Is Seen in Students Who Use E-Cigarettes
description: WASHINGTON  The share of middle and high school students who use e-cigarettes doubled in 2012 from the previous year, federal data show. The rise is prompting concerns among health officials that the new devices could be creating as many health problems as they are solving.

description: BAGHDAD  Abu Mohaned spent Tuesday night washing the bodies of victims of that evenings car bombs, preparing them for burial. When a couple of roadside bombs went off the next day, he did the same thing.

title: Prints of Gritty Nostalgia
description: You can peer up close at the softly diminishing glow. You can back away. You can stare through one of the magnifying glasses provided at the entrance to Telling American History, the enthralling new print show at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn. But you wont be able to figure out how Stow Wengenroth (1906-1978), the Brooklyn-born master lithographer, managed to bring the diffuse haze of city streetlamps on a damp night to a sheet of inked paper.

title: 3 Cities in Running for 2020 Olympics Have Shortcomings
description: BUENOS AIRES  The recent trend of the International Olympic Committee and FIFA, the organizer of soccers World Cup, has been to award the planets two largest sporting events to cities, countries or regions that have never hosted the global competitions.

title: Fresh Look for the Fall Theater Season
description: The most celebrated play ever to originate in New Jersey is arguably Thornton Wilders Our Town, which had a one-night-only shakedown showing at the McCarter Theater in Princeton in 1938, before moving to Boston for tryouts and ultimately to Broadway.

title: A Banking Bankruptcy That Takes a Different Path
description: When a bank holding company files for bankruptcy, it usually occurs after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has taken away its banking subsidiary. In such a Chapter 11 case, the only thing left for the company to do is marshal the assets  including a typically large tax refund  and pay out the results to creditors before liquidating. Washington Mutual provides the most obvious example of this basic model.

title: Poor Infrastructure Hampers Indias Export Chances in Downturn
description: BANGALORE On the outskirts of Bangalore, Karnataka, in a manufacturing unit for Indo-US MIM Tec Private Limited, dozens of workers in blue uniforms stood behind tall, nearly noiseless machines. The equipment pumped and swerved, quietly fusing bits of metal and polymer. Founded in 1997, the company builds a range of parts for cars, factories and consumer goods using a rare manufacturing technique called metal injection molding. It pioneered the technique in India, and claims to be the worlds largest practitioner.

title: Opposition Lawmaker Arrested in Treason Plot in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An opposition lawmaker was arrested on Thursday on charges of plotting an armed rebellion to help overthrow the South Korean government in the event of war on the divided Korean Peninsula.

title: Image of the Day: Sept. 5
As Busy as His Bees
description: Chase Emmons, 45, is a managing partner and the apiary director at Brooklyn Grange, a rooftop farm with locations in Long Island City and the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He splits his time between his childhood home  a garden duplex apartment in the West Village  and a home in Sunderland, Mass. He commutes to the apiary in a 2005 Volkswagen Golf, which he adapted to run on 90 percent vegetable oil. His Sundays are spent inspecting the 35 beehives in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, helping Ben Flanner, head farmer and president of Brooklyn Grange, harvest vegetables to sell at a farmers market, and going on a nighttime run.

title: A Peculiar Peek at Thomas Pynchons Latest
description: Bloggers have called it bizarre, highly bizarre, peculiar and appropriately odd. Its the book trailer for Thomas Pynchons new novel, Bleeding Edge, which will be published on Sept. 17.

title: Amerisleep Continues to Figure Out How to Sell Mattresses Online
description: In my post last week, we took a look at how AmeriSleep is trying to overcome consumer concerns about to buying big-ticket items, like mattresses, online. Firas Kittenah, the companys chief executive, is confident he made the right decision when he closed his bricks-and-mortar retail location, but the challenges remain.

title: All the Rage | Mens Wear That Channels a Classic French Vagabond
description: It seems as if Boudu  the irrepressible tramp from Jean Renoirs 1932 masterpiece, Boudu Saved From Drowning  must have made multiple appearances on designers mood boards this season, because his dishabille swagger could be seen all over the mens runways. Dries Van Noten and Junya Watanabe channeled the disheveled drifter with a profusion of oversize tweed jackets, bathrobelike outerwear and patched-up suits. At Yohji Yamamoto, some models even wore fluffed-up Boudu-like beards.

description: Bill de Blasio has built a broad base of support in the Democratic primary for mayor, the latest New York Times/Siena College poll found.

title: Tuition Aid From a Zombie Elf
description: Douglas Johnson began his sophomore year at the State University of New York at Oswego last week in an enviable position. He made the deans list his freshman year and expects to graduate early with a double major in psychology and public justice. Even better, his family back in Watertown, N.Y., didnt have to take out any loans this fall, thanks to a scholarship that covers about half of his tuition.

title: Gut Bacteria From Thin Humans Can Slim Mice Down
description: The trillions of bacteria that live in the gut  helping digest foods, making some vitamins, making amino acids  may help determine if a person is fat or thin.

title: For Federer and Nadal, Best Debate Is Still Ahead
description: It is safe to assume that Roger Federer would not have had much of a chance against Rafael Nadal had he made it to their anticipated quarterfinal Wednesday night at the United States Open. In other news, as they used to say on Saturday Night Live, Generalissimo Francisco Franco is still dead.

title: Kerouacs Epic Road Trip Novel Was Cast Into the Limelight 56 Years Ago
description: When Jack Kerouacs novel On the Road was published by Viking Press in 1957, the Beat Generation writer had spent several years shopping it around to publishing houses. Within the staid culture of the 1950s, Kerouacs epic tale of free-for-all road tripping across America with socially liberated friends left many publishers doubtful that the book would bring anything other than obscenity charges.

description: The Roman poet Juvenal posed this pretty good question that has traveled down the centuries: Sed quis custodiet ipsos custodes?

title: Dr. Dog: Still at Home in the B-Room
description: Fresh off the summer-festival circuit and about to begin a big tour with the Lumineers, Dr. Dog stopped by the Mercury Lounge on Tuesday to reconnect with their small-room roots, unleashing a two-hour, scorched-earth campaign of songs old and new, including three from their eighth album, B-Room, which will be released Oct. 1. The show was announced only a few days in advance and sold out in minutes.

title: The Ad Campaign: Daughter Helps Present Thompson as the Education Candidate
description: William C. Thompson Jr., the mayoral choice of the influential teachers union, the United Federation of Teachers, is making education the centerpiece of his campaign in the closing days of the race for the Democratic nomination. On Wednesday, he campaigned in the morning with Michael Mulgrew and Randi Weingarten, the current and previous presidents, respectively, of the union, unveiled a five-point plan to help teachers, and then joined Mr. Mulgrew and Ms. Weingarten for a late-afternoon teleconference town hall meeting. Small wonder, then, that his latest television advertisement, Schools, released on Wednesday, also focuses on education.

title: The Perils When Megabanks Lose Focus
description: Five years ago, as Lehman Brothers teetered, there was remarkably little concern about what would happen if it failed and virtually none about what would happen to the rest of Wall Street if it did.

title: Overcommitted
description: Thanks to the magic of American national security politics, a number of young men who grew up in Nepal have found their way west, over northern India and across the breadth of Pakistan, to work at Kandahar Airfield in Afghanistan, destroying million-dollar trucks bought by American taxpayers. They wield blowtorches and wear fireproof suits in the crushing heat, and  according to reporting by Ernesto Londoo at The Washington Post  it takes about 12 hours to demolish each of the vehicles. The trucks need to be cut into pieces small enough to be fed into industrial metal shredders, which grind the parts down into tiny bits of scrap that are sold locally for a few cents per pound. In May, about 11 million pounds of this scrap were apparently sold; by now it is probably more. The contractors who buy it call it gold dust.

title: Bomb Scare
description: President Obama is drifting toward an unwarranted and ultimately unwinnable war with Iran, according to the well-known Mideast expert Kenneth M. Pollack. With Unthinkable, he hopes to persuade the administration to reverse course.

title: Critical Conditions
description: The juror was convinced  and, she believed, all of her fellow jurors were too  that a crime had occurred on that fifth day at Memorial. So concludes Sheri Finks harrowing and minutely detailed description of the hellish events that took place at a New Orleans hospital during Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath in late August and early September 2005. The members of the special grand jury convened two years after those desperate days were in agreement that the state of Louisiana should not indict Dr. Anna Pou for the murder of four patients during the disaster. Why then, did they nevertheless continue to believe that a crime had occurred? The only crime they had been assembled to investigate was homicide, the evidence for and against which they had been studying for weeks. If they thought the 51-year-old surgeon was guilty, why did they let her go free?

description: Seventy-two dollars for rabbit at a Superfund site? my friend said, incredulous, when I invited him to dinner at Glasserie, a new restaurant in Greenpoint at the northernmost tip of Brooklyn, next to oil-spill-besieged Newtown Creek. He declined.

description: Samantha Power, the new United States ambassador to the United Nations, strongly criticized Russia on Thursday in her first extensive public remarks about Syria, accusing the Kremlin of holding the Security Council hostage by blocking even modest efforts to condemn the use of chemical weapons in the Syrian conflict.

title: The Punishment for Being Publicity-Shy
description: Salinger, the doorstop-thick new biography by David Shields and Shane Salerno, announces itself on the dust jacket as the official book of the acclaimed documentary film of the same title. (The film itself credits Paul Alexanders biography of Salinger as its source.) Acclaimed is perhaps wishful thinking, but the most dubious words in that puffy phrase are documentary film. There are plenty of archival images and talking-head interviews, but Salinger, directed by Mr. Salerno, is less a work of cinema than the byproduct of its own publicity campaign. It does not so much explore the life and times of J. D. Salinger as run his memory and legacy through a spin cycle of hype. Salinger moved to the woods of New Hampshire partly to escape the intrusions and indignities of American celebrity culture. Salinger is that cultures revenge.

title: Garden of Earthly Delights
description: The extent to which teenage girls will torture their mothers knows few limits. For me, part of the program was a Ye Olde Herbalist phase. I often took over the family kitchen to brew hyssop tea and goldenseal tincture and to prepare poultices of sage and compresses of comfrey. I grew my hair very long and learned how to write my name in runes. My favorite bedtime reading was a facsimile edition of the 17th-century English botanist Nicholas Culpepers opus, The Complete Herbal. I was totally going to Scarborough Fair.

title: Horton Foote, With More to Say
description: Horton Foote, the great American playwright who made moving drama and heartfelt comedy from close examination of small-town life, died in 2009. But the Signature Theater, which presented many of Footes plays over the years, has unearthed a previously unseen play, The Old Friends, and is producing it this fall with a terrific cast, including Footes daughter Hallie Foote, Betty Buckley, Veanne Cox, Cotter Smith and Lois Smith.

description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: At Lincoln Center, the Fashion Wont Stop
description: Imagine the surprise this morning to arrive at Lincoln Center for the Richard Chai show, one of the first big ones to take place on the first official day of Fashion Week, to discover a scene of fashion bedlam. Outside in the plaza, there were beautiful women in towering shoes, beautiful women in intentionally mismatched tropical prints, beautiful women with lacquered lips, beautiful women with pale skin and oversize sunglasses and perfectly bleached hair and this seasons Saint Laurent leopard-spotted cardigan. (Thank God, I didnt buy that.) People took their pictures.
