Often owned by local runners, these stores offer much more than the standard collection of Technicolor sneakers, short shorts and carbohydrate-saturated gels available online and at larger competitors.

title: Heading to Queens, Just Not for the Tennis
description: This weekend, tennis pilgrims by the thousands will descend upon the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens, for the final matches of the United States Open. Though a tennis fan, the Miser, priced out of even the cheapest seats at Arthur Ashe Stadium, wont be one of them. But there are still plenty of good reasons to be in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park this weekend.

title: A New Divestment Focus on Campus: Fossil Fuels
description: In the 1980s, it was South Africa. In the 1990s, it was tobacco.

title: Thai Trader Settles Smithfield Insider Trading Case
description: A Bangkok-based trader has agreed to pay $5.2 million to settle accusations that he traded on insider information tied to Smithfield Foods proposed $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese food processor, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Thursday.

title: Book a Room, Help a Student
description: Rare is the Orlando hotel that doesnt openly appeal to Disney-bound travelers. But the new Alfond Inn in suburban Winter Park, Fla., offers an interesting alternative.

title: Vintage Thomas Molesworth Furniture Heads to Auction
description: The newspaper tycoon Moses Annenberg spent months at a time on a ranch in Beulah, Wyo. But he enjoyed it for only a few years in the 1930s before he was sent to prison for tax evasion.

title: Richard Avedon Portraits Go to Israel Museum
description: It was in 1994, at the Whitney Museum of American Arts Richard Avedon retrospective, that Leonard A. Lauder, the New York philanthropist who was then chairman of the Whitneys board, remembers falling in love with the photographers murals. One was of the poet Allen Ginsberg and his extended family, taken in 1970 when he posed with aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews to celebrate a reading that he and his father, Louis, gave in New Jersey. Another, Mr. Lauder recalled, was of members of the Mission Council, a group of the senior American officials guiding the Vietnam War.

title: Alec Baldwin to Host TV Interview Show on MSNBC
description: The long-rumored move of the actor Alec Baldwin to the new position of talk show host was confirmed on Thursday with the announcement that MSNBC had hired Mr. Baldwin for a once-a-week program in prime time.

title: Creatures of the Wind, for Real People
description: Hail Hyperborea was the theme of the Creatures of the Wind show at noon, though it was written in such small type on the program that what these eyes saw was Hail Hyperbole.

title: Chileans Family Files Suit in U.S. Over His Torture and Death in 73
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A former Chilean Army officer charged with murdering Vctor Jara, a popular folk singer, shortly after the 1973 military coup has been sued in a Florida court under federal laws allowing legal action against human rights violators living in the United States.

title: Australias Premier Faces Bleak Predictions on Eve of Elections
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, who emerged triumphantly from the political wilderness to regain Australias leadership this year, is battling widespread predictions of a defeat in federal elections on Saturday that would bring an end to his partys tumultuous six years in power.

title: Who Needs Melody When Youve Got a Move On?
description: In the decade since the Czech-born choreographer Dusan Tynek founded a dance company in New York, he has earned a reputation for his imagination, his choreographic craft and his musicality. Yet none of the three works in his thematically and formally unified 10th-anniversary season, which opened at BAM Fisher on Wednesday, are accompanied by music. It would seem that Mr. Tynek has handicapped himself.

title: Tanya Taylor: Spring 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Kuwaiti Sheiks Influence in Olympic World Grows
description: As hundreds of members of the sports industry elite gather this week in Buenos Aires, one member of the International Olympic Committee is likely to play a major role in all the big decisions, from which city will host the 2020 Games to which sport will be added to the roster.

title: A Soft Pitch on Education From a Hard Hitter
description: People tuning into Teach on CBS on Friday night because they see Davis Guggenheims name attached to it and expect another barn-burning look at dysfunction in the educational system may find themselves asking, What have you done with the real Davis Guggenheim and who is this bouquet-lobbing impostor?

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Bold Red Lips at Creatures of the Wind
description: Colorful, crayon-box lips like the ones seen on spring runways last year show no sign of fading for next spring. At the Creatures of the Wind show earlier today, the makeup artist James Boehmer opted for a matte orange hue that made references to the saturated, psychedelic landscape works of the artist Eugene von Bruenchenhein. After defining the lips with a burnt red pencil, Boehmer layered on Nars Timanfaya Satin Lip Pencil (available this spring), a shocking orange with a yellow base so bright it almost glows, he noted. He took a light approach elsewhere, just dusting powder on the face and a pale, shimmery green shadow around the eyes. Eyeliner and mascara were ditched entirely. The lip color almost reminds me of what your grandmother would wear in the 40s, Boehmer said. But shed wear it with a full face of makeup, eyeliner and mascara, so we stripped that away to keep the look from being too granny.

title: Costello Tagliapietra: Spring 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: A Spicy Meatball for a Spicy Bottle
description: Theres spice in those bottles, and some sunny heat. That brightness welcomes the tomatoes, herbs, eggplant, lamb and olives of the Southern Rhne region, to be sure, but it can also have more global aspirations.

title: Where Sorrow Is as Constant as the Tides
description: The images in Edwidge Danticats haunting new novel, Claire of the Sea Light, have the hard precision and richly saturated colors of a woodblock print or folk art painting: a great, Hokusai-like wave  a wall of water rising from the depths of the ocean like a giant blue-green tongue to devour fishermen and their flimsy boats; a group of girls singing and dancing on the beach, six little brown and black angels skipping around fallen sea hearts and sand dollars; a solitary woman standing alone under a flame-colored weeping willow by the cemetery gate, wearing the same plain black dress she had worn to the funerals of other townspeople.

title: Hannah Fidell on A Teacher
description: The director of the drama A Teacher discusses her film about a high school teacher who has an affair with one of her students.

title: Two Men, 58 Years and Counting. A Love Story.
description: In the last apartment they are likely ever to live in together, Kenneth Leedom and Peter Cott were talking about eros and the public life of New York  which is to say, sex on a moving subway train. Mr. Leedom is 88; Mr. Cott is 89.

title: Red Queens
description: Longtime readers of Jonathan Lethem will not be surprised to learn that New York City is the setting of his new novel, Dissident Gardens, though center stage this time is not the authors native Brooklyn or the Upper East Side but Queens  specifically, Sunnyside Gardens, the planned community complex built in the 1920s. Readers may, however, be either disappointed or relieved to find no superheroes, no aliens, not even a Tourettes-afflicted self-appointed private detective. No genre-bending this time, the novel seems to say: spanning 80 years and three generations, it realistically portrays an enchanted  or disenchanted  garden of American revolutionaries.

title: Off the Runway: Day One
description: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Pakistan, Russia and Indonesia.

title: Why Quinn Angers Voters
description: One morning last month, not long before Bill de Blasio was scheduled to appear in Greenwich Village to talk about the dangers of hospital closings  something he has done during the mayoral campaign as regularly as others take their morning juice  supporters of Christine C. Quinn staged a rival news conference to counter the criticism she has endured over the demise of St. Vincents Hospital.

title: Life Without Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: Talk of doing away with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is still just that  talk. But as Congress considers whether and how to get rid of these agencies, consumers ought to be aware of how a substantial reduction in the governments role in housing finance could affect their ability to borrow in the future.

title: Playing at NewFest
description: Images from films in NewFest 2013, at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, featuring films on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues.

title: The Refugees
description: More than 6.5 million Syrians have been displaced by the war, according to the United Nations. The New York Times visited the homes of four of them to hear their stories.

title: A Valentine for One, a Mothers Day Card for Another
description: Adore sounds like a brand of perfume or a Manhattan restaurant that opened during the stand-alone verb craze a few years back. The movie, based on the Doris Lessing novella The Grandmothers, was shown in festivals as Two Mothers. Plenty of variations on its theme of intergenerational lust can be found on the Internet, though you may want to clear your browser history after youre done searching for them.

title: Murray Loses Cool and, Soon, the Match
description: For a few hours, Andy Murray seemed to go back in time, back to the days before he had won majors, when mental meltdowns marked many of his Grand Slam efforts.

title: Jolie Among 4 Recipients of Honorary Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  Angelina Jolie will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award for her philanthropic work, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced on Thursday.

title: Putting the Sex in Homosexuality
description: Amid the euphoria following the Supreme Courts striking down the Defense of Marriage Act, allowing married gay and lesbian couples to enjoy federal benefits granted to wedded heterosexuals, one word that remains seldom heard is sex. Sex, as sexual orientation? Yes. Sexual, as in sexual equality? Yes. But the thing itself, the primal catalyst? Not much.

title: A South African Heroine, With the Flaws Air-Brushed
description: Early in Darrell J. Roodts rushed, patchy biopic, Winnie Mandela, the title character makes a grand entrance in a South African courtroom wearing a stunning outfit you might see in a glossy magazine devoted to African fashion.

title: Chteauneuf That Proves Bigger Is Not So Bad
description: The skirmish lines among wine lovers feature many flash points, subjects so divisive that antagonists bristle even before theyve said a word or tasted a drop. Napa cabernet is one, and so are natural wines. Right up there in the argumentative forefront is the southern Rhne, particularly the wines of Chteauneuf-du-Pape.

description: Farook interview video.

title: Mohhamed
description: Mohhamed interview video.

title: The Jewishness Is in the Details
description: Twenty years ago, the Jewish Museum commissioned Elaine Reichek, the artist known for embroidered and knitted social commentary, to create an installation about being Jewish. What she produced and exhibited in 1994 was A Postcolonial Kinderhood, an exceptionally savvy and elegant instance of identity politics in art.

title: Sol Lewitt
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: She Creates Herself in Multitudes
description: As we cycle through avatars in our online lives, we are discovering a new appreciation for the artist of many identities: a figure like Cindy Sherman, with her parade of photographic personae, or the younger contemporary artists Kalup Linzy and Tamy Ben-Tor, who inhabit multiple characters in their satirical videos. Multiple Occupancy: Eleanor Antins Selves, a riveting show at Columbia Universitys Wallach Art Gallery, suggests that we should also be celebrating Ms. Antin.

title: Aum Nabeel
description: Aum Nabeel interview video.

title: Modernism Blooming in Iran
description: Most accounts of modern art say, basically, one thing: the West creates while the world waits, like a grateful beggar, for a nourishing handout. This is false history. Modernism has always been a global adventure happening for different reasons, in different ways, on different schedules, everywhere.

title: Imad
description: Imad interview video.

description: Basem Rifai interview video.

title: A Stripped-Down Strongman for Our Times
description: Movies like Riddick, a satisfyingly primitive spectacle, help explain the unlikely ascendancy of Vin Diesel as a man of cinema. With his hypertrophied body and Barry White purr, Mr. Diesel  much like his more sweetly appealing brother in brawn, Dwayne Johnson  embodies a particularly salient caricature of masculinity, one that appears to transcend obvious racial identity to make him an ideal modern Everybrute. If Arnold and Sly became the cartoon emblems of Reagan-era might, Mr. Diesel has come into his own as a contemporary hero, one who suggests a postrace ideal, even as he affirms old-fashioned power with displays of annihilating violence.

title: Cristina de Middel: The Afronauts
description: Dillon

title: Whats an Avant-Garde Evening Without a Poet and Plush Toys?
description: The poet Steve Dalachinsky  is as consistent an indicator of a high-quality concert experience as any I have found during 20 years of concertgoing in New York. Surely, you reckon, hes also seen some duff dates in his decades as a regular habitu of the citys nightclubs, concert halls, lofts and provisional spaces. But I have trouble recalling any significant, edifying or exhilarating free-jazz or total-improvisation concert Ive attended at which Mr. Dalachinsky has not been in the audience, rough-edged, congenial and ready with an opinion.

description: Front Desk Apparatus

description: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

description: Morgan Library & Museum

description: 47 Canal

description: James Fuentes

title: Getty Images Announces Winners of Photography Grants
description: PERPIGNAN, France  Eugene Richards received his second Getty Images Grant for editorial photography Thursday evening at the Visa Pour lImage photography festival. The grant will allow him to expand his project, War Is Personal, about Iraq war veterans returning to the United States. His earlier work, which resulted in a book, was partially funded by his first Getty Images Grant in 2008.

title: Secretary, Take a Letter, and Be Sure to Type It Fast
description: Charm. It emanates like a seductive natural perfume from those who are blessed with it. But this elusive quality can also be cultivated. If you cant put your finger on exactly what charm is, you recognize it from the moment you fall under its spell.

title: A Delicate Balance Tested
description: A full appreciation of Lynn Sheltons new-age comedy, Touchy Feely, depends on your knowledge of reiki. In this gentle holistic therapy that originated in Japan, a practitioner moves healing energy through the body using touch or passing the hands above the body. Although I have tried reiki, I cant personally attest to major psychological or spiritual benefits. But it certainly didnt hurt. What you take away from it may depend on the faith you invest in it.

title: Xiaomi Makes Another Big Move in Consumer Electronics
description: TAIPEI  Fresh from poaching a top Google executive to lead its global expansion plans, the Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi on Thursday announced another jaw-dropper: a 3-D television with a 47-inch screen, capable of hooking up to Internet, all for less than $500.

title: 36 Hours in Berlin
description: Berlin, which has been Germanys modern capital for only 23 years, has reached a coming-of-age moment. As it attempts to evolve from a city that relies heavily on government support to one with sustainable industries, companies like Google and Etsy have opened up offices, joining technology start-ups like SoundCloud and ResearchGate, giving credit to the hype that Berlin is becoming a contender for Europes Silicon Valley.

title: Scenes From the German Capital
description: Eat, drink and browse your way around Berlin.

title: The Condo Conversion Crunch
description: On first blush, it looks like Carol Cohen, a top residential broker in Manhattan who has counted the fashion designer Vera Wang and the publishing scion Lachlan Murdoch as clients, has a great setup. She lives with her husband in a sprawling two-bedroom apartment on a prime block on Park Avenue, for which she pays about $3,000 a month in rent, far less than the $9,500 a month a nearby two-bedroom on Park Avenue costs.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Musicians Reject Latest Contract Offer
description: The labor standoff that cost the Minnesota Orchestra its entire last season, and is imperiling the coming season, was extended on Thursday, when the orchestras locked-out players voted to reject the latest contract offer put forward by management.

description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Woman Who Wrote About Life Under the Taliban Is Killed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The author of a popular memoir of life under the Taliban that was made into a major Bollywood movie was shot dead early Thursday morning, 18 years after militant leaders sentenced her to death after she refused to wear a burqa in public.

title: Police Hunt for Driver Who Raced Around Manhattan
description: The old debate raised by participants in the Cannonball Baker Sea-to-Shining-Sea Memorial Trophy Dash in the 1970s is back: Can a good driver drive fast without endangering other motorists? Our laws and those who enforce them say no, they cannot, but there are some people willing to challenge that notion.

title: The Once and Future Marquand
description: Who now remembers the name of Henry Gurdon Marquand, the financier who was one of the great art collectors of the 19th century? In the 1880s he put up one of the most opulent of the Fifth Avenue-style mansions  but he built it on Madison Avenue. It vanished a century ago, leaving only a monogram, but now the Marquand name is back.

description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Food Matters | Ali Larters Book of Seasonal Menus for Homegrown Parties
description: Ali Larter, the Los Angeles-based actress best known for her roles in Heroes and Varsity Blues, nearly put herself under house arrest for two and a half years while creating her first cookbook, Kitchen Revelry ($32.50, St. Martins Press). This book has been my every day, nights and weekends, said Larter, who wrote and art directed the petite little party book, as she put it, at home. Its taken over my house. And it was all accomplished with what Larter called an incredible team of women: her good friend Tracy Zahoryin visited almost daily to help taste and develop the recipes, which Alison Attenborough food styled around Larters home and Amy Neunsinger photographed while friends and family poured in, gobbling it all up. (Her nearest and dearest are pictured in the book, too.)

description: Photos from Asia Societys new exhibition of Iranian artwork.

title: Secret Documents Reveal N.S.A. Campaign Against Encryption
description: Details on N.S.A. efforts to defeat widely used Internet encryption technologies.

title: Weight Off Your Mind
description: My husband and I have a beautiful 6-month-old daughter. She is chubby but not overweight by any means. My mother-in-law, who obviously has a weight obsession and is quite thin, has started making comments about my daughters size: I cant believe her legs are so big when she kicks all the time. Or: Shell thin out when she starts to crawl. My husband knows that these comments bother me, but he will not address them with her. I want to protect my daughter from her grandmothers damaging and unhealthy fixation with weight. What should I do?

title: Countdown to Fashion Week
description: In a five-part series of reports on young, under-the-radar fashion designers we visit each at a different stage in the process as they prepare for New York Fashion Week.

title: A Low-Rise Feel at High-Rise Prices
description: The apartments that agents begin leasing this month at 50 North 5th Street, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will be among the first rental buildings in the neighborhood to offer the kind of perks that have become increasingly common in the neighborhoods most expensive condominiums.

title: Timken Agrees to Split in Two After Pressure From Activist Investors
description: Activist investors scored another victory on Thursday when the board of the Timken Company agreed to spin off its steel business from its industrial bearings operations amid pressure from two big shareholders.

title: Marissa Webb: Spring 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Spare Times for Sept. 6-12
description: NYC Century Bike Tour (Sunday) Cooler weather this weekend may turn a bicyclists thoughts to this annual ride  the 24th  through the streets, parks and green spaces of the city. Sponsored by Transportation Alternatives, the tour features courses of 15 to 100 miles, with all the bumps, dips and climbs of open streets, as well as the relative smoothness of bicycle paths and the straightaways of bridges.

title: Chained to the Hearth or Warmed by It?
description: I have waited my whole life to be oppressed.

title: Past and Future, Scrolling By
description: The Pictures Generation of artists from the 1970s and 1980s extended Pop arts fascination with mass-media images to show how sophisticated and seductive they could be  and how, despite the supposed divide between high art and mass culture, the two were frequently made by the same people. Tracking the Thrill, at the Kitchen, a selection of works by Gretchen Bender (1951-2004), makes this explicit by exhibiting her artworks alongside music videos she edited for bands like Megadeth, R.E.M. and New Order, and the credits she created in 1988 for the Fox networks Americas Most Wanted.

title: Samantha Power on Syria
description: Ms. Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, spoke at a news conference on the crisis in Syria.

title: Broadway Annie to Close in January
description: The Broadway revival of Annie, which opened last November to lukewarm reviews, will close at the Palace Theater on Jan. 5, 2014, after 38 preview performances and 487 regular performances, the producers announced on Thursday.

title: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Inmates End Hunger Strike in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Inmates at California state prisons have ended a two-month hunger strike, corrections officials and inmate advocates announced on Thursday.

title: Russia: Bill Would Allow Children to Be Taken Away From Gay Parents
description: In the latest sign of government pressure on gay men and lesbians in Russia, a member of the State Duma, the lower house of Parliament, has proposed a bill that would allow the authorities to take custody of children if one or both of their parents are gay. Russia is already facing a barrage of international criticism, including some calls for a boycott of the coming Winter Olympics in Sochi, over a new law that bars propaganda on nontraditional sexual relationships. Supporters of the law say it is intended to protect children, while critics argue that it is a transparent effort by officials to suppress homosexuality. In an interview with The Associated Press and the state-controlled Channel 1 television station that was made public on Wednesday, President Vladimir V. Putin insisted that gay men and lesbians do not face government-sanctioned discrimination. The legislation was introduced this week by Aleksei Zhuravlyov, a member of United Russia, the party that nominated Mr. Putin for president and controls a majority in the Duma.

title: Sophisticated Cameras to Begin Tracking Every N.B.A. Play
description: By most accounts, Carmelo Anthony was a better, more dedicated passer last season. Knicks fans saw it. Teammates praised him for it. Yet Anthonys assist average, 2.6 per game, was the lowest of his career. Clearly, there was a piece missing in this equation.

title: Shaving Seconds
description: Average response time to some 911 calls has improved slightly since last year.

title: Israel Backs Limited Strike Against Syria
description: JERUSALEM  President Obamas position on Syria  punish President Bashar al-Assad for using chemical weapons without seeking to force him from power  has been called half-pregnant by critics at home and abroad who prefer a more decisive American intervention to end Syrias civil war.

title: The Importance of the Start to Running
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: In an Affair With a Student, Someone Learns Painful Lessons
description: Long on atmosphere and short on believability, A Teacher tracks a young Texas high-school teacher sometime after she has started having sex with one of her students. Diana (Lindsay Burdge) is pounding drinks at a bar with her roommate not long after this debut feature by Hannah Fidell opens, giggling at a text message on her cell. Soon enough, though, shes breaking the law with her mystery texter, Eric (a solidly real Will Brittain), in a car parked on a suburban street so inky black and conveniently deserted that the setting looks like what it is: a location that was cleared for a shoot.

title: National Parks Try to Appeal to Minorities
description: LA PUSH, Wash.  Thrusting out into the Pacific Ocean, Olympic National Park can feel like a lost world, with its ferny rain forests, violent surf and cloud-shrouded peaks.

title: Mayoral Run by Putin Critic Vexes Kremlin
description: MOSCOW  The ground rules were set in the moments before the mayor, Sergei S. Sobyanin, arrived on the Kremlin embankment of the Moscow River accompanied by Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church.

title: Navalny Shakes Up Moscow Mayors Race
description: In 2013, as Moscow prepared for its first mayoral elections in a decade, the anti-corruption candidate Aleksei A. Navalny energized the youth vote, irritating the Kremlin.

title: Poor, Black and Hispanic Women Are More Often Counseled on Emergency Contraception
description: The number of women using emergency contraceptives  commonly known as the morning-after pill or Plan B  has increased significantly in the last decade, according to the results of a new survey released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. From 2002 to 2006-10, the percentage of women who reported using an emergency contraceptive in the last 12 months rose to 2.2 percent from 0.9 percent, a 144 percent change.

title: Market Report | Mens Watches That Keep a Low Profile
description: After years of bigger and more complicated movements, watches are returning to a slender profile, reminiscent of early-20th-century classics. Here, a few ultrathins.

title: Facebook Delays New Privacy Policy
description: Facebook has apparently decided to delay a proposed new privacy policy after a coalition of privacy groups asked the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday to block the changes on the grounds that they violated a 2011 settlement with the regulatory agency.

title: Thats One Devil of a Fixer-Upper
description: Leslie Bibb certainly puts her all into the job of carrying the spawn of Satan in Hell Baby. But the film, written and directed by Robert Ben Garant and Thomas Lennon, rarely dares to be smart, settling instead for familiar gags that would have the Devil himself yawning.

title: A Biotech King, Dethroned
description: He was once hailed as the king of biotechnology. In the industrys frontier days, David Blech was the top gunslinger, quick to draw his checkbook to start new companies or prop up faltering ones.

title: Stuck in Mexico City Traffic
description: In a crowded city of 20 million people and about four million cars, congestion is a way of life.

title: Stranded in a Sea of Cars, Where Speedometers Barely Budge
description: MEXICO CITY  From the top of a tall building on a clear night, the traffic here looks like a stream of light  bright white flowing one way, ruby red the other. On the ground, however, its painfully obvious that the opposite is true: nearly everyone is stuck.

title: Rallies for Immigration Overhaul Planned
description: Groups supporting an immigration overhaul said they were planning a mobilization early next month to press the House of Representatives to vote on a bill giving legal status to illegal immigrants. They will hold rallies in at least 40 cities nationwide on Oct. 5 and a large rally in Washington on Oct. 8, said Gustavo Torres, executive director of Casa de Maryland, one of the organizations leading the events. Immigrant leaders said they hoped to keep pressure on House lawmakers so they would not lose sight of immigration amid debates over military action in Syria and the budget.

title: Donovan Returns, But Does He Make U.S. Team Better?
description: SAN JOS, Costa Rica  No player has scored more goals for the United States mens national team than Landon Donovan, and six months after his 31st birthday, he insists that he has never performed better on a soccer field than at this moment.

title: Love in a Time of Quarantine
description: Save the toddler, save the world is the premise of Flu, a South Korean riff on Steven Soderberghs Contagion that thumbs its nose at that films measured restraint. Charging gleefully over the disaster movie cliff, the director, Kim Sung-soo  whos been lying low since making his goofy 2003 comedy, Please Teach Me English  has clearly decided to return with a bang.

title: Kenyan Lawmakers Vote to Leave International Court
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenyas Parliament took the first step toward withdrawing the country from the International Criminal Court on Thursday, less than a week before Kenyas deputy president goes on trial in The Hague.

title: A Japanese Social App Contacts New Shores
description: TOKYO  Traditionally, Japanese bow when greeting others. They do not tend to shake hands. But millions of them have started shaking their smartphones.

title: Zvonko Busic, 67, Croatian Hijacker, Dies
description: Zvonko Busic, a Croatian nationalist who used fake explosives in 1976 to hijack a Trans World Airlines flight out of La Guardia Airport and planted a real bomb beneath Grand Central Terminal that killed a police officer, was found dead at his home in Rovanjska, Croatia, on Sunday. He was 67.

title: Macroeconomics and the Little Guy
description: American Made Movie is harmless propaganda on behalf of re-establishing American manufacturing and encouraging consumers to support it. But it contains a contradiction of sorts, attributing the decline of the manufacturing sector to macroeconomic forces seemingly beyond anyones control, while pinning the hopes for reversing it on small-scale successes and plucky individuals.

title: Academias Fog of Male Anxiety
description: This is the fourth of five posts this week on women in philosophy.

title: The Bush Burden
description: Hes there in every corner of Congress where a microphone fronts a politician, there in Russia and the British Parliament and the Vatican. You may think George W. Bush is at home in his bathtub, painting pictures of his toenails, but in fact hes the biggest presence in the debate over what to do in Syria.

title: Europe Offers U.S. a Deal, Hoping for Global Rules on Airline Emissions
description: BRUSSELS  Seeking to end years of acrimony, the European Union has made concessions to the United States to try to gain support for global rules on airline emissions.

title: Hi, Its Your Doctor

title: Whats on Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) ZERO DARK THIRTY (2012) Jessica Chastain, in an Oscar-nominated role, portrays Maya, a C.I.A. officer obsessed with finding Osama bin Laden, in Kathryn Bigelows fictionalized intelligence procedural. (Above, Ms. Chastain with Christopher Stanley.) Tushaar Mehra is Abu Ahmed al-Kuwaiti, the lead that Maya and her colleagues, including Dan (Jason Clarke) and Jessica (Jennifer Ehle), chase over the next eight years, using controversial interrogation techniques on prisoners to extract information. The abuse scenes are crucial to Zero Dark Thirty because they serve as a claim  one made cinematically rather than with speeches  that these interrogation methods are unreliable when it comes to producing actionable information, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. To omit them would have been a reprehensible act of moral cowardice. She added: Ms. Bigelows direction here is unexpectedly stunning, at once bold and intimate: she has a genius for infusing even large-scale action set pieces with the human element. One of the most significant images is of a pool of blood on a floor. Its pitiful, really, and as the movie heads toward its emphatically nontriumphant finish, it is impossible not to realize with anguish that all that came before  the pain, the suffering and the compromised ideals  has led to this.

title: Americas Self-Defeating Wars
description: Regarding Forcing Obamas hand in Syria (Views, Sept. 2): Vali Nasr, dean of Johns Hopkins Universitys Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies, is wrong to say that it is in Americas interest to take decisive action against the Assad regime. Our economic woes at home are the result of trying to settle ancient tribal disputes in Iraq, Afghanistan and a few North African countries. Now we are contemplating an attack on Syria. But we will never end these tribal disputes, no matter how many American lives are lost in the process or how many U.S. dollars are spent. title: Who Made That Catchers Mask?
description: In the early 1870s, catchers played bare faced. Balls routinely struck their eyes, broke their noses and knocked out their teeth. The danger increased when catchers, who had stood two dozen feet behind the batter, moved closer to the plate  an innovation, says the baseball historian Peter Morris, that allowed the top pitchers to throw their best pitches. The facial injuries finally decreased when a team from Harvard University rigged up a mask to protect its catchers that resembled a sturdy bird cage. The manager of the team, Frederick Thayer, patented the mask in 1878. Fans hated it. When the Harvard catcher James Tyng stepped onto the field with his head swaddled in steel and leather, he endured jeers from the crowd  people hooted at the mad dog who had to be muzzled. Editorial writers complained that the innovation detracted from the game. What was next  a lightning rod to save the catcher from freak storms? Would players limp around the bases with stovepipes on their legs for protection?

title: Top Coaches Evaluate Trends at Junior Tournament
description: Martin Redlicki was upset. Shaking his head and raising his arms, he watched shot after shot skim past him into the corners for winners.

title: Persistent Scars of Long-Term Joblessness
description: Hugely elevated levels of long-term unemployment remain one of the worst and most persistent scars from the Great Recession, as underscored yet again in the mediocre August jobs report. All in all, about 4.3 million Americans have been out of work for six months or more.

title: The Right to Remain Silent
description: While applying for a new job, I may need to state whether I have ever been arrested. I was arrested a few years ago for leaving the scene of a fender bender. I strenuously argued my innocence, and the charges were dropped and even erased  so I have been arrested but never charged with a crime. I am comfortable explaining the situation, but do I have an ethical duty to disclose this information on the application? JIM, VERMONT

title: The 8.25.13 Issue
A Pro Surfers Tips for Being Chill
description: Miley Cyruss literary foil; Mark Leibovich questions evolution; Mario Batalis peach julep.

title: The Old Haunts
description: The intersection of Route 27 and Main Street in East Hampton has charmed and delighted me since I was a child. There is the postcard loveliness: the town pond reflecting reeds and sky, the swans, the worn cemetery stones set in lush grass. Every summer of my childhood I felt that catch-your-breath thrill at the unchanging sight of it as my father drove us through town for our two-week vacation in what he called the country.

title: The Bond Market
description: Portraits of the women who played opposite 007.

title: Bond Girl
description: In an excerpt from Taryn Simons coming film, Honey Ryder (Nikki van der Zyl), 1962, Nikki van der Zyl reads the lines she dubbed for the first Bond film, Dr. No.

title: Today in Small Business: Gratuity Not Included
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: American Tower Adds Wireless Infrastructure in $3.3 Billion Deal
description: With Americans hungry for wireless services, one owner of broadcast towers is making a play to expand its reach.

title: Decision to Publish Against Government Request Was Not a Particularly Anguished One
description: The New York Times has come under fire in the past for agreeing to government requests to hold back sensitive stories or information, but it bucked such requests in publishing a front-page article in Fridays paper.

title: Lives of the Cells
description: Cancer would seem a dreary, frightful topic if it werent also such a universal one. In this era of longer human life spans, its almost as inevitable as death and taxes. Most of us will experience some form of cancer  if not in our own bodies then at close remove, through the suffering of loved ones  and therefore none of us can afford to ignore it. Knowledge is better than ignorant dread, and good writing based on keen reporting is far better than medical jargon, garbled hearsay or misinformation from the Web. Thats just one reason for reading George Johnsons graceful book, The Cancer Chronicles. Another is that the biological details of just what cancer is and how it occurs are (forgive me for saying so) fascinating. And not just fascinating but also, as handled by Johnson, revealing of certain deep truths about life itself. Those truths involve two elemental concepts, familiar (if dimly) from high school biology and physics: mitosis and entropy. More on that fateful pair in a moment.

title: A Special Purchase to Curb Behavior Could, Just as Easily, Terrify a Pet
description: BACK in March, I wrote about a wily raccoon that kept sneaking into our house through a swinging cat door.

title: Twitter Suspends Somali Militants Account, Cutting a Link to the Wider World
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Shabab militant groups Twitter account, home to a stream of messages at once threatening and mocking, has been suspended for the second time this year.

title: Google Introduces New Desktop Apps
description: Even if Google is ready to live entirely online, everyone else might not be.

title: Wheelies: The Hip Mercedes Edition
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wM2KDQskhHA

title: Just Before Brooklyn Boys Funeral, 2 Arrests in His Killing
description: Hours before mourners began filing past the open coffin of a 16-month-old Brooklyn boy who was fatally shot in his stroller last weekend, detectives on Friday broke into a Pennsylvania apartment and arrested two suspects in the killing.

title: Listen Up | The British Folk Rockers Bears Den Explore the American Frontier
description: I think that honesty as a universal language is a really cool idea, said Andrew Davie, the lead vocalist and guitarist of the acoustic folk-rock trio Bears Den. The bands debut EP, Agape, bears out that sentiment. Released last week by the independent label Communion Records, its a collection of lyrically sincere and emotionally raw songs. It also reflects the bands D.I.Y. approach, right down to the hand-carved potato paw prints they stamp every CD with. (Davie and his bandmates Kevin Jones and Joey Haynes showed up to their breakfast interview last month with their hands still stained with paint from the night before.)

title: Crying for the Common Father
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  Vietnamese people can find an aphorism by Ho Chi Minh for nearly any occasion. A favorite schoolyard banner has him saying: For the sake of 10 years, we must plant trees; for the sake of 100 years, we should cultivate people.

title: Final Showdown
description: Where, where is the town? Talking Heads sang. Now, its nothing but flowers.

title: The Drift of Years
description: Over a decade ago, The New Yorker ran a short story Ive never been able to forget. A wisp of a thing, barely more than twice the length of this review, it contains little action, less plot. It doesnt seem to be about anything  except a whole life. We meet the unnamed protagonist as a child clearing ice-cream dishes from the family dinner table, surreptitiously licking the creamy dregs from each one. We glimpse her as a teenager necking on the couch, as a young wife reveling in the domestic sensuality of motherhood, as an older woman attending her husbands deathbed, even then unable to keep from physical contact, her open lips brushing . . . the surgical tape that secured the respirator in his mouth. In the end, Alice McDermotts Enough is a portrait of a woman filtered through a sensory lens, capturing the life of the body, replete with exultation and ache. Which means this is also a story about mortality.

title: Memorial Days
description: His names all wrong for starters. Steve Rush, Marty Rush, Jake Rush all have a hard-boiled literary glamour. There is even a DJ Rush. But Norman? Only one last name goes with Norman, and that was nabbed by Mailer. Rush couldnt be more inappropriate; Norman has never been in a. . . . His first book, Whites, a story collection, was published in 1986, when he was 53. Between that and Subtle Bodies there have been just two novels: a long one, Mating, and the even longer Mortals. Its not the frequency of these sturdy ol buses so much as their speed that is remarkable, their emphatic rejection of notions of narrative urgency. Walking, to put it oxymoronically, is Rushs preferred pace. In Mating the narrator recounts how she hiked to a utopian village presided over by the enigmatic Denoon, on whom she had developed a high-I.Q. crush. This was not a stroll to Fruitlands in Massachusetts; it was a trek through the Kalahari. She barely made it, almost gave up the ghost. Me too.

title: Two Indias
description: In late June, a television reporter named Narayan Pargaien spent three days in the northern Indian state of Uttarakhand to cover the regions devastating monsoon floods, which have killed more than 5,700 people. Like most journalists covering the disaster, Pargaien dutifully described families who had lost everything, including their modest thatch-roofed homes. Unlike most journalists, Pargaien reported from the scene while perched on the shoulders of a flood victim in the middle of a swollen river. As the outrage poured in, Pargaien tried to explain himself. In an interview with the Indian Web site Newslaundry, he said the man who carried him had insisted upon it. He was grateful to us and wanted to show me some respect, Pargaien said, as it was the first time someone of my level had visited his house.

title: By Design
description: With this issue, the Book Review unveils its first full redesign since 2007. Under the guidance of our art director, Nicholas Blechman, and Kelly Doe, The Timess director of design, were now sleeker, more engaging and more vibrant. The new design updates the reviews that form the heart of our presentation and showcases the other features rounding out each issue  two of which debut this week. As Blechman puts it, The redesign gives the Book Review more of a feel of a magazine  improved pacing between sections, with smaller features in the front and a reinvented back of the book.

title: Difficult Women
description: WHO ASKED YOU?By Terry McMillanViking, $27.95.

title: Paperback Row
description: ELSEWHERE,  by Richard Russo. (Vintage, $15.) In this bittersweet memoir, the Pulitzer-winning novelist reflects on his enduring bond with his mother  a proud, idiosyncratic working woman  and the decaying industrial town she spent her life trying to escape. Balancing darkly funny anecdotes and profound sympathy, Russo has a fine, subtle way of describing how he saw himself and his mother, Meg Wolitzer wrote in the Book Review.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE CHILDHOOD OF JESUS,  by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $26.95.) With hints of Beckett and Kafka, Coetzees enigmatically titled dystopian allegory presents a quasi-socialist state in which conformity and anonymity are the highest values.

title: Inside the List
description: She Is Me: Genre writers are generally spared the hoary advice to write what you know. George R. R. Martin has never bludgeoned anybody with a battle-ax (as far as I can tell), and Jane Austen probably never met a zombie. But Kathy Reichs  whose mysteries about the forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan sold well even before they were adapted for the Fox television series Bones  knows where shes coming from. Reichs earned her Ph.D. in physical anthropology from Northwestern University in 1975, and among other highlights in her busy career she has consulted with the United Nations on the Rwandan genocide and helped to identify the remains of 9/11 victims in Manhattan. Tempe Brennan, in other words, is a lot like her creator. Shes me, Reichs told a Canadian TV interviewer last month. She does what I do. . . . She thinks the way I think.

title: Born of Struggle
description: Between 14 million and 20 million Chinese died in the war of resistance to the end against Japan last century. Another 80 million to 100 million became refugees. The conflict destroyed Chinas great cities, devastated its countryside, ravaged the economy and ended all hopes for a modern, pluralistic society. The narrative of the war is the story of a people in torment, Rana Mitter, a professor of Chinese history at Oxford University, writes in his superb work, Forgotten Ally.

title: One Months Data May Not Sway the Fed
description: A number of economic commentators said Friday morning that the disappointing August jobs report makes it less likely the Federal Reserve would begin to pull back in September from its economic stimulus campaign.

title: Letting Go
description: In 1968, a letter to The British Medical Journal titled Not Allowed to Die described the ordeal of a retired 68-year-old doctor admitted to an overseas hospital (almost certainly in America) with metastatic stomach cancer. After much of his stomach was surgically removed and a blood clot cleared from his lung, he asked that no further steps be taken to prolong his life, for the pain of his cancer was now more than he would needlessly continue to endure. Two weeks later the unfortunate doctor had a heart attack in the hospital. His heart was shocked and restarted five times in a single night; morning found him in a persistent vegetative state. His body remained alive for another three weeks.

title: In Toronto, Fifth Estate Filmmakers Embrace Ambiguity
description: TORONTO  Thumbs up, thumbs down, I find that very limiting.

title: Other Peoples Pain
description: If your best friend has just had his heart broken, give him a copy of Tom Barbashs new collection of stories, Stay Up With Me. Inscribe it: Everybody in this book is worse off than you. Barbashs characters are lonely, unhappy and at least temporarily ruined. And yet theres something addictive about these stories  like potato chips or a stiff drink.

title: Journey Into Darkness
description: Amanda Lindhout grew up rough. Born in Alberta, Canada, she spent childhood nights lying in her top bunk, listening to her mother, Lorinda, being beaten badly by her boyfriend. By the fourth grade, Lindhout was Dumpster diving for bottles and cans with her older brother. Flush with recycling money, she haunted a nearby thrift store to buy National Geographics. Between the yellow borders, she studied the mossy temples at Angkor, skeletons brushed free of volcano ash on Vesuvius, Palestinian refugee children squatting in tents the color of potatoes. She trained her mind to escape from the violence around her.

title: A Cool Classic, Sliced and Diced
description: Cucumbers are the ultimate summer vegetable  cool, crisp and refreshing. So its only fitting that Martha Rose Shulman celebrates the cucumber as we say goodbye to the sunny, hot days of summer and usher in the fall. She writes:

title: Obama Falls Short on Wider Backing for Syria Attack
description: STRELNA, Russia  President Obama raced home on Friday to confront one of the biggest tests of his presidency as he ramped up a campaign to persuade Congress to support airstrikes against Syria that many world leaders he had consulted declined to back.

title: The Case Against Tapering in September
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: The Gun Report: September 6, 2013
description: Weve written a few times about Jewelry for a Cause, which melts down guns procured from buybacks in New Jersey and makes bracelets and necklaces out of them. Many of the firearms collected in these buybacks were acquired illegally, and destroying them means taking them out of circulation. To those concerned with public safety, this would seem to be a good thing.

title: Syria News Quiz
description: The New York Times invites you to test your knowledge of the Syrian civil war and its effects across the region.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: In the Wake of Katrina
description: This week, Sheri Fink discusses Five Days at Memorial; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Katy Butler talks about Knocking on Heavens Door; Jennifer McDonald introduces the new feature Bookends; George Johnson discusses The Cancer Chronicles; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: A Lasting Experiment With Music
description: There are no wrong notes on Coming Apart, the first album by Body/Head, a duo of the musicians Kim Gordon and Bill Nace. Nor is there a possibility of any.

title: The Exclusive | 655 Park Avenue
description: A one-of-a-kind 12-room duplex at 655 Park Avenue is about to enter the market at $16.9 million.

title: On Park Avenue: Elegant and Homey
description: A one-of-a-kind 12-room duplex at 655 Park Avenue, whose distinctive layout was commissioned in 1924 by its first owner, a Rockefeller family member with a fondness for massive marble fireplaces and antique English pine woodwork, is about to be placed on the market by its third owner, Karen McGarry Karp.

title: For Cheaper Homes, Skip Manhattan
description: With the prevalence of fierce bidding wars for apartments in Manhattan, homes that get poached within a day of the open house, and interest rates that keep inching up, a buyer could become so frustrated by hunting for real estate in the 212 area code that he or she might just decide to give up.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: In the Wake of Katrina
description: This week, Sheri Fink, Katy Butler and George Johnson.

title: For Kenneth Cole, a Tweet Too Far
description: In the Encounters profile of Kenneth Cole that ran in Thursday Styles this week, mention was made of the designers penchant for creating provocative advertisements that used real-world social issues  among them gun control, AIDS and abortion  to grab the attention of potential customers.

title: 10 Questions for Tom Cole
description: Representative Tom Cole, Republican of Oklahoma, spoke with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC on Syria and the coming fiscal negotiations.

title: Oklahomans React to Syria and Obama
description: At a town hall gathering in Midwest City, Okla., Representative Tom Cole listened to constituents sound off on whether the United States should take military action against Syria.

title: Obama Discusses Syria at the G-20 Summit
description: In St. Petersburg, President Obama continued to hold his ground on Syria. He also said he intended to make his case in an address Tuesday to the American people.

title: Fanfare Straining to Be Heard
description: Benjamin Britten was delighted to have been born on Nov. 22, the feast day of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of musicians and church music. That the year of his birth, 1913, was also the centennial of Verdi and Wagner is something Britten never particularly remarked upon in later life.

title: Evoking Older Ideals and Earthly Realities
description: Not on the outside looking in, Gregory Porter crows in passing during The In Crowd, one of the few cover songs on Liquid Spirit, his soulful and assured new album. And in case you didnt detect the mix of pride, validation and relief in that ad-libbed status report, Mr. Porter soon offers another one  It feels nice  that forms a malleable refrain as the tune struts to a close.

title: British Ingenuity, Delivered by Americans
description: The most extraordinary dance adventure in 2013-14 in the United States is hard to believe even when you know all about it. Its set to happen on the Gulf Coast; and it concerns a dead choreographer who wasnt American.

title: Innovations With Fairy Tales
description: By tradition, ballet traffics in transformation. Most full-evening narratives that are the bread and butter of ballet companies draw their stories from fairy tales. New productions must find fresh life in much-used material, transforming it without forsaking the familiar. This fall two recent, high-profile remakes of classic stories will arrive in New York, coincidentally on the same day.

title: The Balance of a Career
description: LOS ANGELES  Of all the things the artist Chris Burden did, and had done to, his body for the sake of art  shot, through the arm, with a .22 rifle; nailed, through the hands; cut, with broken glass; confined, for five days inside a tiny locker  perhaps his most poetic performance piece was the simplest.

title: Sounds of Darkness and Ancient Jealousy
description: When Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, inaugurated the White Light Festival in 2010 as a means to illuminate spirituality in disparate works, she set off a debate about transcendence in music and what role a commercial festival might (or might not) play in a listeners spiritual journey.

title: Design at Home, in Gardens, Up Walls
description: Old things that astonish and enlighten keep emerging from the shadows. In exhibitions and auction previews this autumn, long-hidden objects tell stories about Venezuelan pearls, Vesuvian eruptions, the political ramifications of British garden follies, porcelain forms that simulate craggy Western vistas and battles for fame in the pencil-making industry.

title: Kanye West Plans Seven-Week Tour in Fall
description: Kanye West will headline his first solo tour in five years to promote his album Yeezus, it was announced on Friday. Press representatives for the tour said in a news release that the Yeezus Tour, as it is called, will begin Oct. 19 at the Key Arena in Seattle and run for seven weeks, when it will conclude Dec. 7 at the Toyota Center in Houston. New York-area tour dates include a Nov. 19 appearance at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn and a Nov. 23 appearance at Madison Square Garden.

title: 10 Questions for Tom Cole
description: Representative Tom Cole, a Republican, has brought the pragmatism of a former political operative to his work representing Oklahomas Fourth Congressional District. He served as a bridge between the two parties during last years fiscal negotiations, when he urged fellow Republicans to accept higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans. He continues to advocate a compromise budget deal to avoid a government shutdown or a debt crisis, and he maintains a good relationship with the White House.

title: Three-Wheeled Motorcycles, Honda S.U.V.s and Minivans Are Recalled
description: About 5,000 Can-Am Spyder RT and ST motorcycles from the 2013 model year are being recalled for a fire hazard, and Honda is recalling 270 Pilot sport utility vehicles and Odyssey minivans from the 2013 model year for an engine problem, according to reports posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Web site.

title: The Old Are Working, but Not the Young
description: This summer has seen a larger share of a certain group of people working than at any time in the last three decades, according to government figures.

title: No Immediate Risk Is Found From Arsenic Levels in Rice
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration announced Friday that it had found no evidence that current levels of arsenic in rice pose an immediate health risk.

title: Kering Takes Minority Stake in Altuzarra Fashion Label
description: Kering, the luxury conglomerate formerly named PPR and home to brands including Alexander McQueen and Balenciaga, announced on Friday that it had taken a minority stake in Altuzarra, the label started in 2008 by the French-American designer Joseph Altuzarra.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Peter Som: Spring 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Referee Has the U.S. Teams Attention
description: As if Friday nights World Cup qualifier in San Jos between host Costa Rica and the United States did not have sufficient story lines:

title: Yeah? Well, Sos Your Old Man!
description: Its a mans world. Again.

title: New Parent, Old Parent: What to Do When Your Child Wont Go to School
description: We introduce a new feature: New Parent, Old Parent. As Michael Winerip writes on Booming, were hoping to connect the readers of two Times staples, the Motherlode blog and Booming, with the goal of providing the very best kind of parenting ideas and advice: the kind that has been tried and tested by those who have been through the mill wheel and come out the other side.

title: Attacking Mitch McConnell From the Right
description: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell has done his best to stay neutral in the intra-Republican war over whether to shut down the government in order to stop the implementation of the Affordable Care Act. Although he acknowledged in August that the plan wouldnt actually work, he told The Washington Posts Greg Sargent that he did not mean to take sides in the dispute.

title: Saluting the Old Guards of Prime Time
description: September is not a prime time for old television shows. They quietly slip back onto the schedule, just happy to be there, while attention is lavished on the broadcast networks latest pretty young things.

title: Obama Describes His Talk With Putin
description: President Obama said he had a candid and constructive conversation Friday with President Vladimir V. Putin. Syria dominated their discussion.

title: Jenni Kayne: Spring 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Waiting to Woo Vodafone, and Paying the Price
description: Verizons agreement to acquire Vodafones stake in Verizon Wireless is a megadeal by any measure: at $130 billion it ranks as the third-largest ever, and the largest since the collapse of the dot-com bubble in 2000.

title: Yes, I Can, and, Whats More, as the Star
description: How can you hit a man in my condition? Michael J. Fox complains when his television daughter gives him a playful smack on the arm in the premiere of The Michael J. Fox Show.

title: A Witness to Gentrification in Cobble Hill
description: In the morning, when Peggy White makes her way down Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, to the no-frills coffee shop where she likes to linger with friends, it can take her an hour to walk five blocks.

title: Hyperactivity Linked to Inner Ear Defect
description: When hyperactivity is found in children with severe hearing loss, it is often assumed to stem from frustrations they have communicating or socializing. But a new study says a genetic defect in the inner ear may also play a role in causing hyperactive behavior, suggesting that at least in some cases, hyperactivity can have a neurobiological root.

title: For Marvel, a Tricky Gene Transfer
description: LOS ANGELES  How do you take a story born in comic books that most people know from the movies and successfully adapt it for television?

title: Big Ticket | Opulent Duplex for $22 Million
description: A 12-room duplex at 950 Fifth Avenue, a vertical bastion of billionaires with just seven residences and an infinitely selective co-op board, sold for $22 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: An Interview With Jason Wu
description: Malina Gilchrist, senior market editor at T Magazine, interviews the fashion designer Jason Wu on his new makeup collaboration with Lancome and looking beyond fashion for inspiration.

title: Vanderbilt Footballs New Era
description: With rape charges against four former players as a backdrop, Vanderbilt played its football opener on Aug. 29 to a capacity crowd.

title: Poised to Enter a Convent, Then She Fell in Love
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: A New Low at Rising Vanderbilt
description: NASHVILLE  Traffic snaked around Vanderbilt Stadium three hours before kickoff. Fans dressed, as instructed, in all black. Wynonna Judd belted out the national anthem, and red fireworks exploded overhead. The assembled discussed bowl games and winning seasons and Southeastern Conference upsets, and they were serious.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in London; Los Angeles; Berlin
description: Frieze Art Fair, LondonFrom Oct. 17 to 20, LondonsFrieze Art Fairwill once again set up shop in Regents Park, with 175 international galleries, including heavyweights like Gagosian and Victoria Miro, in a hangarlike tent designed by Carmody Groarke. In addition to the over 1,000 artists showcasing their works, a number of talks will be held with artists, including Meredith Monk on Oct. 17, the photographer Stephen Shore on Oct. 19, and the choreographer Jrme Bel on Oct. 20. Tickets start at 34.40 (about $52).

title: T Time | Jason Wu on Beauty, RuPauls Drag Race and the Unfashionable Allure of Las Vegas
description: This afternoon, Jason Wu will unveil his spring/summer 2014 ready-to-wear collection, which he said last week will have a new sense of ease that could be surprising for some. To mark the occasion, Ts senior market editor, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, sat down with the designer in the first installment of a new series called T Time. Watch as Wu discusses his approach to beauty, his new collaboration with Lancme, his passion for RuPaul and why he so values a Vegas getaway. Look for future episodes of T Time in the weeks ahead.

title: For Young Designers, the Time Is Now
description: There has probably been no better time in recent history to be a young designer in New York than today, when the fashion audience is hungry for newness, the editors need constant content, and the businesspeople sense an opportunity to capitalize on the talent. Just this morning, Kering, the company that owns top labels like Gucci, Stella McCartney and Balenciaga, announced it had invested in Altuzarra, the label started by the designer Joseph Altuzarra in 2008. (It is a minority stake.)

title: G-20 Leaders Agree to Continue Stimulus Plans
description: MOSCOW  The leaders of the worlds 20 largest economies issued a joint statement on Friday saying it was too early to ease off government stimulus spending, in spite of recent positive economic news.

title: Knopf Acquires New Paolo Bacigalupi Novel
description: Knopf has acquired a new novel by Paolo Bacigalupi, the science fiction writer whose 2009 book The Windup Girl sold 200,000 copies and was considered one of the top novels of the year.

title: The Vulnerable Mr. Bond
description: Its funny how our emblems of cool can be so unsure underneath.

title: In Toronto, the Oscar Smackdown Gets an Early Start
description: TORONTO  Through much of August, Harvey Weinstein seemed to be slugging his way through a one-film Oscar fight. While most of the movie world was waiting out the end of the summer blockbuster season, Mr. Weinstein was waging an early campaign for his film Lee Daniels the Butler.

title: Fall TV Preview: Old Hits Return, New Worlds Open
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Shows to Watch For
description: A selection of notable fall television programming.

title: Corruption in the Confederacy
description: Between 1862 and 1865, officers of the Confederate District Court of North Carolina, empowered by a new national law, confiscated and sold millions of dollars worth of property from North Carolinians accused of being alien enemies. The proceeds of confiscated and sold property were to be sent immediately to Richmond, but most was never reported. Many officers of the District Court, like David Schenck of Lincoln County, became wealthy enforcing the Act of Sequestration while thousands of their fellow Tar Heels were deprived of their property, charged with disloyalty, and in some cases even executed as enemies of the Confederacy.

title: 3 Quiet Museums in Rome
description: One of the joys of Rome is its ability to make you feel as if there is a place that has spent centuries accumulating layers of beauty and history, patiently waiting just for you to arrive.

title: Marseille Polishes Its Image
description: Until the European Union named Marseille a European Capital of Culture for 2013, it may have been one of the most underappreciated cities on the Continent. Situated on a splendid Mediterranean harbor, surrounded by hills and blessed with an average 300 days of sunshine, a variety of museums, great restaurants and a vital, multicultural population, it has just about everything a visitor could ask for. Yet because of its rough-edged reputation, people usually preferred to spend their sojourns in the South of France in the quieter, smaller cities of Aix-en-Provence, Avignon, Arles and Nmes.

title: A Mortgage Market Out of Balance
description: The vast system that provides home loans to millions of Americans has long been a strange place. A surprising development has made it even stranger.

title: New Consoles Special Game: Waiting
description: Video game players are always excited to get their hands on new consoles, and in November, two new game machines are scheduled to be introduced: Microsofts Xbox One and Sonys PlayStation 4. But while new consoles usually lead to better games, often that happens only in the long run. Some of the final games made for aging consoles have been better than the first games that were released for brand-new systems. Neither the PlayStation 3 in 2006 nor the Xbox 360 a year earlier went on sale with a single memorable initial title.

title: High Holy Days, and Cantors Are on the Road Again
description: On the eve of Rosh Hashana last year, as Lois Kittner was passing through security at the airport in Newark, a security screener halted her. He had a question about several strange items in her carry-on bag. One looked like some kind of animal bone; the other was a piece of metal that came to a suspiciously narrow point.

title: Defying Expectations, TV Actors Try Different Roles
description: Sooner or later, everything old is new again, especially on television. In a season when the Hollywood gene pool teems with fresh specimens, some familiar faces are shaking things up, defying stereotypes  and showing those newbies how its done. Mid-glorious-career, four veteran actors are revealing different sides of themselves. Maybe we dont know them as well as we thought we did.

title: Tennis in Spain Anyone? Anyone?
description: I love tennis and travel: balancing those two addictions during the years four tennis majors is never easy.

title: Hyphens, Hybrids and Getting a Hand
description: The aisle has been walked, the cake eaten and the bouquet tossed. Now, what name or names will the happily married couple use? These days, the options have become more varied.

title: The Power of Stepping Back
description: I am the chief executive of my company, with responsibility for 30 people in the United States and another two offices overseas. As part of my vacation last month, I took two weeks when I was completely offline and didnt check in to my office at all.

title: Book Review Podcast: Introducing Bookends
description: This week, The New York Times Book Review unveils its first redesign in six years. title: Museum of Moving Parts
description: This fall, two French choreographers of note continue to push the boundaries of contemporary dance. In Disabled Theater, Jrme Bel collaborates with Theater Hora, a Zurich company  many in the group have Down syndrome  to explore the concept of normality. Its a risky, haunting work. For Mr. Bel, who has created acclaimed theatrical portraits of dancers like Vronique Doisneau and Cdric Andrieux, Disabled Theater extends on his study of people and their bodies. The production is a co-presentation of Performa 13, the latest installment of the performance biennial, and New York Live Arts, where it will be shown starting on Nov. 12. In his daring piece, Mr. Bel questions notions of handicaps and abnormality with his seemingly innocent gaze and understated showmanship. In doing so he reveals the disturbing, uncomfortable point at which fragility and strength meet.

title: The Ad Campaign: Spitzer Attacks Stringer on Term Limits
description: With polls suggesting that the Democratic primary for New York City comptroller is a dead heat, Eliot Spitzer has started airing the first negative television ad of the campaign. Titled Our Voice, it accuses his rival, Scott M. Stringer, of having cut a back-room deal to lift term limits and allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to run for a third term. The Spitzer campaign also started airing a Spanish-language version of the ad and a similar one on the radio.PRODUCER Siegel StrategiesTHE SCRIPT Voice-over: Term limits were voted in by the people, until 20-year career politician Scott Stringer worked to destroy them, cutting a back-room deal to hand a third term to the mayor against the peoples will, even testifying before the City Council to get it done. Eliot Spitzer has always fought against the same special interests and back-room politicians supporting Stringer. Because Stringer didnt only take away our term limits. He took away our voice. But this Sept. 10, we get to use it.ON SCREEN The music, brassy and solemnly patriotic, sounds ripped from the score of a Western. There are images of Mr. Stringer, including one with Mr. Bloomberg, and a graphic of a piece of paper with Term Limits written on it being gradually torn to shreds. A phrase from a Christian Science Monitor article about the term-limits debate (counter to the will of the voters) flashes across the screen. As the music shifts to a more hopeful mode, the ad closes with images of Mr. Spitzer shaking hands with voters and patting them on the back, and a close-up on a Hispanic woman and a black man standing next to Mr. Spitzer.ACCURACY Mr. Stringer did testify before the Council in 2008, urging members to vote to extend term limits to 12 years, from 8 years. There is no evidence, however, that he was part of any back-room deal to hand Mr. Bloomberg a third term. He endorsed Mr. Bloombergs 2009 opponent, William C. Thompson Jr.As to whether Mr. Spitzer fought against the same special interests and back-room politicians that support Mr. Stringer, the claim is so broad that it is hard to quantify its measure of truth. If special interests refers to the unions that have endorsed Mr. Stringer, Mr. Spitzer was himself endorsed in previous campaigns by some of the same groups. However, as governor he also prominently clashed with one of the unions backing Mr. Stringer, 1199 S.E.I.U., over cuts that he proposed to health care. Mr. Stringer, like most major New York City candidates who are not self-financing, has accepted donations from people working on Wall Street. As attorney general, Mr. Spitzer led investigations into financial industry practices and made many enemies on Wall Street. The former governor is financing his campaign with money from his familys real estate fortune.SCORECARD Although Mr. Stringer did support lifting term limits to allow Mr. Bloomberg to run for a third term, his role in the debate was minor. To accuse him of being part of a back-room deal is misleading. And although Mr. Stringer has been heavily supported by labor, a political action committee that threatened to raise major Wall Street money to back him has fizzled. The ad speaks to the caustic tone the campaign has taken in its final days; soon after this ad began airing on Thursday, the Stringer campaign went up with its own negative ad.

title: The Ad Campaign: Stringer Says Spitzer Held Himself to a Different Standard
description: Hours after Eliot Spitzer started broadcasting the first negative television commercial in the Democratic primary for comptroller, his opponent, Scott M. Stringer, responded with his own negative spot. Titled Clear Choice, it invokes the prostitution scandal that led Mr. Spitzer to resign as governor in 2008.PRODUCER GMMBTHE SCRIPT Announcer: The Times, Post and Daily News all endorse Scott Stringer. Hell audit every city agency to cut waste so we can invest in jobs and schools. And he far outdistances Eliot Spitzer in integrity. Spitzer jailed people for prostitution and financial crimes, but when he got caught doing the very same thing, he held himself to a different standard, and walked away scot-free. Thats why The Times, Post and Daily News all say the choice is clear: Scott Stringer, comptroller.ON SCREEN The announcer speaks over what sounds like the upbeat theme music for an evening newscast, while the screen shows images of Mr. Stringer at his desk and talking to a man in a pharmacists coat, a flyover picture of City Hall and an image of a school hallway. When the narrator mentions Mr. Spitzers putting people in jail, a person is shown from the back in handcuffs. This is followed by black-and-white images of Mr. Spitzer, with the words Same Crimes and Different Standard and a CNN headline  Spitzer Wont Be Charged in Prostitution Scandal  flashing on the screen. The ad ends with an image of the New York skyline and a photograph of Mr. Stringer on the Brooklyn Bridge.ACCURACY As far as prostitution goes, the ad is accurate. As governor, Mr. Spitzer was caught patronizing prostitutes, precipitating his resignation. The assertion that he committed financial crimes, however, is misleading. In announcing that they would not charge Mr. Spitzer, federal prosecutors said there was insufficient evident to bring charges against Mr. Spitzer for any offense relating to the withdrawal of funds for, and his payments to to the prostitution ring. The Times, The Daily News and The New York Post have all endorsed Mr. Stringer.SCORECARD If Mr. Stringer stuck to reminding voters that Mr. Spitzer patronized prostitutes  something that few have likely forgotten  he would be on solid ground. Bringing in financial crimes stretches the truth and the available evidence.

title: Fearlessly Mining the 1990s for a Soul Sound to Call Their Own
description: Body Music, the debut album by the British club-soul outfit AlunaGeorge, is one of the chilliest albums of 2013 so far and also one of the most piercing. Over the last couple of years, this duo  Aluna Francis, who sings, and George Reid, who produces  has found the electrifying overlap between the British 2-step garage of the late 1990s and the fleet, attitudinal American R&B of the mid-1990s, with a sprinkle of New Jack Swing on top. Its made for some elegant, sassy and deconstructed modern soul music, both energetic and also strategically broken, as if they were rewiring the parts in real time.

And in 1973  a year in which Ms. was added to the United States governments list of acceptable prefixes, and the Supreme Court legalized abortion  she faced Bobby Riggs in the Battle of the Sexes.

title: Picture This, Embellished
description: The Pictures Generation artists of the 1970s and 80s plowed into the avalanche of mass-media imagery, making work that stood outside the seemingly omnipotent visual landscape of the late 20th century. Elad Lassry, a sought-after Los Angeles photographer who is sometimes described as a post-Pictures Generation artist, makes brightly colored, high-gloss images that can appear to leave little distance between the commercial and the analytical. But Mr. Lassry has said he thinks about such imagery as free radicals, pictures that toy with their conventions and ask questions about the nature of seeing  and, in doing so, become objects in their own right.

title: Offbeat Artists in Brooklyn

BeginningThursday, the festival, named for Brooklyn Emerging Artists in Theater, celebrates its second year with a lineup of choreographers and directors who have created site-specific works for nontraditional locations in four neighborhoods. On the dance end, the choreographer Yanira Castro offers the premiere of Nancy, an installation focusing on the performer Nancy Ellis that explores ideas revolving around the representation of a performer. LeeSaar the Company pairs a Gaga/people class  the movement language invented by Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin  with an open rehearsal at Congregation Beth Elohim, where the troupe is based.
