title: The First Rule ... Well, You Know
description: Its hard to believe that David Finchers fable Fight Club (1999), at IFC Center on Friday and Saturday at midnight, could ever have been financed. Yes, as its name suggests, it has plenty of action. (And if youre disgusted by the sight of shirtless men pummeling one another to a pulp, this film is not for you.) But what sets it apart is its merciless attack on consumer culture in sequences brutal, comic and brutally comic. Rarely has a film employed product placement to such deleterious effect for the corporations involved. Fight Club, based on the Chuck Palahniuk novel, is as rich in brains as it is in testosterone.

title: Georgia Tackle Overcomes a Stubborn Foe: Steroids

A University of Georgia offensive lineman, Houston also took a pill normally prescribed for tuberculosis and had 60 ultrasound treatments to dislodge the banned substance, known as 19-norandrosterone. He tried hours of deep tissue massage, but each time his urine was tested, more than 100 times in three and a half years, the results always came back positive.

title: Somalia: Government Says Report Rebuts Fiscal Mismanagement Charges
description: Somalia said Friday that a foreign investigative team hired by the government had rebutted allegations of financial mismanagement by United Nations monitors. The United Nations Monitoring Group on Somalia and Eritrea issued a report in July in which it charged that Somalias central bank functioned effectively as a slush fund. The government report, released Friday but dated Aug. 30, said that the allegations and purported findings have no basis in fact. Charges of endemic corruption have made it difficult for Somalias year-old government to receive money directly from donors and to reclaim overseas assets. Jarat Chopra, the United Nations groups coordinator, questioned whether the law firm and the consultancy retained by the government had financial conflicts of interest. The Monitoring Group is standing by its findings, which are based on the evidence it obtained during its investigations, said Mr. Chopra.

title: China: Official Denies Taking Bribes
description: Lei Zhengfu, a former Communist Party official in the city of Chongqing, insisted during an appeals hearing on Friday that he had not taken bribes, the state news media reported. Mr. Lei was convicted in June of having accepted nearly $520,000 in bribes to help a businessman, Xiao Ye, and he was sentenced to 13 years in prison. In addition facing the bribery charges, Mr. Lei was a victim of a blackmail ring run by Mr. Xiao, in which young women had sex with officials and secretly filmed the act. A video of Mr. Lei having sex with an 18-year-old had been in the possession of the Chongqing police, who had investigated the blackmail ring but had not moved to prosecute anyone because city officials kept the case quiet, the state news media reported. Bo Xilai, the party chief of Chongqing at the time, was himself subsequently charged with corruption.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) ARGO  (2012) Ben Affleck, above, directed and stars in this Oscar winner for best film. It covers a little-known chapter of the Iranian hostage crisis in which Antonio J. Mendez, a Central Intelligence Agency officer and wizard of disguise, was tapped to help free six State Department employees stranded in Tehran after revolutionary forces seized the United States Embassy on Nov. 4, 1979. His plan: to have them pose as a Canadian movie crew filming a science-fiction flick called Argo. John Goodman and Alan Arkin play the Hollywood makeup artist and producer who assist him in his mission. Bryan Cranston, his neck tendons popping, is one of his bosses; and Clea DuVall, Tate Donovan, Scoot McNairy, Rory Cochrane, Christopher Denham and Kerry Bish are the escapees. After setting your pulse racing, Mr. Affleck smoothly downshifts, easing from the high anxiety of the opener  which evokes 1970s political thrillers like Sydney Pollacks Three Days of the Condor  into something looser, mellower and funny, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Affleck handles his own roles, on camera and behind it, with a noticeable lack of self-aggrandizement, she added. In the end, this is a story about outwitting rather than killing the enemy, making it a homage to actual intelligence and an example of the same.

A child perishes with her mother in a tornado in Oklahoma, the month after an 8-year-old is slain by a bomb in Boston. Runaway trains claim dozens of lives in otherwise placid Canada and Spain. At least 46 people are killed in a string of coordinated bombings aimed at an ice cream shop, bus station and famous restaurant in Baghdad. But the data is fallible, too. A study that used internet search data to predict future home sales was more accurate than forecasts by experts from the National Association of Realtors, but a similar approach using searches related the flu was not. title: Backstage Beauty Report | Stripped-Down Makeup at Alexander Wang
description: Rarely does a no-makeup look truly mean just that. But at the Alexander Wang show this evening, there wasnt a speck of foundation, eye shadow or lipstick anywhere in sight. I call it raw beauty, the makeup artist Diane Kendal said of the barely-there, extreme-minimalist look she created backstage. Proving the point, her routine took all of five minutes: she patted Nars Skin Aqua Gel Luminous Oil-Free Moisturizer on the skin to give it a nice luminous quality and dotted stick concealer down the sides of the nose and over any blemishes or redness. Lashes were curled; arches were set with a quick pass of brow gel. And thats it. Its actually hard to tell which models have their makeup done and which dont, one observer noted, puzzled. Kendal couldnt be happier about that. Alexander loved that the girls looked so cool [when they came in for casting], she said. So we agreed that the more you do with makeup, the less cool it looks. The models seemed to embrace the no-fuss effect. Its very au naturel, Joan Smalls said, adding that this is the fastest makeup Ive had done for a show. Jourdan Dunn called the pared-down approach laid-back and easy, while Hanne Gaby Odiele said, Its simple but fresh; its like how we walked in  but a little less tired.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13) LAST TANGO IN HALIFAX Derek Jacobi, above, and Anne Reid portray Alan and Celia, childhood sweethearts, now both widowed and in their 70s, who fall in love all over again  and begin to lament what if?  after being reunited on the Internet nearly 60 years later. Sarah Lancashire and Nicola Walker play the daughters who would be the last people to stand in the way of their parents happiness, but who cant help themselves. Theres nothing to be gained from saying unkind things about Last Tango in Halifax, a warm comforter of a series, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Its based on actual, inspiring events in the life of the writers mother. And it has been expertly assembled and fine-tuned for maximum heartwarming effect, so those who like this sort of thing will like it very, very much. But while the show begins with a potentially interesting situation, he said, it proceeds to do little with it. He added: A good test of how youll respond to this Last Tango could be how you responded to the film from which it (hilariously) borrows its title. If the portrait of despair in Last Tango in Paris left you shattered but exhilarated, then Last Tango in Halifax may not be your cup of tea. In the season finale of Silk, at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, Martha (Maxine Peake) and Clive (Rupert Penry-Jones) have their Queens Counsel interviews as she takes on the biggest case in her career  defending a repeat offender charged with murder  while struggling to focus as the stress resulting from her personal life increases.

The Bedlam theater company will bring its productions of Shakespeares Hamlet and George Bernard Shaws Saint Joan to the Lynn Redgrave Theater in the East Village, according to the producers. Both works are to be directed by Eric Tucker, and all the roles will be played by the same four actors (Ted Lewis, Andrus Nichols, Tom OKeefe and Mr. Tucker), similar to the companys run of Hamlet this year at Access Theater. title: Things Fall Apart

He has found new  not always welcome  allies (Nagel has paved the way for a religious world-view!), and some long-time admirers have denounced his claims and arguments (Nagel has paved the way for religious mumbo-jumbo!). One morning, as I sat at my desk in a high-rise downtown, a man dropped down inches from my window, cleaned it, and disappeared to the next floor. This momentary interaction seemed a perfect metaphor for life in many multiethnic American cities where the work of immigrants often goes unnoticed. I hoped to find out more about what motivated these men to spend their working days dangling hundreds of feet in the air.

The health care law, he declared, has proven to be unpopular, unworkable and unaffordable, and he predicted sticker shock in the months ahead.

So, as another far-off war worsens, Americans are loath to take sides, even against a merciless dictator, even to the extent of sending weapons. The voices opposed to getting involved range from the pacifist left to the populist right. The president, fearful that foreign conflict will undermine his domestic agenda, vacillates.

Jazz is the only music in the world where four people sit up on a bandstand, and they have to give shape and logic and form to music as theyre making it, he says as he prepares the saxophonist Patrick Bartley, the pianist Tony Madruga and the bass player Russell Hall for a performance. title: Two More Writers for Shakespeare Effort
description: Margaret Atwood and Howard Jacobson are the latest authors to be commissioned by Penguin Random Houses Hogarth imprint to write their interpretations of plays by Shakespeare, the publisher is to announce on Monday. Ms. Atwood will tackle The Tempest, while Mr. Jacobson has chosen The Merchant of Venice. They join Anne Tyler, who will provide her own take on The Taming of the Shrew, and Jeanette Winterson, who will reimagine The Winters Tale. The plays are scheduled to be published in print, digital and audio formats in 2016 to coincide with the 400th anniversary of Shakespeares death as part of the Hogarth Shakespeare project. In a news release, Ms. Atwood said that she had selected The Tempest because it has always been a favorite of mine, and working on it will be an invigorating challenge. Is Caliban the first talking monster? Not quite, but close. Mr. Jacobson also gave his reasons for selecting The Merchant of Venice: For an English novelist, Shakespeare is where it all begins. For an English novelist who also happens to be Jewish, The Merchant of Venice is where it all snarls up. He added: Who is the merchant and who is the Jew? Portia wanted to know. Four hundred years later, the question needs to be reframed: Who is the hero of this play, and who is the villain? Hogarth plans to announce more writers for the project in the future.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Advertising spending in the United States rose 3.5 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period a year ago, according to a report released Monday by the Kantar Media unit of WPP. For the first half, Kantar Media said, American ad spending rose 2 percent from the first half of 2012. The second quarters increase represented the sixth quarterly gain in a row, Kantar Media reported; results for the first quarter, which initially showed a decline of 0.1 percent, were subsequently revised to show a gain of 0.3 percent. Media with growth in ad revenue in the second quarter, according to the report, included outdoor, up 7.4 percent; television, up 6.4 percent; and magazines, up 1.6 percent. title: Backstage Beauty Report | Seashell-Like Updos at Carolina Herrera

Herrera, though, is just the kind of designer who appreciates classic, clean lines, which Pita played up in the sleek, tightly coiled updos seen on her runway. The shape was inspired by a long seashell with a swirl at the top, he said. To achieve the effect, he brushed strands straight and generously misted on By Byron Spirulina Hair Spray for grip. Hair was then parted off to the side and divided into two sections at the back, each of which was rolled in toward the scalp, leaving a loop at the top, and pinned in place. I need it tighter here, Pita said, cupping the base of a models updo and ordering a redo. (Fact: even the pros dont nail things on the first attempt.) The finished result was entirely right for the Herrera woman. This isnt a jeans-and-a-jacket kind of look  its cocktails and an event, Pita noted, as the delicate clouds of hair spray settled around him.

Abkhazia, a sliver of land along the Black Sea, broke from Georgia in 1992 and is heavily reliant on Russian economic support. title: Russia: Inquiry Focuses on Antics of U.S. Rock Band With Russian Flag

During that performance, which took place in neighboring Ukraine, the bassist, Jared Hasselhoff, passed a wadded-up Russian flag through the crotch of his pants. Russian investigators convened a panel of psychological and linguistic analysts to examine the video, and it concluded that the act had been intended to offend. After the contention over its appearance in Ukraine, the band canceled a show in Russia and left the country. The authorities have been sensitive to the political overtones of Western rock performances since Madonna spoke out in support of gay rights and for jailed members of the punk group Pussy Riot at concerts in Russia.

title: Japan: No Indictments Over Fukushima Accident

Naoto Kan, who was prime minister at the time of the accident, will also not be prosecuted over his inability to prevent the multiple meltdowns and explosions that hit the plants reactors, driving 100,000 people from their homes, according to the broadcaster, NHK. Prosecutors said that their decision was based on data provided on a voluntary basis, and on the opinions of experts, who suggested that the scale of the earthquake and tsunami that triggered the accident could not have been predicted. That finding, however, has been contradicted in various studies, including an influential parliamentary report that called the accident a manmade disaster. A group of Fukushima residents who had sought indictments told NHK that prosecutors had failed to respond to the voice of local residents."

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (13) BILLIE JEAN KING She played tennis like a man: muscular, aggressive, fast on her feet. But Billie Jean King, above, was all about girl power, crusading for gender equality on the court and off. And in 1973  a year in which Ms. was added to the United States governments list of acceptable courtesy titles, and the Supreme Court legalized abortion  she faced Bobby Riggs in the so-called Battle of the Sexes and won. When he jumped over the net, his first thing he said to me was, I underestimated you, she recalled. He was perhaps the only one. Ms. King won 39 Grand Slam titles and a record 20 at Wimbledon; founded the Womens Tennis Association in 1973; became the countrys first openly lesbian major sports figure in 1981; and received a Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Obama in 2009 for championing the rights of women and gay people. title: An Offer We Cant Refuse
description: Jeffrey Goldberg has fifteen questions about the proposal, floated as a near-impossible hypothetical by John Kerry and embraced with alacrity by the Russians, to have Bashar al-Assad turn over his chemical weapons stockpile as an alternative to U.S. strikes. Theyre good questions! But they arent questions that will prevent this strange peace plan from going forward, because at this point the Obama White House doesnt really have any option except to play the card that Vladimir Putin just dealt. A congressional resolution authorizing strikes was on life support even without the Russian option; with the Russian option on the table, the resolution is as dead as a doornail buried six feet under in the local cemetery, and the potential humiliation the administration was facing a few days ago would become a certainty if they decided to turn to the offer down outright. Which means there is no alternative: As Dan Drezner says, you take the deal, you take it now, and you worry about Goldbergs questions further down the line.

For a large  and very old  organization, Ive found this company to be rather innovative and willing to take risks to stay on the cutting edge of technology. Internally, however, there are certain areas where we havent pushed the envelope, and when it comes to the development environment we use to build our website, we have been behind for a while. When I started at The Times, our dev environment was a combination of mounted file systems from remote servers mixed with a poorly organized Subversion repository that was extremely difficult to work with. All of those systems were put in place for good reasons, but over time the reasons became less relevant and the solutions more outdated.

title: Why Roger Federer Is the Greatest of All Time
description: Roger Federer, who I wrote about in the magazines U.S. Open issue, was the big story coming into the Open; the state of his game dominated the conversation for most of the tournament. But the big story coming out of the Open is his longtime nemesis, Rafael Nadal, who won the mens title last night with an enthralling four-set victory over the world No. 1, Novak Djokovic. The win gives the 27-year-old Spaniard his 13th grand-slam singles title at exactly the same age that Federer won his 13th, which leaves the whole GOAT debate even more unsettled. GOAT? Thats short for greatest of all time and is an acronym that has been tossed around promiscuously during the Federer years. With a record 17 majors highlighting his numerous career achievements, Federer has staked a strong claim to GOAT status. But he has a losing record against Nadal, and a lopsided one at that. The two have played 31 times since 2004, and Nadal has won 21 of those matches. Federers record against Nadal is a large blot on an otherwise remarkable rsum. How can you be considered the greatest player ever if you were arguably not even the best player of your own era? When I spoke with Federer at Wimbledon, he didnt object when I noted that some feel that Nadal ought to be regarded as the finest male player of all time. I believe well never quite know, Federer told me.

We worked together to come up with the idea, Gilbert said of the eye-catching embellishments that were custom created for the designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy and took two days to hand paint and stamp. My genius assistant and I worked on them in between fittings and shows, the stylist noted. Having done that work in advance allowed Gilbert to streamline her routine backstage: she applied John Frieda Frizz-Ease Curl Reviver Styling Mousse before blow-drying, curling and parting hair far over to one side. The extensions were then glued in a diagonal band across the head, while the rest of the hair was pulled into a small side knot below the ear. The peekaboo effect of the print was particularly striking on the bleach-blonde model Soo Joo Park, who gave it a thumbs up as far as street-style trends go. And this July, they invited me to come along.

title: In Detroit, a Case of Selling Art and Selling Out
description: DETROIT  These days, the message screens above the main ticket desk at the Detroit Institute of Arts regularly flash the phrase Thank You Voters. Unusual as it may seem among announcements about exhibitions and events at this world-class museum, it belongs there. On Aug. 7, 2012, the citizens of the three counties that contain and surround Detroit  Wayne, Oakland and Macomb  voted in favor of a 10-year commitment to a small increase in real estate taxes that would guarantee the institute $23 million a year, roughly two-thirds of its annual operating budget.

title: Election 2013: Rise of the Machines

The lever-action voting machines that were pulled out of storage for Tuesdays voting date back to the 1960s. Like humans of that vintage, they are prone to crankiness and mechanical failure.

title: Taking the Reins, Then Hanging On

Like other New Yorkers who fetishize the Pacific Northwest, Adriana Baer thought that life would get easier when she moved here last year to become artistic director of a small, respected stage company, Profile Theater. Sure, there would be challenges: Ms. Baer was 29, female and an outsider in a city  and an industry  where many donors and professional peers were older men. She was also replacing the theaters founder, often a tricky transition, and taking on a $500,000 annual operating budget that barely covered costs.

title: A Copyright Victory, 35 Years Later
description: In the lucrative world of music copyright, it may be something of a watershed moment: on Friday, after six years of legal wrangling and decades after he wrote the lyrics to the hit song YMCA, Victor Willis will gain control of his share of the copyright to that song and others he wrote when he was the lead singer of the 1970s disco group the Village People.

Based on nomenclature alone, this should be a film about heroism and perseverance, a detailing of the muscles that work stealthily so that the body might move unfettered.

title: On 9/11, My Two Cents on Syria

When we co-chaired the 9/11 Commission, which was set up in 2002 and issued its report on the attacks in 2004, we investigated the failures that left our country vulnerable and recommended 41 actions to correct them and strengthen our national security.

title: Loud Voice Fighting Tide of New Trend in Education
description: Diane Ravitch made her name in the 1970s as a historian chronicling the role of public schools in American social mobility. In the 1990s, she went to work in the Bush administrations Education Department, where she pushed for a rejection of 1960s relativism and a return to basics and standards. After leaving government, she called for the removal of incompetent teachers, for tying school performance to student scores, and for closing failing schools.

title: Threaten to Threaten
description: If youre an average American and are confused and worried about us getting embroiled in a no-win Syrian civil war, youre right to be concerned. It means youre paying attention. But if youre a member of Congress or a senator whos still wondering whether to grant President Obama the authority to use force to deter Syrian President Bashar al-Assad from again murdering hundreds of his people with poison gas, it now makes sense to take a timeout. That also means youre paying attention.

The United Nations General Assembly will meet later this month to assess progress  impressive in some areas, halting in others  toward achieving the United Nations Millennium Development Goals, which were adopted in 2000 and are supposed to be reached by the end of 2015.

title: Pakistans Peaceful Transition
description: During most of his five years as Pakistans president, Asif Ali Zardari was so embattled that there were constant rumors that he would be killed, jailed or ousted in a military coup. On Sunday, he left office after a formal lunch hosted by his political rivals. This was the first time that an elected Pakistani president had completed his term; most others were overthrown or forced to resign. It was a remarkable development in a fragile nation not known for peaceful transitions. On Monday, Mamnoon Hussain, an obscure 73-year-old political figure, was sworn in as his successor.

The would-be assassin, Ilya Pyanzin, was arrested last year in Ukraine. The authorities said he had planned to set a bomb on Mr. Putins motorcade route. Mr. Pyanzin pleaded guilty in exchange for a reduced sentence, Russian news agencies reported. The case was covered extensively during the presidential campaign by state-controlled media.

The four suspects, ages 23 to 34, were arrested last week after a robbery at a fast food restaurant in Coignires, a suburb of Paris. The police said the men carried out the robbery to finance a trip by one of the men to Syria. The four were charged with complicity in a terrorist undertaking.

Big bright monitors drive me nuts; screens in the bedroom are gross. He takes his rule seriously, for in Karps newly renovated loft, in south Williamsburg, Brooklyn, screens are scarce, as is, for that matter, anything particularly shiny or smooth. It is, instead, a dedication to all that is aged, rough or both: ancient bricks, weathered concrete, blackened steel and reclaimed oak. While Karp designs the future, his personal aesthetic is worlds apart from the Star Trek flight deck or the Google campus that form our usual idea of what is to come. Karp doesnt believe, he says, that the next century is necessarily about more screens covering more surface area.

In sharp, spare sentences, she told me she has traveled twice to Siberia. She told me how her son has been in and out of a juvenile detention center. At 16, he is now in state custody and wants nothing to do with her. This woman was devastated and could hardly make sense of what has happened. She said after investing everything she has in this boy, both financially and emotionally, she has been left with nothing and no one.

title: For Male Models, Handsome Is as Handsome Does
description: If youre a top model, becoming a fashion designer may seem like a logical next step  unless youre a man. While male models have had success in other fields (Mario Sorrenti is a top fashion photographer, and Magnus Berger is a creative director at WSJ Magazine), few have made the jump from runway to design studio. But a new generation of male models is parlaying fashion connections and using social media to get noticed, not just for their good looks but also for their original designs. These guys have access to all the ingredients of the industry just by being in front of the camera, said Dan May, the style director at Mr. Porter, the online luxury site. If theyre shrewd enough, they can easily pick up on how to build a business and evolve it firsthand, from understanding product development, branding, marketing and P.R. Here are four models who are breaking the mold.

title: The Champagne of Venetian Glass
description: In 1925, Napoleone Martinuzzi became creative director of the Venetian glass company popularly known as Venini. In 1928, inspired by the strength and opacity of ancient glass, he devised a technique called pulegoso that produced a bubbly glass. It can be seen in Napoleone Martinuzzi: Venini 1925-1931, an exhibition through Dec. 1 at Le Stanze del Vetro on San Giorgio Maggiore in Venice. A show theme is the friendship between Mr. Martinuzzi and the poet Gabriele DAnnunzio, who commissioned intensely colorful, intricate works, like a pumpkin made of layered glass. Martinuzzi brought the tradition of Murano glass into the modern era, said the shows curator, Marino Barovier, and his work is rich in energy and saturated with a surprisingly contemporary taste. Closed Wednesdays. 011-39-041-5229138 or lestanzedelvetro.it.

title: When Cats and Cubes Collide
description: High tech meets fake fur in Rimula, a lounge chair by Guillaume Sonnet that playfully mixes materials. Mr. Sonnet, a 27-year-old Belgian architect introducing his first production piece, combined the geometry of epoxy-coated tubular steel with the fluffy comfort of a synthetic pelt. (He was reaching for the effect of a cat that had jumped up onto a seat, he said.) The chair is a deformed cube  it measures about two square feet  with every angle offering a different perspective. And its continuous line is a literal representation of his pencil sketch, he said. The chair, which is produced by Liparus, a year-old company that promotes young Belgian designers, made its first appearance recently in Paris. It is available for $1,127. Information: 011-32-497-16-46-17 or liparus.be.

title: A Fresh Look for Persian Carpets
description: Geoffrey Orley and Bahram Shabahang met in the bazaars of Isfahan, Iran, in 1972 and started a business together to import antique Persian carpets. Thirty years later, they set out to create new ones, which are produced with techniques the men feared were dying out. All of their rugs are handmade with silk and wool from their own silkworms and sheep. The yarnis handspun, bathed in natural vegetable dyes, rinsed in streams and dried in the sun. Mr. Shabahang, a trained architect from a family that has made rugs for 400 years, creates all the designs. The latest collection, which was woven in Turkey, includes Printemps, shown above at right, inspired by a piece of Art Deco stained glass (4 feet 2 inches by 6 feet 2 inches; $5,500), and Adrift, inspired by a birds-eye view of lilypads in a pond (3 by 5 feet; $3,400). Both rugs are wool. Information: (212) 421-5800 or orleyshabahang.com.

I just hate plastic toys that are played with for five minutes and then end up in a landfill.

title: A Rockefeller Who Prefers A Rustic Life

(Reader, dont be dismayed: there are those accouterments, too.) Ms. Rockefeller, the youngest of David and Peggy Rockefellers six children, and a great-granddaughter of John D., grew up between a town house in Manhattan, a farm in Tarrytown, N.Y., a house in St. Barts and another in Maine, and struggled with shyness and undiagnosed dyslexia. Yet the star of the memoir may be Ms. Rockefellers mother, Peggy, who battled depression and the exigencies of her role as a Rockefeller wife with an antic wit and a passion for rural life, both of which qualities she worked hard to instill in her children. After Peggy bought a 20-acre island in Maine for $300 from a lobsterman (private island alert), she and her three youngest children built a cabin there by themselves, along with an outhouse, stone wall and vegetable garden.

title: May It Please the Audience

I have no empirical proof to support this  surely none that would hold up in court  but its an opinion based on a lifetime of seeing shows, talking to audience members and, for that matter, lawyers, who invariably seem more informed about the current theater season than the average person I meet at a party. So an adaptation of a transcript of a Supreme Court argument might have more commercial potential than youd think. Moreover, Arguendo, a staged re-creation of a 1991 case about the right of strip clubs to feature performers who are totally nude, is being mounted at the Public Theater by the Elevator Repair Service, which has a history of imbuing potentially dry material with off-kilter theatrical joy.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Berry Lips (and No Shortage of Bronzer) at Michael Kors
description: Of course, its Michael Kors  there had to be a little bit of glam! the fashion designer exclaimed, with a laugh, when describing the beauty look at his show this morning. To achieve the necessary oomph, the makeup artist Dick Page slicked on a rich berry lipstick, called Dame, from Korss new 18-piece makeup collection. Its a color thats not an obvious color, and thats what makes it work on so many different complexions, the designer said of the shade worn by his entire cast of models, including Karolina Kurkova, Joan Smalls and Liu Wen. Page applied the hue, blotted it, and then set it by brushing powder onto one layer of tissue that had been pressed to the lips to diffuse the color and pull it out of focus, he explained. The finishing touch? Bronzer. Im bronzer obsessed! Kors admitted, which explains the generously sized compacts of his labels Sporty Bronze Powder used backstage (If I had a horse who needed bronzing, theres enough product in here! quipped Page). It all came together to create a relaxed, just-back-from-holiday look, which the model Karmen Pedaru easily channeled: she was spotted sitting outside, soaking up a bit of sun, moments before opening the show.

It even proved an irresistible target for the hosts on Morning Joe on MSNBC the next day, as they kept asking one another and several of their guests What is wrong with you? before bursting into laughter. title: Getting Past the Outrage on Race
description: George Yancys recent passionate response in The Stone to Trayvon Martins killing  and the equally passionate comments on his response  vividly present the seemingly intractable conflict such cases always evoke. There seems to be a sense in which each side is right, but no way to find common ground on which to move discussion forward. This is because, quite apart from the facts of the case, Trayvon Martin immediately became a symbol for two apparently opposing moral judgments. I will suggest, however, that both these judgments derive from the same underlying injustice  one at the heart of the historic March on Washington 50 years ago and highlighted in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s speech on that occasion.

Night after night  for 29 nights through Oct. 3 and a projected 44 hours  Mr. Daisey is making like a modern-day Scheherazade, telling stories of his life and the life of New York City, ranting and railing at any number of contemporary scourges along the way, in an epic series of performances hes collectively calling All the Faces of the Moon.

title: Israel: To Avoid Trial, State Pays Family of Prisoner X
description: Israel has reached a compensation agreement with the family of Ben Zygier, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed in Israel after apparently getting caught in a web of espionage and who died after hanging himself in his cell in December 2010. The Israeli authorities have concealed the reason for the arrest and secret imprisonment of the man who was known as Prisoner X, citing national security reasons. Israels Ministry of Justice said in a statement late Tuesday that negotiations were held after the family claimed the state had been negligent in its treatment of the case. The state will pay the family just over $1.1 million to avoid a court trial that might have revealed details harmful to state security, according to the statement.

title: Britain: Politician Leaves a Post After Assault Charges

Mr. Evans, 55, a Conservative who represents a constituency in Lancashire, said that he would remain an independent member of Parliament while he seeks to prove his innocence in court, where he is scheduled to appear Sept. 18. The Crown Prosecution Service had said Tuesday that the charges would be based on alleged offenses against men, according to The Associated Press.

title: Canada: Crude Oil in Runaway Train Was Mislabeled
description: The crude oil on a runaway train that derailed, exploded and destroyed much of Lac-Mgantic, Quebec, killing 47 people, was far more volatile than warning signs on its tank cars indicated, investigators said Wednesday. Donald Ross of the Transportation Safety Board of Canada said that the crude had been classified like substances with relatively low flash points, like diesel fuel. But tests on the oil remaining in tank cars that survived the crash found that it belonged in a more explosive category that includes gasoline. Questions had been raised about why the explosion had been so devastating, given the relatively low volatility of most crude oil. Mr. Ross said that accurate labeling would not have required the use of stronger tank cars or altered the actions of firefighters, but investigators are eventually expected to make new safety recommendations based on their findings.

title: Hospital Confronts Childbirth Deaths in Mumbai Slum

When Ms. Nadumani parted the thin curtain that served as a door, Chaya covered her breasts and straightened her matted hair. In the face of high unemployment and low inflation, key institutions  the European Commission, the Bank for International Settlements, the OECD  have consistently called for policies that would depress advanced economies even more.

title: Day 8 at NYFW: Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, Marc Jacobs
description: Three powerhouses show their collections today, wrapping the spring 2014 season of New York Fashion Week.

title: Boehner Seeking Democrats Help on Fiscal Talks
description: WASHINGTON  With Congress momentarily freed from the Syrian crisis, lawmakers plunged back into their bitter fiscal standoff on Thursday as Speaker John A. Boehner appealed to the Obama administration and Democratic leaders to help him resolve divisions in the Republican ranks that could lead to a government shutdown by months end.

title: Good Times at the Top
description: Inequality wonks wait eagerly for the latest update of the Piketty-Saez data, which estimate concentration of income at the top using income tax returns. The latest edition does not disappoint: it shows, as one might expect but needed confirmed, that the very rich have recovered just fine from the Great Recession, even as the great majority of Americans continue to struggle. In fact, the super-elite  the top 0.01 percent  actually had higher incomes in 2012 than they did at the height of the bubble.

title: Photos: A Test of Will, With a View
description: A race that compiles a breakdown of the athletes who abandoned the competition cannot be kind.

title: Warner and J.K. Rowling Reach Wide-Ranging Deal
description: LOS ANGELES  Warner Brothers is doubling down on the J. K. Rowling business. The studio, whose blockbuster Harry Potter films have generated billions of dollars for the company, announced on Thursday that it had concluded a deal with Ms. Rowling that will include new movies, distribution rights to a television mini-series and new theme park attractions.

title: Mayor Defends Record Amid Campaign Attacks
description: For months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been ignored and maligned by many of those seeking to succeed him.

title: Today in Small Business: Burts Buzz
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Poetry Pairing | Trees
description: We ring in the new school year with the return of our Poetry Pairing series.

title: The Story Behind the Putin Op-Ed Article in The Times
description: A Times reader, Lawrence DeVine, has a few questions about The Timess publication of an Op-Ed article in Thursdays paper by Vladimir V. Putin, the president of Russia. He asks: Did he call up the editorial page editor and say, hey, how would you like 800 words on you, us and Syria, Ill have it in by Wednesday night deadline, no sweat, Ill take your usual freelance rates?

title: A Little Slip of a Thing
description: Chuck Chewning lowered his tall, lean frame into a petite slipper chair at David Duncan Antiques on the Upper East Side. Both he and the chair were elegant, but his height and the chairs diminutive size made this an amusing exercise to witness.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 2 Matchup Breakdown
description: After months of preparation, it is understandable that fantasy owners tend to panic after seeing some of their top draft picks struggle to start the season.

title: American Jihadist Is Believed to Have Been Killed by His Former Allies in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A young man from Alabama who traveled to Somalia and became an infamous Islamist militant, commanding guerrilla forces and earning a $5 million American bounty on his head, was believed to have been killed by his former extremist allies on Thursday, according to news reports and Islamist Web sites.

title: Fool for Being Fooled
description: Ive long been fascinated with the concept of misdirection in crossword cluing and the feeling of wonder in general when something beautiful and unexpected happens. I was also curious about why we seem to love being fooled so much, so Im presenting the following as a think piece.

title: Another Set of Beatles BBC Recordings Is on the Way
description: When Capitol Records released The Beatles Live at the BBC to great fanfare in 1994, Beatles collectors lamented that the two-disc set barely scratched the surface of the vast trove of recordings the band made for the BBC between March 1962 and June 1965. Many of those radio recordings were already on a 10-disc bootleg set, after all, and in the 19 years since then, bootleggers have come up with another three discs worth of material.

title: Hilton Is Ready to Go Public, but Other Buyouts Are Still Waiting
description: With Hilton Worldwide Holdings filing on Thursday to go public, it appears that one of the biggest deals of the buyout boom is headed toward a successful completion.

title: Footsteps of Kings (Like Olivier and Gielgud)
description: Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown, Shakespeare wrote some 400 years ago, and although crowns are far less abundant now, uneasy heads are everywhere on the world stage. So the audience for the new series The Hollow Crown should understand exactly what Henry IV of England means when he speaks that famous line. That, at least, is the hope of the BBC and PBS, the co-producers of the four-part series, which was shown in Britain last year and is to be broadcast on Great Performances in the United States, beginning on Friday, Sept. 20.

title: The Gun Report: September 12, 2013
Letting Lips Do What Hands Do
description: Sometimes love arrives like a thunderbolt. Sometimes it arrives with a bonk on the head with a balloon.

title: Classically Innovative
description: LONDON  Does Shakespeare ever get stale for experienced Shakespeareans? In Nicholas Hytners contemporary production of Othello at the National Theater here, two leading British theater actors, Adrian Lester and Rory Kinnear, have drawn acclaim for the fresh clarity and credibility of their performances as Othello and Iago  characters whose ultimately lethal actions can sometimes strain belief.

title: An Off Broadway Rarity: Buyer & Cellar Turns a Quick Profit
description: The critically acclaimed play Buyer & Cellar, an Off Broadway show starring Michael Urie (Ugly Betty) as a struggling actor who goes to work for Barbra Streisand, recouped its $500,000 capitalization in just nine weeks of performances at the Barrow Street Theater, the producers announced Thursday.

title: Youngest Djokovic Is Adjusting to Life as a Pro
description: On Monday afternoon the eyes of the tennis world were fixated on Flushing Meadows, Novak Djokovic played the 37th installment of his rivalry with Rafael Nadal. Several thousand miles away in Banja Luka, a picturesque city in northern Bosnia, another Djokovic watched from his hotel room, living every moment and dreaming that one day he too might experience the adrenaline rush of competing on such a grand stage.

title: Lessons From the Dell Deal
description: The tortuous Dell buyout is essentially over after shareholders approved the companys purchase by its chief executive, Michael S. Dell, and the private equity firm Silver Lake. Now, its time to step back, be introspective and draw some lessons.

title: Wheelies: The Papal Beater Car Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: From Sketch to Stage: A Season of Shakespeare
description: A look at  costume sketches from Shakespeare productions in the new season.

title: At the End of Eden, Rustic Tranquillity
description: The street was empty when I locked the door at the inn and plopped myself down on the curb. It was 4:30 a.m., the air as still as slack water: a great time to be in Panama City. On the quiet, empty sidewalk I took inventory of everything I would need for the next few days: bug spray, sunscreen, snacks, bathing suit, shorts and lots and lots of water.

title: As They Liked It
description: Actors, directors and others in Shakespeare-themed productions this fall recall the Shakespeare moment they still cant shake.

title: Brush Up Your ... Oh, You Know
description: A selective guide to Shakespeare-based productions in New York this season.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 25
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: A Hallucinatory Blaze, via Tibetan Ritual
description: Damien Hirst once encrusted a skull with diamonds, and Takashi Murakami has turned out canvases with cartoon versions of skulls. But when the artist Zhang Huan addresses similar iconography, he creates paintings in a style all their own. Sitting in his Shanghai studio one day recently amid dozens of Tibetan death masks, he was busy preparing for the opening on Friday of Poppy Fields, an exhibition of new works at the Pace Gallery in Chelsea.

title: What if a Teacher Doesnt Like a Parent?
description: The very first question for the Parent-Teacher Conference comes from A. J. Jacobs, editor-at-large at Esquire magazine, author and father of three: a 9-year-old and 7-year-old twins. A. J. plays the role of guinea pig in his writing, whether he is following the Bible as literally as possible in his book My Year of Living Biblically or striving to be the healthiest man in the world in Drop Dead Healthy. Consequently, when I needed a guinea pig for my first installment of the Parent-Teacher Conference, A. J. was a willing subject. In the coming weeks, Ill be answering questions about the parent-teacher relationship in this space on alternating Thursdays. Have a question? E-mail me at teacherlahey@gmail.com.

title: Caring for a Mind in Crisis
description: One afternoon at a school not far from the hospital where I was working, a teacher opened a utility closet and found a staff member passed out on the floor. He was clutching a small bloody mass in one hand, a sharp knife in the other, she reported, a red stain spreading rapidly at his middle.

title: Senate Panel Approves Journalist Shield Legislation
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday passed legislation to provide greater protections against reporters being fined or imprisoned if they refuse to identify confidential sources. The bill, the Free Flow of Information Act of 2013, passed by 13 to 5, after lawmakers agreed on an amendment defining who qualifies as a journalist.

title: Looking for the Anti-Bloomberg
description: With Dave Weigel calling Tuesdays outcome in New Yorks mayoral primary (which turned on liberal angst about stop and frisk and economic inequality) and Colorados recall elections (which turned on conservative backlash against gun control) a defeat for the ethos of Bloombergism, this seems like a good time to highlight Jonathan Chaits excellent New York Magazine essay on Michael Bloombergs worldview and (deluded) presidential ambitions. Chait does a fine job of capturing the essential elements of Bloombergism, from the authoritarian governing style to the distinctive pink police state approach to social policy (sexual freedom and bike lanes for me, stop and frisk and soda bans for thee), and he cuts to the heart of why Bloombergs overall agenda wasnt really perfectly calibrated to the median voters allegedly post-partisan desires, as so many of the mayors Acela Corridor fans wanted to believe:

title: All the Rage | Mens Wear Collections for Speed Racers and Getaway Guys
description: In a welcome contrast to the bare-bones runways that have set the scene for most womens shows during New York Fashion Week, mens wear designers have played up the masculine, visual references. From the venues to the clothes, its almost as though Drive, the 2011 visual thriller starring Ryan Gosling, influenced it all. General Idea presented its sleek separates inside the Classic Car Club, where models walked in front of a pair of antique roadsters that set the tone for the labels mesh and reflective jackets. Tim Coppens took his collection to the track, outfitting his crew whose members carried racing helmets as the accessory du jour in long and short sleeveless jumpsuits and classic racing leathers. Backstage at Siki Im, models dressed amid parked cars before the show began inside an old garage. Opening Ceremony showed both mens and womens looks in its very first runway, but the setting and presentation was decidedly masculine: an army of models flooded the vast space at the SuperPier, all at once, chauffeured by a stream of shiny cars. And the satin bomber jackets, like the one Gosling wears in Drive, were in no short supply either. Bespoken, J. Crew, Marc by Marc Jacobs and Porsche Design all showed metallic and satin versions of the short zip-front blouson, many with models wearing expression-concealing shades like Goslings deadpan character.

title: A Heady Cocktail of Books and Booze
description: LET the publishing industry fret about the future of print. In an ever more digitized age, literature as live event appears to be thriving.

title: My Tragic Encounter With James Taylors Pig
description: The summer of 1971 was drawing to a close, and I had a large and growing problem: Kosher, my pet pig. I was 16, and the pig had been a poorly-thought-through joke gift from my father. When he brought her home to our Manhattan apartment in June, Kosher  the name was also his idea  was a (sort of) cuddly pinkish-white football who fit into a shoe box and drank from a bottle.

title: Ralph Lauren: Black, White and Red All Over
description: New York Fashion Week wraps up today with the three majors: Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs. Mr. Lauren kicked things off this morning with a collection shown at the St. Johns Center Studios over on Washington Street, where the designer had built an especially spare set this season: a white glass runway with a black backdrop at the end. No fancy chandeliers. No antlers. Just an enormous bouquet of white lilies that scented the entrance.

description: Mr. Hewitt says goodbye to a neighbor in the settlement.

title: Living With Cancer: A Rainbow Coalition
description: Everyone recognizes the pink ribbon of breast cancer, but fewer know the color of testicular (orchid), uterine (peach), lung (white), pancreatic (purple), or head and neck (burgundy/ivory) cancers. Given current research and treatment, as well as a commitment to equity, is it time to imagine a rainbow coalition?

title: Bowie Among Nominees for Britains Mercury Prize
description: David Bowie has been nominated for Britains prestigious Barclaycard Mercury Prize, along with several younger artists who were not even born when he first emerged as a star in the early 1970s.

title: After Frustration, Winslow Embraces Fresh Start With Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When tight end Kellen Winslow sought and received his release from the New England Patriots last September, ending his stint with the team after only nine days, it was as amicable a parting as there can be in the N.F.L.

description: The latest womens collection from Calvin Klein at New York fashion week.

title: Raucous Scene Grips Afghan Capital: Soccer Euphoria
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Olympic Stadium in Kabul has not seen this big a crowd since the Taliban used the place for public executions, with attendance mandatory.

title: Senator Asks Cellphone Carriers: What Exactly Do You Share With Government?
description: Last year, Edward J. Markey, then a member of the House of Representatives, asked the countrys major cellphone carriers to disclose how many data requests they received from federal and local law enforcement agencies. More than one million in 2011 alone, they said, revealing for the first time how ubiquitous cellphone records had become in criminal investigations.

title: Modern Love | Falling in Love at 71
description: Nora Johnson, long divorced, wasn't looking for love when she met George, a widowed 83-year-old. It just happened.

title: In a Breathtaking First, NASAs Voyager 1 Exits the Solar System
description: PASADENA, Calif.  By todays standards, the spacecrafts technology is laughable: it carries an 8-track tape recorder and computers with one-240,000th the memory of a low-end iPhone. When it left Earth 36 years ago, it was designed as a four-year mission to Saturn, and everything after that was gravy.

description: I used to think that elder love, if it even existed, was confined to rocking chairs or golf carts, that it had to be a dull business because of the physical limitations of age.

title: Simon Anderson, on Creating a Culture of  Shameless Honesty
description: This interview with Simon Anderson, chief executive of DreamHost, a Web hosting provider and domain name registrar, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Ackermann to Resign From Board of Siemens
description: Josef Ackermann, the former chief executive of Deutsche Bank, plans to resign as a deputy chairman of Siemens, a decision that comes shortly after he abruptly resigned as chairman of Zurich Insurance Group last month.

title: Too Much Shakespeare? Be Not Cowed
description: The feast of Shakespeare on New York stages this season represents a boon for those who cannot get enough of his work. But there are many who will be happy to leave this banquet entirely untasted. Shocking but true: There walk among us a solid bloc of the Shakespeare-averse.

title: Havens Found Off the Treadmill

title: Spinning a Ballot Measure on Gambling
description: Generally speaking, proposals for constitutional amendments on the ballot in New York State are written in carefully dull, straightforward language. The idea is to ask voters if they want to make a more permanent change to the way the state government operates, yes or no. Thats all. The phrasing should not nudge voters in either direction, in favor or against.

title: After Mayoral Primaries, a Sharp Divide
description: Joseph J. Lhota and Bill de Blasio embraced the role of fierce rivals on Thursday, displaying the testy tenor and deep ideological divide of a general election matchup even as thousands of ballots from New York Citys mayoral primary had yet to be counted.

description: In a Google+ Hangout, the Secretary of State John Kerry speaks with the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof, the executive editor of Syria Deeply, Lara Setrakian, and Andrew Beiter, a school teacher.

title: Cape Verde Disqualified From World Cup Playoffs
description: Cape Verde, a tiny group of islands off West Africa bidding to become the smallest nation ever to qualify for the World Cup, was thrown out of the competition Thursday for fielding an ineligible player in a qualifying match last Saturday.

title: Teaching Children the Easy Lesson of Syria
description: We should be talking to our children about what is happening and what is being considered in Syria. Because while it may be counterintuitive, there are easy lessons in both the Syrian conflict, and the conflict over whether the United States and other nations should or should not intervene. They are not necessarily easy to understand, but they are easy to convey; so easy that they can be captured in clich: Uncertainty is the only certainty, and only hindsight is 20/20.

title: Vodafone Says Shareholders Clear Kabel Deutschland Bid
description: LONDON  Vodafone announced on Thursday that it had received sufficient investor support to win approval of its 7.7 bilion euros ($10.2 billion) takeover of the German cable operator Kabel Deutschland.

title: Seeking Connections on Independence Day
description: The quietly desperate characters in Four are driven by the piercing loneliness that goads people into pursuing risky couplings with strangers in the night. June (Emory Cohen), a closeted, baby-faced teenager, steals out of his parents house during a Fourth of July celebration and hooks up with Joe (Wendell Pierce), a stocky, middle-aged African-American college professor he met online. Joe picks up June in his car as the boy waits beside a pay phone at an abandoned strip mall. For the next few hours, they drive around as Joe tries to get to know the evasive, sulky June. Eventually, they stop at a motel.

description: The genre-crossing singer K.D. Lang will make her Broadway debut in February in After Midnight, the musical about Harlems legendary Cotton Club that opens at the Brooks Atkinson Theater in October.

Also, that Jeff Sachs, whose analysis and motives become increasingly mysterious, thinks that I dont pay enough attention to wasteful government spending. And that calls, I think, for a couple of reminders.

title: Toronto Video: Jason Bateman on Bad Words
description: TORONTO  In the comedy Bad Words, Jason Bateman stars as a man who enters a childrens spelling bee. Its also Mr. Batemans directorial debut. In this video, Mr. Bateman discusses the bitter character he plays, and also talks about the overseeing his first feature.

description: The future is on its way at the Guggenheim and at Sothebys.

title: The Story of Chagall, as Told by His Granddaughters
description: Strolling through a museum, two sisters stopped at a painting, a fantasy scene of faces and rooftops and a huge ox hanging upside down. They remembered it from childhood  it had hung in their parents living room, not because their parents were wealthy art patrons with an impressive collection, but because the painting had been made by their grandfather, the artist Marc Chagall.

title: Chinas Plan to Curb Air Pollution Sets Limits on Coal Use and Vehicles
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government announced an ambitious plan on Thursday to curb air pollution across the nation, including setting some limits on burning coal and taking high-polluting vehicles off the roads to ensure a drop in the concentration of particulate matter in cities.

title: Atomic Gaffes
description: A little over 50 years ago a South Carolina doctor (and the grandfather of this reviewer) treated a family for injuries sustained when a sudden, inexplicable explosion tore through their backyard. The injuries were not serious, and after spending the night at the doctors house they returned home to discover that the object in the 50-foot crater left behind their house was an atomic bomb that had fallen from a passing Air Force plane. The bomb had not been armed with its nuclear core; the blast came from the explosives intended to trigger a chain reaction. The crater can still be seen today.

title: What Becomes of the Lost Estates?
description: Recently I attended two extraordinary dinners in New York, one featuring the precise, focused red Burgundies of Ren Engel and the other the exquisite Cte-Rties of Marius Gentaz.

title: Something I Said?
description: Ive put off writing to you because Im afraid you will yell at me. My best friend had a really lousy boyfriend. He was cheap, took her for granted, and Im pretty sure he cheated on her. But I kept quiet about him, as I suspect you recommend. (He wasnt abusive or anything.) Even after they broke up, I vowed to say nothing. But one night, after a couple of glasses of wine, I told her exactly what I thought of him. Surprise! Theyre back together again, and now my friend will barely look at me. What can I do? Lisette

description: The actor talks about the differences in how audiences interpret a character.

title: Riding the Waves of a Memorial
description: Olga Bloom, the Bargemusic founder, liked to wake up early and go to the barge not long after daybreak. She would tune her violin or viola and play some music, often her beloved Bach, as she looked through the big windows at the back toward the rushing currents of the East River and the skyscrapers of Lower Manhattan, the view her audience had during concerts.

title: Works From Earliest Photographers Are on Display and on Sale
description: Archives and favorite works from a few of the earliest photographers have stayed together and are headed for public view and sale.

title: Calvin Klein in Full Color
description: There were five black models in the 35-look Calvin Klein show this afternoon. Five models is a significant number in a collection that in recent seasons has included only one or no black models, the most prominent example in New York of a general trend of whitewashing the runways.

title: Richard Stengel to Leave Time for the Obama Administration
description: Richard Stengel, the managing editor of Time magazine, is leaving to become under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs at the State Department, according to people with knowledge of the appointment.

title: X-Factor Hits a New Ratings Low in Its Season Premiere
description: The days of the singing competition blockbuster on television may be coming to an end.

title: Pynchonopolis
description: Are you ready for Thomas (Screaming Comes Across the Sky) Pynchon on the subject of Sept. 11, 2001? On the one hand, his poetry of paranoia and his grasp of historys surrealist passages make a perfect fit. Yet his slippery insouciance, his relentless japery, risk being tonally at odds with the subject. Either way, and despite his sensibilitys entrenchment in 60s Californian hippiedom, Pynchon is a New Yorker, with an intimate license to depict the sulfurous gray plumes and tragic tableaus of that irreconcilable moment: On the way home she passes the neighborhood firehouse. Theyre in working on one of the trucks. . . . She threads among the daily bunches of flowers on the sidewalk, which will be cleared in a while. The list of firefighters here who were lost on 11 September is kept back someplace more intimate, out of the public face, anybody wants to see it they can ask, but sometimes it shows more respect not to put such things out on a billboard. . . . What makes these guys choose to go in, work 24-hour shifts and then keep working, keep throwing themselves into those shaky ruins, torching through steel, bringing people to safety, recovering parts of others, ending up sick, beat up by nightmares, disrespected, dead?

title: U.S. Jumps to No. 13 in FIFA Rankings
description: It is fitting that the game that counts the most for the United States mens soccer team  a World Cup qualifier against Mexico  also counts in the latest edition of FIFAs world rankings, released Thursday.

title: Singing Soprano in Normandy
description: Mobsters cant help themselves. Its in their nature to solve problems the family way  with baseball bats, explosives and anything at hand that leaves an opponent dead or writhing in agony. Sadistic violence is a reflexive response to having grown up in households where fathers regularly beat their sons senseless for no reason.

title: Republicans Say Documents Show Abuse of Power at I.R.S.
description: House Republicans on Thursday released what they said was further evidence that the Internal Revenue Service acted on political impulses when it targeted conservative groups for special scrutiny.

title: In a Cultural and Sexual Netherland, Gaudy and Unsettling
description: Shortly after The Last Time I Saw Macao opens, a bosomy blonde begins lip-syncing to Jane Russell crooning You Kill Me. This lip-syncer isnt just any ordinary chanteuse, but Candy (Cindy Scrash), a transsexual with a square jaw and breasts that look ready for liftoff. Howard Hughes  who fretted about how Russells bust should be deployed in Macao, an amusing 1952 Hollywood noir made by his studio  might have approved. Candy, dressed in a cheongsam with a peekaboo front, performs the song in a pool of light against a tall fence, a couple of lions frolicking on the other side. Like Russell, Candy may be from planet Earth, but shes also from another world.

title: Loveless Marriage on a Lovely Island
description: While watching Kat Coiros dour marital drama, And While We Were Here, I realized with a mixture of sadness and relief that adultery and erotic discontent, at least in the movies, are not what they used to be. Theyve lost any frisson of the exotic and forbidden.

title: A Modern Warrior (and a Meat Sack)
description: Were in the middle of a boomlet of superb, satire-minded writing about professional football. That screaming you hear coming across the sky? Its a wobbly spiral.

title: Federal Judge Approves American Airlines Plan to Exit Bankruptcy
description: A federal judge approved American Airlines bankruptcy plan on Thursday but ruled that the decision was contingent on Justice Department approval of the carriers merger with US Airways.

title: Doomed Blond Bombshell Not Really Included
description: The misleading title of Jayne Mansfields Car suggests that this meandering family drama, set in Morrison, Ala., in 1969, relates to the blond, buxom Hollywood star who died in 1967 in a traffic accident in Louisiana. But the only thing this loquacious multigenerational family history has to do with Mansfield is a brief scene of her wrecked vehicle on display as a traveling sideshow.

title: Horrors With Lighthearted Bookends
description: At the risk of sounding like a crank: Love is the problem with Chagall: Love, War, and Exile at the Jewish Museum.

title: A Strange Bond Between Killers
description: Ive created a monster, John says to Lee, with a satisfied smile. John is proud of his protg, and proud of himself for being such an effective mentor. He is also speaking the literal truth.

title: An All-Too-Human Federal Reserve
description: If Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve seeks to demystify that organization, it doesnt really succeed. But the documentary, by Jim Bruce, does leave you with the impression that however the Fed does what it does, it is often just guessing or willfully acting against the best long-term interests of the economy.

title: Trying to Be a Parent, for Better or for Worse
description: There is something irresistible about a movie that begins with a wedding (think of The Godfather), and there are few movie weddings as beautiful as the one at the start of Mother of George, Andrew Dosunmus gorgeous and delicate new drama. The party, a swirl of color, music and sentiment, observed with an eye for telling details of behavior, sets the tone  exuberant, dignified, a little bit anxious  for what is to follow.

title: A Couple Flees a House of Death but Cant Escape the Ghosts
description: A mess from start to finish  though, judging by the ending, this story wont be over any time soon  Insidious: Chapter 2 is the kind of lazy, halfhearted product that gives scary movies a bad name. From its robotic acting to its generic props (enough already with the self-motivated childrens toys), this shoddy sequel, tacked together with the cynicism of a carnival barker, suggests that the director, James Wan, is long overdue for a vacation.

title: Pakistanis Iron Grip, Wielded in Opulent Exile, Begins to Slip
description: LONDON  For two decades, Altaf Hussain has run his brutal Pakistani political empire by remote control, shrouded in luxurious exile in London and long beyond the reach of the law.

title: From Welded Worshipers, a Joyful Pneumatic Noise
description: CHICO MacMURTRIE, a Brooklyn-based artist, has been building robots for nearly three decades. His creations do not vacuum the house, teach foreign languages to children or try to take over the world; they were designed to play music, mainly syncopated rhythms, and perhaps evoke some thought about humanity.

title: When Appraisals Come in Low
description: One consequence of the subprime mortgage crisis is a far more rigid home appraisal process. Borrowers can complain about lower than expected appraisals  which may mean they cant borrow enough to meet an agreed-upon sale price, or cant refinance  but lenders very rarely reconsider.

title: Microscope on the U.S. Food Supply
description: GMO OMG, Jeremy Seiferts plain-folks primer on genetically modified food, is pitched somewhere between the high school student and the helicopter parent. Its central concern  that Americans are inadequately informed about the corporate manipulation of the food supply  may be valid, but its reliance on cute-kiddie silliness does little to fill that void. Even children as photogenic as Mr. Seiferts are no substitute for rigorous research.

title: A Little Ditty That Became an Anthem of Hip-Hop
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Family Reunion With a Party Under the Clouds
description: It has been a long time since a marijuana high has been romanticized like this in the movies. Right in the middle of Richard LeMays Naked as We Came, a terminally ill woman, her daughter, her son and her handsome young housemate (with whom the son has just spent the night) share a joint on a glorious green lawn  and the universes whitest clouds float by, casting a spell, in the bluest sky of all time.

title: Silly Girl, You Want to Race a Boy?
description: You can tell that Wadjda is a rebel by looking at her feet. The other students at her all-girls madrassa in Saudi Arabia accessorize their long, shapeless gray dresses with black Mary Janes and frilly socks, but Wadjda, a lanky 10-year-old with big eyes and an easy smile, favors black Converse high-tops, a small gesture of spirited individuality in a world that seems organized to suppress any such expression.

title: The March on Washington, in Harlem
description: By the end of 1963, Medgar Evers had been murdered, four young black girls had perished in the bombing of an Alabama church, and Nina Simone had had enough. The next year, she put her career on the line by releasing Mississippi Goddam, her defiant response to these deaths and an anthem for the civil rights struggle.

title: To Table, From a Farm of Their Own
description: Farm to table has a ring of authenticity at Arethusa al Tavolo in Bantam, which is owned by George Malkemus and Anthony Yurgaitis, the proprietors of Arethusa Farm in Litchfield; they are also president and vice president of Manolo Blahnik in North and South America. Al Tavolo, which opened in June, is adjacent to the dairy farms retail shop, the two businesses occupying brick buildings separated by a narrow courtyard.

title: F.D.A. Panel Backs Pre-Surgery Drug for Breast Cancer
description: A federal advisory committee cleared the way on Thursday for the first approval of a cancer drug that would be used to treat patients before surgery to remove their tumors.

title: 20% Turnout in New York Primaries
description: Bill de Blasio took first place in the Democratic mayoral primary on Tuesday with the votes from only about 3 percent of all New Yorkers. If that percentage seems small, consider that the number and share of votes received by Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee, was only about one-tenth that amount.

title: Friars Club Proposed for Landmark Status
description: To most owners, landmark designation is no joke.Repairs must be at a high level,time is spent in review,major changes are barred  thats nothing to laugh at. Now it looks as if the 1909 town house of the Friars Club, at 57 East 55th Street, may come before the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Will the Friarsbe happy if their monastery is protected, or wouldthe commissioners get the next roast?

title: A Short Post, a Big Splash: #TwitterIPO
description: Twitter, which began as a side project in a small but failing start-up seven years ago and grew into one of the worlds largest platforms for public conversation, is about to take its biggest step yet into maturity: selling stock to the public.

title: Calvin Klein: Spring 2014 RTW
description: New York

title: Sharing the Bounty of Priceless Art
description: Films about caped avengers, Hobbits and young wizards are often packaged as franchises. Sequels are less expected, though, for documentaries about working-class patrons of Minimal and Conceptual art. But Herb & Dorothy 50x50 is just that: Megumi Sasakis follow-up to her 2009 film about Herbert and Dorothy Vogel  him a postal clerk, her a school librarian in New York City  who accumulated an enormous and trailblazing art collection.

title: The Brilliance of His Universe
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Brahms Rising: Echoes of a First Impression
description: Brahms was 20 when he first played for Robert and Clara Schumann at their home in Dsseldorf on Oct. 1, 1853. In her diary entry that night, Clara gushed about the handsome young musician whom God appeared to have placed, fully formed, on earth. Equally gushing but more important for Brahmss career was the article Robert published in his journal of music criticism, in which he imagined heroes and graces standing watch over the infant Brahmss cradle.

title: The Activist Who Worked for the F.B.I.
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Absolutely, Paul; Right Away, Ringo
description: Sweet but far from juicy, Good Ol Freda offers a gobsmackingly tame profile of Freda Kelly, the Beatles longtime secretary and fan club manager. Now an amiable, still-typing grandmother in her late 60s, Ms. Kelly sits on a nondescript sofa and delivers nostalgic observations on a time when her life was a great deal more exciting.

title: Disney Infinity Game Has Strong Early Sales
description: LOS ANGELES   Disneys new Infinity video game is a hit out of the gate, but it is too early to say whether the release will deliver the kind of blockbuster holiday sales that the companys struggling interactive division needs for a turnaround.

title: Boldly Deciding to Stay Sunny, Sweet and Upbeat
description: Utter simplicity: a fresh breeze blowing through a meadow as a barefoot country girl skips through the grass under a blue sky dotted with a few puffy clouds. That describes the aura around the irresistible Sutton Foster on Tuesday evening at Caf Carlyle, where she opened her new cabaret show.

title: A Brass-Filled Tribute Does Not Hold Back
description: Its hard to imagine that a work consisting of 52 trumpets could be a chamber version of anything, but Henry Brants imagination was large scale. He originally wrote Flight Over a Global Map for 100 trumpets, one of several works  including Orbits for 80 trombones, soprano and organ  that he composed for vast brass or wind forces.

title: Images Propelled Beyond Pictures
description: Among the works by eight artists in New Photography 2013 at the Museum of Modern Art is a series of prints by Josephine Pryde showing guinea pigs bustling about in what appears to be studio detritus. Viewers who know that Ms. Pryde uses photography to explore ideas about social issues will surely assume that these are not just affectionate pictures of her cute little pets. A wall label explains that the guinea pig, native to South America, was so named when it was brought to Europe on slave ships known as Guineamen.

Few New York art seasons are fully under way until the Metropolitan Museum of Art rolls out a fall exhibition with enough visual thrills and historical insights to knock your socks off. Yet this years offering may be even more outstanding than usual.  Interwoven Globe: The Worldwide Textile Trade, 1500-1800, opening on Monday, is a staggering overview of more than three centuries of art, commerce, craft and cross-cultural fertilization.

The ousted Democrats, Angela Giron of Pueblo and John Morse of Colorado Springs, will be replaced by Republican state senators.

title: 36 Hours in Buenos Aires
description: Sure you can have a tango-filled, steak-fueled weekend in Buenos Aires. But Argentinas capital and largest city also has a much more contemporary side that has been emerging from its traditional roots and European influences for years now. Blame it on a creative class of Porteos, as the locals are known, who have turned the Latin metropolis into a vibrant, cosmopolitan community. And its a movement that keeps evolving. From hidden supper clubs to bankrolled art galleries to buzzing boutiques, the sprawling city is a study of sophistication on the rise. But that doesnt mean you should bypass the old timey cafes and parrillas. Partly what makes the city so irresistibly alive right now is its checkered past peeking through its new personality.

title: A Steakhouse Amid a World of Tastes
description: In the last few years, Mount Kisco has enjoyed a rush of restaurants drawn to its buzzing downtown. Joining the long-appreciated Thai Angels and the Spanish restaurant La Camelia, newcomers have been filling other ethnic niches. Theres Neo with its creative New World spins on Asian fare; Bonnie Sarans Indian and French places, Little Kebab Station and Little Crepe Street; the Ethiopian spot Lalibela; the trattoria and cafe Via Vanti!; and Taverna Pandesia, a Greek restaurant  to mention just a few. It was only a matter of time until a steakhouse threw its hat into the ring.

title: Fred Katz, Who Married Cello to Jazz, Dies at 94
description: Fred Katz, a classically trained cellist who quite by accident helped elevate his instrument to unlikely stardom in jazz, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94.

description: Two years after local militias overthrew the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, many of those same fighters have brought Libyas critical oil industry to a halt, as a challenge to the latest in a series of that countrys interim governments.

description: WASHINGTON  More than 100 women were arrested on Capitol Hill on Thursday after they blocked a busy intersection to press the House of Representatives to move on immigration legislation in a protest that rallied national womens groups to the cause.

description: PARIS  While thousands of Polish labor union members marched through Warsaw on Thursday, a member of the governing party defected, pushing the center-right government of Prime Minister Donald Tusk to the brink of losing its parliamentary majority amid intensifying popular discontent.

title: A GameDay Extravaganza, Minus the Game
description: The ESPN traveling circus known as College GameDay set up camp this week in College Station, Tex., where top-ranked Alabama will play No. 6 Texas A&M on Saturday. ESPNs trucks, stages, video walls and sponsor tents, as well as the Home Depot Bus, have taken up nearly one-third of the drill field where the Aggies corps of cadets holds formal reviews. And starting with reports Thursday afternoon and running through its three-hour show Saturday morning, GameDay and other ESPN shows will spend hours analyzing the matchup.

description: WASHINGTON  Initial jobless claims fell to their lowest level last week since the spring of 2006, the Labor Department said on Thursday. Or not.

title: Colorado Towns Are Left Stranded in Deadly Floods
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Walls of water cascading down hillsides caused flash floods across Colorado on Thursday, killing at least three people. The flooding cut off major highways, isolated mountain towns and closed the main campus of the University of Colorado, the authorities said.

title: Orioles Zip Around but Need On-Field Surge
description: BALTIMORE  The wheels whirring beneath outfielder Steve Pearces feet propelled him along the concave underbelly of Oriole Park at Camden Yards. As if on cue, a stadium attendant opened the clubhouse door, and Pearce rode into the inner sanctum aboard his motorized skateboard.

title: A Brilliant Mess
