title: The Beast, Not the Beauty
description: She isnt a comedian, but the artist Amy Sillman is funny and dirty.

title: New Releases Top Chart
description: The top five albums on the Billboard 200 chart this week are all fresh releases, led by Jack Johnsons From Here to Now to You, which sold 117,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

title: Moms Van Is Called Uber
description: On the first, fine Tuesday in autumn, Guy Parkin, 13, was sitting outside on the steps of the Salk School of Science on East 20th Street. He had stayed late to attend a Specialized High School Admissions Test group study session, so it was nearing 5 p.m. when a black S.U.V. pulled up, dispatched through his mothers account on the Uber app.

title: Uber-Practical: Using the Private Car Service App to Transport Teens
description: I should say it up front: Im an Uber car user. When Im in outer Boston or the outer boroughs of New York City, where yellow cabs can be hard to hail, I use the Uber app to call a car  especially if Im pushed for time. If I were a city parent, I could see the practicality of using an Uber to take a child from Point A to Point B.

title: An Arm-Twister in the Oval Office
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The crowds excitedly filing in to the American Repertory Theater here are not, I am willing to bet, panting at the prospect of hearing words like filibuster and cloture tossed into their laps. Nor are they eager to watch politicians fulminating and pontificating in front of microphones. For such diversions, after all, we have cable news, and with the government slouching toward yet another partisan smackdown, its showtime 24/7.

title: 7 Paratroopers and Paths They Took Through an Israel at a Crossroads
description: Much has been made over the years, and rightly so, of the messianic fervor that swept Israel after its spectacular victory in the 1967 war. The conquest of Sinai from Egypt, the Golan Heights from Syria, and the West Bank and East Jerusalem from Jordan, all in a biblically epic six days, seemed to religious Israelis  and many secular ones  like a miracle, a sign that God wanted to reunite his people with their promised land. Not long afterward, settlement beyond the 1967 borders began.

title: A Shop on Land Is Focused on the Water
description: Captain Mikes Diving Services on City Island in the Bronx is just a stroll away from Long Island Sound.

title: HBOs Party Celebrates Its Domination on Emmy Night
description: HBO did not sweep this years Emmy Awards, but it still had plenty of reason to celebrate Sunday night.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Writers this month are preoccupied with lost youth. Multiple characters in two short-story collections confront growing old while three novels and a nonfiction oral history reflect on lives cut short.

title: Irans Leader, Denouncing Holocaust, Stirs Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  As he conducts a high-profile good-will visit to New York this week, Irans new president, Hassan Rouhani, says he is bringing a simple message of peace and friendship. But on Wednesday, Mr. Rouhani set off a political storm here and in Iran, with an acknowledgment and condemnation of the Holocaust that landed him in precisely the kind of tangled dispute he had hoped to avoid.

title: Thursdays Matchup: 49ers (1-2) at Rams (1-2)
description: 8:25 p.m. Eastern

title: U.K. Utility Shares Fall After Pledge to Freeze Rates
description: LONDON  Party loyalists applauded. Investors blanched.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Curtain Call
description: To mark the conclusion of Milan Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of 14 of its visionary designers and capture how the gesture can subtly reveal a hint of their personalities, whether outsize or not.

title: The Fashion Week Sports Report
description: VERA WANG WAS ONTO the sports trend back in New York. Marc Jacobs, too, had the right shoes for it with his Teva-style sandals. But if there was one unifying theme of the Milan collections that ended on Monday (and lets admit it, they were a bit all over the place), it was sports.

title: If Father Doesnt Know Best, Hes Willing to Learn
description: It doesnt take long to realize that something is off in The Michael J. Fox Show, the new NBC sitcom in which Mr. Fox plays a variation of himself: Mike Henry, a network news anchor reviving his career after a hiatus because of Parkinsons disease.

title: A Giant of Dance, Seizing on Musicality to Weave His Spell
description: Amid a fall dance season richly packed with significant events across the New York dance map, a single program at New York City Ballet stands out like a summit. All of its four items are by George Balanchine, and all are well known  and yet who ever knows any Balanchine ballet?

title: Giving Drug Advice Along With Music
description: When the TomorrowWorld festival opens outside Atlanta on Friday, concertgoers can expect to see safety measures that have become common at European electronic dance music festivals but have yet to catch on in the United States: a nonprofit drug education group will be giving advice, not only on the dangers of drug abuse, but also on how those who choose to take party drugs can use them more safely.

title: Look Good in Ways You Can Afford
description: Boots That Go Over the Knee for Under $1,000

title: Olivier Zahm Brings Purple Jeans to Closed Label
description: OLIVIER ZAHM, THE EDITOR of Purple magazine, is a fixture on the fashion circuit but probably not someone who would likely wind up on a best-dressed list. Has anyone ever seen him wearing anything besides a denim jacket and jeans that are two sizes too small?

title: From Art to T. Rex, Shutdown Stirs Worry
description: WASHINGTON  The Hope Diamond, all 45.5 carats of it, will remain securely guarded here at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. The Japanese giant salamanders of the National Zoo need not worry if the HVAC systems keeping their habitat just right break down  a maintenance crew will be on call.

title: Garde Robe: High-End Clothes Storage
description: Secreted away in a nondescript warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, may be one of the most valuable collections of contemporary fashion in the world. Few know of its existence. There are no signs on the building. To get there, you take an elevator to the second floor and enter an unmarked door.

title: Sudans President, Wanted by International Court, Cancels Visit to U.N.
description: The United Nations said Wednesday that President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who is wanted by the International Criminal Court in The Hague on genocide charges, has canceled his visit to the General Assembly, amid protests in Sudans capital.

title: ScienceTake: A Frogs Secret to Sticking
description: Nature is full of animals with amazing abilities that scientists are trying to understand, and the torrent frog is one of them. True to its name, it lives stuck to waterfalls.

title: Pinpricks, but No Dagger in Putinland
description: MOSCOW  There were some complications when the Conceptual artist John Baldessari brought his latest works to Russia as part of the fifth Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Art. First, the title of his project, Double Take, did not translate easily into Russian.

title: Art Matters | Miuccia Prada, Jane Fonda and Some Models Wearing Latex
description: With looks that made references to the fist-in-the-air energy of the early-90s riot grrrls and Britney Spearss Work Bitch on the soundtrack, Miuccia Pradas spring 2014 show once again explored the paradoxes of dressing the women of today  and tomorrow. For years now, collections like this latest have been inspiring artists across disciplines and generations to ponder the intersections of the beauty industries and feminist ideals.

title: USA-2 Moves to Semifinals in Venice Cup
description: The world team championships in Bali, Indonesia, have reached the semifinal stage.

title: Keeping It Fake
description: It was a typical stand-up show, with embarrassing personal stories and observational gripes, until Kate Berlant strutted onstage in the East Village bar Niagara. She was wearing a backpack and an expression out of a TED talk.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Oracles Sailing Success, and an Apple Maps Oops
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Learning From the Black Lumberjack
description: Robert Rising is a self-taught lumberjack and furniture maker who came to his profession 10 years ago because he was building a house in upstate New York and wanted, he said recently, some cool wood for counter tops and furniture. Since last spring, he has been hosting D.I.Y. Fridays at his yard in Ardsley, N.Y. For $200, plus the cost of the wood, which can range from $350 to $3,500, participants make their own furniture.

title: Libertys Fields of Flowers
description: The London company Liberty began selling textiles for furnishings in 1874, but a century later it licensed out the interiors side of the business to put more energy into fashion. Now that the license is expired, Liberty has been reeling home dcor back with collections like Nesfield, new coordinated fabrics, wallpaper and paint that reflect the companys heritage of elaborate prints and vibrant colors. Named for William Nesfield, a 19th-century English landscape architect, the collection draws from Libertys archive of some 43,000 designs. Patterns include classic chintzy small flora and some quite big abstract paisleys and geometrics, said Kirstie Carey, managing director of Liberty Wholesale. Though Nesfield is not going to be for the faint of heart, Ms. Carey added, those who fear a festival of flowers do have the option of picking one or two elements. All the styles work together, she said. Information: liberty.co.uk.

title: Discounts at Michele Varian, Peter Harrison and Sferra
description: On Thursday only, Michele Varian is taking 20 percent off all items, in store and online (recycled porcelain bottles, regularly $24 to $48, are about $19 to $38). Some discontinued or damaged items at the store will be up to 85 percent off from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m.; 27 Howard Street (Crosby Street), (212) 343-0088, michelevarian.com. Use code Stoopsale if shopping online.

title: Looking for Beauty, Finding Soul
description: The Inspired Home: Interiors of Deep Beauty (Harper Design, $35) sounds like yet another gorgeous coffee table book. But its author, Karen Lehrman Bloch, was determined to show homes that are not merely perfect; they also have a soul.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Rochas Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: Whats the Best Way to Give Our Shower a High-End Look?
description: Q. Theres an ugly plastic shower stall in our bathroom. If we decide to replace it, whats the best way to give the shower a high-end look?

title: Soaked, Not Welded
description: For a lighting collection called OverNight, Els Woldhek and Georgi Manassiev, London designers known as Odd Matter, coat stained-glass panels in conductive paint and immerse them overnight in a copper bath. The copper builds up on the edges to form a tightfitting frame, eliminating the need for welding.

title: Musings on a Structure for Heaven
description: The architect Alexander Gorlin, 58, has kept files full of arcane references to kabbalistic principles during two decades of designing projects, from public schools and synagogues to palatial Hamptons houses. Although not a terribly devout Jew, he has studied ancient Jewish texts and modern interpretations by scholars including Gershom Scholem and Daniel C. Matt. He has looked for buildings and artworks related to the texts themes of shattering, repair, voids and heavenly structure. His fifth book, Kabbalah in Art and Architecture (Pointed Leaf Press, $60), compares Herzog & de Meurons steel lacework of the Birds Nest Olympic stadium in Beijing to the radiance of the Birds Nest mentioned in the Zohar and Rothko paintings to Exodus descriptions of deep colors bleeding into one other.

title: You Are What You Stack
description: It is publishing season for decorators, and scores of them have new books out. The monograph, an expository form once reserved for architects, seems to have become the preferred form of publicity for interior designers as well, even those with just a few years of work under their belts.

title: When a House Falls in the Forest
description: Not long ago, I learned that the house I grew up in had been razed to the ground. This was no ordinary house, certainly not to me. It had walls of glass that overlooked a wood we called the Forest. There was a skylight that turned the rain into a thunderous clatter, and acorns thudded down on it from the overhanging oaks. The spiral staircase to the lower level had real rocks in it  the bedrock left standing when the house was settled onto its perch on the hill. Light filled every room, and the shadows of trees and leaves floated in and out.

title: Bookends: Embracing Literature
description: The Haslegrave brothers, who own a design firm called hOmE, have amassed an impressive collection of books and magazines. Anyone visiting their loftlike studio in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, will notice stray periodicals stashed in nooks and crannies, and volumes stacked in corners and lining makeshift shelves. Yet not a single proper bookend.

title: What Lurks Beneath the Linoleum in Columbia County
description: Namely, wide-plank pine floors and square-head nails.

title: Scraping Away the Decades
description: The restoration began with a valiant swing of the sledgehammer. Robert Highsmith and Stefanie Brechbuehler knew that somewhere inside the house they had bought was a quaint 1850s structure, but the 20th-century additions made it almost impossible to see.

title: Poll Results on President Obamas Performance
description: Complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll of 1,014 adults conducted from Sept. 19 to Sept. 23 via cellphones and land lines.

title: The Places Your Phone Shant Go
description: If you ever pull out your phone somewhere you might regret, just know that our readers are watching.

title: The Waters Murky. Come On In!
description: Most people, when they imagine scuba diving, probably picture crystalline waters and exotic locations like the Bahamas, Bermuda and Belize. Few would think of the Bronx.

title: Roll Over? Fat Chance
description: She has been in at least three fitness programs. She runs on the treadmill. She swims in a lap pool. Her trainers shout encouragement. And although her target weight still eludes her, Lolita remains optimistic, smiling gamely during her workout and snacking on carrots.

title: Doggie Weight Watchers
description: With waistlines expanding, some chubby dogs are being sent to fitness programs to get slim and trim.

title: Canine Cardio
description: With so many American dogs overweight, mans best friend is hitting the gym at kennels and pet spas across the country.

title: Americans Views on the President
description: With another fiscal deadline looming in Washington, The New York Times and CBS News asked Americans for their opinion on the federal budget, government spending and President Obamas job performance.

title: Obamas Approval Rating Matches Two-Year Low, Poll Shows
description: President Obamas standing with Americans has slumped significantly, as the public remains skeptical about his health care law and unsure about the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Breaking Bad Creator Gilligan in Deal for CBS Show, Battle Creek
description: Vince Gilligan, the creator and producer of one of the most-talked-about series in recent years, Breaking Bad, is the hottest name in television. Breaking Bad is fresh off an Emmy win for best drama and drawing huge audiences as it builds toward the final episode of its five-season run on AMC on Sunday.

title: West Says U.N. Nears Syria Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS  After months of crippling deadlock, members of the United Nations Security Council have inched closer to the details of a binding resolution on Syria, Western diplomats said Wednesday, though Russia, one of Syrias strongest allies, denied that a consensus had been reached.

title: Day Devoted to Hoisting Guinness Starts to Leave a Bitter Taste
description: DUBLIN  Bars across Ireland will be thronged on Thursday with early evening drinkers. Groups of inebriated young people will be staggering around the streets, and hospital emergency rooms will be packed.

title: The Yankees Farewell Sundays of 2008 and 2013
description: Because the Yankees, in most seasons, roll out of bed and stroll right into the postseason, it stands out when they actually do not get there.

title: A Big Week for the Advertising Industry, in Many Ways
description: A REVEALING picture can be painted by the numbers of the 10th annual Advertising Week in New York. An estimated 90,000 people are attending the conference this week, with events taking place at more than a dozen locations. And according to Matt Scheckner, executive director of Advertising Week, 798 speakers will have participated in 198 panels, presentations and seminars.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Fund to Let Investors Bet on Price of Bitcoins
description: The upstart stock exchange SecondMarket has made a name for itself allowing investors to buy shares of hot private companies like Twitter. Now that those companies are going public, SecondMarket is turning its attention to the next new thing  bitcoin.

title: Pursuing Graft Cases at Higher Levels, Chinese Leader Risks Unsettling Elites
description: HONG KONG  Shortly before his retirement late last year, Zhou Yongkang, the longtime chief of Chinas domestic security apparatus, visited an office of the state oil company where he had started his ascent in the Communist Party hierarchy. He spoke of his undimmed devotion to the company, China National Petroleum Corporation, and to his fellow oilmen.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,263 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Chaos and Harmony in Old Dhaka
description: The Bangladeshi photographer Munem Wasif explores the streets, rhythms and harmonies of Old Dhaka.

title: The Americas Cup Finale: Oracles Path to Victory
description: A look at how the final race in the Americas Cup unfolded, with Oracle Team USA beating Emirates Team New Zealand by 44 seconds.

title: Jane Connell, Agnes Gooch of Mame, Is Dead at 87
description: Jane Connell, a character actress best known for her portrayal of Agnes Gooch, the mousy secretary to the title character in the musical Mame, died on Sunday in Englewood, N.J. She was 87.

title: Oscar Espinosa Chepe, Cuban Economist and Castro Critic, Dies at 72
description: Oscar Espinosa Chepe, a high-ranking Cuban economist and diplomat who became a vocal critic of Fidel Castro in the 1990s but chose to remain in Cuba, despite enduring harassment and imprisonment, died on Monday in Madrid, where he was undergoing medical treatment. He was 72.

title: U.S. Sees Direct Threat in Attack at Kenya Mall
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Viewing the deadly siege at a shopping mall in Kenya as a direct threat to its security, the United States is deploying dozens of F.B.I. agents to investigate the wreckage, hoping to glean every piece of information possible to help prevent such a devastating attack from happening again, possibly even on American soil.

title: Trailer: Hers to Lose
description: Christine C. Quinn, the longtime front-runner in the New York City mayoral race, lost in the 2013 Democratic primary. This behind-the-scenes documentary captures the final month of her campaign.

title: Fight Over Energy Finds a New Front in a Corner of Idaho
description: LAPWAI, Idaho  In this remote corner of the Northwest, most people think of gas as something coming from a pump, not a well. But when it comes to energy, remote isnt what it used to be.

title: Jets Lineman Crosses to the Other Side
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Will Campbell loved football, and he loved Warren Sapp, and he stood 6 feet 5 inches and weighed over 300 pounds. So he played on the defensive line. He was a top talent in Michigan, among the best tackles in the nation, a cornerstone of the Wolverines formidable 2009 recruiting class.

title: Cruz, Tea Party Hero, Rankles Senate G.O.P. Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ted Cruzs crusade to dismantle President Obamas health care law has helped cement his status as an emerging hero of the Tea Party and conservative grass roots. But it is stoking resentment and derision from many other Republicans, including his own Senate colleagues, who see his campaign as impractical, self-interested and potentially damaging to the partys electoral efforts in 2014 and beyond.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 19 through Sept. 23 with 1,014 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

title: In Indonesia, a Governor at Home on the Streets
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Each day, Joko Widodo, the governor of Jakarta, does something practically unheard-of among Indonesias political elite: he ventures into the streets to speak with the people who elected him.

title: NBC Gets More Than It Expected
description: When NBC Sports Group made a deal last year to carry the Americas Cup races from San Francisco Bay, it had modest hopes about viewership. The television heyday of the Cup, the premier yachting regatta, ended more than 20 years ago. By 2010, the Cups profile in the United States had declined enough so that live coverage that year was available only on what is now ESPN3, a digital network.

title: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Calls for War Crimes Inquiry

The official, Navi Pillay, the high commissioner for human rights, said she detected no new or comprehensive effort to independently or credibly investigate the allegations that tens of thousands of civilians were killed by the military during the closing months of the war. The government also offered no satisfactory responses to concerns over high levels of harassment of journalists, lawyers and human rights defenders, Ms. Pillay said, citing widespread fears over the degree to which the rule of law and democratic institutions in Sri Lanka are being undermined and eroded. Sri Lankas ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, Ravinatha Aryasinha, rejected Ms. Pillays views as not the result of an objective assessment.

On Wednesday,an estimated 175 workers who serve food, sell mementos ordo maintenance workin federal buildings in Washington D.C. went on strike for the day.Instead of showing up at their jobs, they showed up in front of the White House, where they urged President Obama to live up to his word.

title: Soldiers on the Home Front: David Finkel Talks About Thank You for Your Service
description: In his book The Good Soldiers, David Finkel, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Washington Post, vividly recounted the experience of a United States Army battalion in Baghdad in 2007 and 2008. In The New York Times Book Review, Doug Stanton called it a ferociously reported, darkly humorous and spellbinding book. Now, in Thank You for Your Service, Mr. Finkel follows several of those same soldiers back home in the United States, where they struggle with their memories of the war and the transition back to domestic life. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Finkel discussed his reporting methods, the militarys suicide rate, how being so close to the suffering of soldiers has changed him and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Sleeping at the Bauhaus
description: The Walter Gropius-designed Bauhaus Dessau in Germany has converted its studio building, once housing for architecture students, into a dorm-style boutique hotel. Book one of the 20 rooms fitted with Marcel Breuers steel tube furniture. Or, beginning in late October, stay in spaces personalized to reflect a notable former inhabitant  like a Josef Albers room, with replicas of a bed, a table and a cupboard the artist made while living there; or one dedicated to the architect Franz Ehrlich, with pieces he created for the German Democratic Republic in the 1950s. Doubles from about $55.

description: A lot of attention has been given to the health insurance exchanges opening next month. But if youre like most Americans, youll still get your insurance through an employer. And that means the annual open enrollment season, when you choose your benefits for the coming year, will soon be upon you.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Only days after heavily armed assailants stormed a crowded mall and killed scores of people in the capital, militants killed three people near the border with Somalia, Kenyan officials said Thursday, putting this country even further on edge.

But in reality, she is a full-time college student, and her father and I pay her tuition and virtually all her living expenses. A great deal of screaming has already been done. Can you help us navigate a more peaceful pathway?

title: In Fragmented Forests, Rapid Mammal Extinctions
description: In 1987, the government of Thailand launched a huge, unplanned experiment. They built a dam across the Khlong Saeng river, creating a 60-square-mile reservoir. As the Chiew Larn reservoir rose, it drowned the river valley, transforming 150 forested hilltops into islands, each with its own isolated menagerie of wildlife.

title: 36 Hours in Hampstead, London
description: Start with Montmartre. Add a cupful of Beacon Hill, a shot of vintage West Village and a splash of Hollywood. Combine with Londons most beautiful hill, and garnish with one unwelcome McDonalds. Here in Hampstead, Londons worst-kept, high-altitude secret, the ghosts of Sigmund Freud, T. S. Eliot and Robert Louis Stevenson mingle with Ricky Gervais, Ridley Scott and more Madonna-accented American expats than you can shake a Land Rover key at. But were all equal when it comes to losing ourselves in the charming lanes of Hampstead Village and the joyfully directionless expanse of the Heath, a metropolitan mini-wilderness that may be Europes finest city park. Welcome to Hampstead, as serene, green and lovely as ever.

title: In London, Big Views and Peaceful Picnics
description: Pack your provisions for this tour of the Hampstead neighborhood.

title: Boutiques Emerge in a Santiago Barrio
description: The Lastarria neighborhood in downtown Santiago used to be a leafy and tranquil residential area favored by retirees, but with its easy access to the city center and its many finance and consulting companies, the small barrio is drawing a more caffeinated younger set. This recent influx has led to the opening of several locally owned boutiques that have become the go-to places for one-of-a-kind finds. Though the main avenue, also called Lastarria, is mostly lined with bustling restaurants, these shops are tucked away on side streets in old buildings that are a mix of neo-Classical and colonial architecture.

description: During past government shutdowns, our capital city has stopped various local services, including garbage pickup, and closed scores of buildings across Washington, D.C.

title: HBO Orders Fifth Season of Boardwalk Empire
description: HBO subscribers can look forward to at least one more year of Nucky (Thompson): the cable network said Thursday that it was ordering a fifth season of Boardwalk Empire, its Emmy Award-winning period drama starring Steve Buscemi as a crime boss in 1920s-era Atlantic City. Boardwalk Empire, created by the Sopranos alumnus Terence Winter, began its fourth season on Sept. 8 and has drawn about 2 million viewers each week for first-run broadcasts of new episodes, though HBO said in a news release that the average gross audience was 7.5 million viewers over multiple showings. The series was recently rewarded with five Emmys for its 2012 season, including the award for outstanding supporting actor in a drama, which went to Bobby Cannavale for his portrayal of the violent and vengeful mobster Gyp Rosetti.

title: A Steakhouse With Theatrical Flair
description: It was one of the last miserably hot days of summer the first time I visited Stone Manor 101 in Hawthorne, but I did not feel sweaty and uncomfortable for long. Sitting on the steakhouses cushioned seats, enjoying the air conditioning, we looked out the big back windows and saw an open-pit fire being started outside. A few sips of a cool pepper margarita, made with a jalapeo-infused tequila, fresh lime juice and mint leaves, and I was transported to a whole different environment. The mugginess was gone; I actually felt cozy.

title: It Wasnt All He Needed, or All He Did
description: Success for an artist can be a dangerous thing. Just ask Robert Indiana. In the early 1960s, he was a leading light of the new Pop Art trend, along with Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg and Roy Lichtenstein. Then came disastrous mega-success. His 1966 images of big, blocky letters spelling the word Love  the o suggestively tilted  went viral. In the subsequent decade, his overproduction of the image in two and three dimensions, including his design for a 1973 United States postage stamp, eventually ruined his reputation in the serious New York art world. Disheartened, in 1978 he exiled himself to the island of Vinalhaven in Maine, where, at 85, he continues to live.

title: Christies Opens for Business in Mainland China With Its First Auction
description: SHANGHAI  Christies held its first auction in mainland China Thursday, a modest affair by international standards that brought $24.9 million for 39 paintings, sculpture, jewelry, watches, and wine.

title: A Peaceful Voyage
description: ON a crisp, sunny fall day at the Millers Launch shipyard on Staten Island, a crew of shipbuilders from Manchester, England, was putting the finishing touches on a boat called The Ship of Tolerance. All that was missing was its sail: a collage of about 150 paintings executed not by the celebrated married artists who conceived of this wooden vessel,  Ilya and Emilia Kabakov, but by scores of local schoolchildren charged with expressing its message of acceptance and understanding. The aesthetic was decidedly primary-color happy, with rainbows, smiley faces, multihued people holding hands and carefully lettered imperatives like Peace on Earth.

title: Feeling For | A Reed Krakoff Clutch that Travels Well
description: My wife is very organized, but too many times Ive watched her dig deep into her handbag for travel documents at the airport. I thought it would be great to make a document pouch for her. It slips nicely into a handbag, and it can double as a chic clutch. $490; reedkrakoff.com.

title: Not O.K.
description: Several years ago David Finkel, a reporter for The Washington Post and a 2012 MacArthur fellow, wrote what might be thought of as a post-heroic Iliad for the Iraq war. Now, in Thank You for Your Service, he has written an equally cogent Odyssey.

title: The Botany of Desire
description: My most influential college course began with an assignment from the Book of Genesis: we read the two different creation stories that coexist there. If we wanted a secondary source to explain lifes existence, the professor said, we were free to spend extracurricular angst reconciling those conflicting reports. But hereafter in class, as scientists, we would look to life itself as primary source. As for the organisms in our purview, his credo was: It takes a superior mind to appreciate a plant. By superior I believe he meant uncommonly patient. Plants do everything animals do, but slowly. They migrate, communicate, deceive, stalk their food and, with an ostentation of styles and perfumes to put the animal kingdom to shame, they make love. Its just that catching them in flagrante delicto might require time-lapse photography.

title: This Is Only a Test
description: Over the past 20 years, a rising tide of voices in the world of public policy has been telling us that public education has fallen into an abyss of mediocrity. Our schools are broken, the mantra goes. Principals and teachers  their lack of rigor and low expectations for their students  are the primary offenders. The problem can be fixed only if schools are held to strict accountability. No excuses are to be permitted.

title: For City Opera, the Talk Turns to a Shutdown
description: It may very well be all over for New York City Opera after the buxom lady sings.

title: Give Children a Chance to Lose  and Win
description: How many participation trophies and medals do you have displayed in your home or discarded somewhere in the mud room? Weve got assorted skiing and soccer medals, hockey trophies, and certificates of achievement galore, and now is perhaps a good time to say that of my four sports-playing children, only one has ever really won something, because only one is old enough to have ever really competed  and he has lost far more often than he has won.

title: Gerard Mortier Named Artistic Adviser of Teatro Real Opera House in Madrid

title: Hold the Russian Vodka: Great Comet Producers in Protest Against Anti-Gay Bias

The action is meant as a protest against recent instances of bias and violence against gay people in Russia, according to the producers, Howard and Janet Kagan. In addition, they are donating $10,000 to Human Rights Watch, which has been trying to combat antigay bias in Russia; the producers will also donate revenue from all food and drink sales at the Friday performance and party afterward.

title: Plucking Sounds From South American Skies
description: On Wednesday night, Alan Gilbert conducted his fifth opening gala concert as the music director of the New York Philharmonic. You would think that devising a program for this occasion would be easy. But there are conflicting imperatives at work, and Mr. Gilbert has never quite gotten the balance right.

title: With Tastes Growing Healthier, McDonalds Aims to Adapt Its Menu

title: A Republics Last Stand, Sublimely Sketched
description: Venice in the 18th century was a city of highs and lows, a flourishing art capital that happened to be in the late stages of a long political decline. A new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum captures something of the wild, up-and-down nature of life during the last gasp of the Venetian Republic.

description: Young Southern women flocked to the New Orleans classrooms of the Newcomb Art School in the early 1900s to learn how to mold clay teacups, carve vases, embroider tablecloths and hammer silver chalices. The results of their grueling work at the school, which was part of Tulane University, appealed to tastemakers like Louis Comfort Tiffany, museum curators and retail distributors from Boston to Los Angeles, and they ended up in elite collections.

Italy-born and Philadelphia-bred, Mr. Auriemma loves Italian cooking, and with Genos Grille, his restaurant in Storrs Center, a glossy new mixed-use development next to the main campus, he has set out to present Italian food the way it used to be, as he put it on the phone after my visits.

Artists came to scrutinize and protest the very conditions and institutions under which art is produced, and married the aesthetic charge of their performances to forthright political action.

description: Sting told a choice anecdote near the close of his concert at the Public Theater on Wednesday night, reaching back to his boyhood in an English shipbuilding town. It was the day of a launching, he recalled, and amid the festive pomp, a Rolls-Royce cruised down the street, bearing the queen. Planted curbside with his mother in his Sunday best, frantically waving a little Union Jack, he was certain that Her Majesty spotted him.

title: Headbanging After Therapy
description: The last time I saw them in my professional capacity as a film critic, the members of Metallica were in therapy, working out their issues in the fascinating documentary Metallica: Some Kind of Monster. Nearly 10 years later, they seem to be doing well. Metallica Through the Never, a new concert film directed by Nimrod Antal (Kontroll, Predators), shows the band  three decades after the release of its first album  in vigorous middle age. Lars Ulrich, the drummer, is still a kinetic master of tricky time signatures, and his partner, the singer James Hetfield, bellows with undiminished authority. The fans, chanting along and giving devil-horn salutes, are as passionate as ever.

title: U.N. Deal on Syrian Arms Is Milestone After Years of Inertia
description: UNITED NATIONS  The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have agreed on a resolution that will require Syria to give up its chemical weapons, but there will be no automatic penalties if the Syrians fail to comply, officials said Thursday.

title: Celebrating the Eclectic, the New, the Joyous
description: An old-fashioned but excellent line of thought proposes that dance is singularly and naturally equipped to express joy. Let other emotions be conveyed by other body movements or other arts, but dance and joy go together, wedded by high energy and continuous, ebullient rhythm.

title: For Cicely Tyson and Kerry Washington, Roles of a Lifetime
description: It was the meal where nobody ate. On a recent Sunday morning, Cicely Tyson and Kerry Washington  one an Oscar nominee in 1972 for Sounder and a Tony Award winner this year for A Trip to Bountiful (which ends its Broadway run Oct. 9), the other a 2013 Emmy nominee for Scandal and a newlywed after her marriage this summer to the San Francisco 49ers cornerback Nnamdi Asomugha  met for brunch in the dining room of the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side. As soon as Miss Tyson entered the room and greeted Ms. Washington with a tight embrace and the words Dont get up, dont you dare get up to their third table companion, the two began an animated, breakneck conversation about race, role models, overcoming parental disapproval and why Olivia Pope wears so much white.

title: Visual Artists, Choosing to Play by Ear
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.  THE first thing you see when you walk into the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum is a 13-foot-wide poster of six men, mostly middle-aged and overweight, in coveralls and baseball caps. They are fans of the country singer Merle Haggard and were photographed by the British artist James Mollison at a concert in Huntsville, Ala., in 2006 as part of The Disciples, his series showing fans of 59 pop groups.

title: Rallying to Keep the Game Alive
description: When I took up tennis, my husband was happy to play with our two children and me, as long as we didnt have to play by the rules. As Denis repeatedly explained to us, playing by the rules placed him at an unfair disadvantage because he didnt know the rules, and he didnt know how to serve.

title: Uninsured Americans Divided on Impact of Health Care Law
description: Less than a week before the health insurance marketplaces established by the 2010 health care law begin accepting customers, a New York Times/CBS News poll has found that there is some support among uninsured Americans for President Obama and his law, but also a wariness and a lack of understanding about what the law will mean for them.

title: Love, Forbidden and Persecuted
description: I dont care about the Jews, the Palestinians, Fatah or Hamas, Nimr (Nicholas Jacob), a closeted gay Palestinian, declares to his thuggish older brother, Nabil (Jameel Khouri), in Out in the Dark.

title: Citing New Evidence, Urging a Posthumous Pardon in 1992 Case
description: Armed with what it says is new evidence of wrongdoing in the prosecution of Cameron Todd Willingham, the Innocence Project on Friday will ask Gov. Rick Perry to order the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles to investigate whether the state should posthumously pardon Mr. Willingham, whose 2004 execution has become a lightning rod of controversy over the Texas justice system.

title: Carrying Debt After Retirement
description: If college debt is a hindrance to young adults, mortgage debt is the drag on homeowners heading into retirement.

title: Infatuations, Female and Feline
description: The French painter who called himself Balthus was infatuated with his mediums rich history and with girls. He painted alluring, disturbing pictures of nubile adolescents more than he painted anything else, making images that conjured Courbet, Ingres, Piero della Francesca and Seurat and were charged with suggestive undercurrents. Occasionally he included cats in these scenes, increasing their erotic frisson.

title: Theres More Than Meets the Eye
description: Oh, no, I thought when I heard that the Museum of Modern Arts big fall show was a Ren Magritte survey. Dozens of undersung modernist painters, many of them women, on at least five continents, have never had a New York moment, and here were getting an artist we practically cant avoid. The pipe; the giant eye; the choo-choo in the fireplace.

title: At Midterm, Every Campaign Is About Obama
description: Texas Democrats are trying to put together a ticket to run against the Republicans in 2014. But Texas Republicans dont care whose names appear on the other ballot; they already know the name of the candidate theyre running against:

title: The Hits Flowed From a Famous Studio
description: If you want to bob your head along to a jukebox sampler of glorious American songs, then Muscle Shoals is the documentary for you. But if you want to learn how the area near the small Alabama city of Muscle Shoals, which hugs the south bank of the Tennessee River, became a renowned music center  the place where Percy Sledges Civil Rights-era chartbuster When a Man Loves a Woman was born and where Aretha Franklin poured sweat and tears into I Never Loved a Man (the Way I Love You)  then you will need to look and listen elsewhere.

title: Plenty of Jobs, Not Enough Shelter
description: An oil boom is creating a strain on housing in small towns across the western part of North Dakota.

description: Stephan Stoyanov Gallery

description: Paula Cooper Gallery

description: CRG Gallery

description: KnowMoreGames

title: Its Not the Rare Birds They Mind So Much. Its the Watchdogs.
description: LUBBOCK  An odd-looking grouse with an intricate mating dance is at the center of an intense battle over wildlife conservation among energy companies, Texas officials and environmental advocates and the federal government.

title: Brian Adam Douglas: How to Disappear Completely
description: Andrew Edlin 134 10th Avenue, near 18th Street,

title: Rock the Bells Festival Cancels Remaining Shows
description: Promoters of the Rock the Bells hip-hop festival have canceled two shows in Washington this weekend and two in the New York City area next weekend because of lackluster ticket sales.

description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: The Traditional (and Inner) Rhythms of Kabul
description: In We Came Home, Ariana Delawari documents her fathers role in helping his home country, Afghanistan, modernize its financial system after the fall of the Taliban. But this intimate film, Ms. Delawaris first, is about so much more: her familys history (seen in home movies and photographs), the resilience of the Afghan people, and her own story of self-discovery as a musician.

description: Images from a new Balthus exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Enrollment to Be Delayed for Small-Business Marketplaces
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Thursday announced another minor delay in the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, saying that the insurance marketplaces for small businesses would be fully open for enrollment a month later than it had planned.

title: Its More Than Whats for Dinner
description: If the director Jim Mickle has a signature style, its to approach horror and hideousness with the elegiac rhythms and lyrical imagery of the best westerns, his mournful tone suggesting deep empathy for his disturbed characters. So when he took on Jorge Michel Graus marvelous 2011 creep-out, We Are What We Are, he didnt so much remake as reimagine. Retaining the title but moving the action from Mexico City to the Catskills, Mr. Mickle transforms a politically charged allegory of social decay into a dreamy commentary on the ravages of extreme religious observance.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Minister Admits Overstating Her Credentials
description: A Methodist minister who resigned her pulpit last year after deciding that she was no longer a believer, and who was recently hired by a humanist group based at Harvard to help build congregations of nonbelievers throughout the country, has acknowledged fabricating aspects of her educational background.

title: Dance Listings for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Mystery of the Ordinary
description: A look at the Ren Magritte survey at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Free-Range Herds, in the Broadest Sense
description: Cattle drives in westerns have taught moviegoers the beauty of the herd, a rippling organic mass spreading across the landscape like a bestial cloud. The documentary Hiver Nomade (Winter Nomads) shares that sense of peace as it shadows two French shepherds wrangling and coaxing their 800 sheep in search of green pasture across the snow-covered Swiss countryside.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Rick Owens Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: A Nuptial Curse in the Finest Korean-American Tradition
description: The romantic comedy Wedding Palace, Christine Yoos feature directing debut, is swimming in color, clichs and stereotypes, recalling Baz Luhrmanns Strictly Ballroom and other films of that highly stylized ilk. While the story is a bit weak, the film does a good job of contrasting Korean-Americans who steadfastly adhere to the traditions of their homeland with South Koreans who have renounced old customs.

title: Spare Times for Children for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
description: The Medieval Festival

title: From Korea With Love
description: Can you imagine what James Bond would do with Google Glass? Hed probably use his specs to undress young women digitally while also rescuing the free world. The secret agent in the new South Korean film The Spy: Undercover Operation instead uses modern gadgets like this to monitor his wife. In many ways this action-comedy is similar to Roger Moore-era Bond films, but with a henpecked husband instead of a playboy as the hero.

title: Pakistani General Attacked in Quake Zone
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Militants on Thursday shot two rockets at a helicopter carrying the Pakistani general in charge of disaster relief for the devastating earthquake this week, officials said.

title: Spare Times for Sept. 27-Oct. 3
description: Swingin With the All Stars: Louis Armstrong & Baseball (closes on Sunday) Local baseball fans disappointed by the playoff elimination of the Mets and the Yankees can still find something to cheer about with this exhibition at the Louis Armstrong House Museum, 34-56 107th Street, Corona, Queens. A devoted baseball fan  he followed the Dodgers and the Mets and had ties to the Yankees  Armstrong also had a special interest in a sandlot team in New Orleans, which he named Armstrongs Secret 9. So devoted was he that he bought the teams uniforms and equipment.

title: Texas Davis Is Expected to Enter Race for Governor
description: HOUSTON  Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator whose filibuster in June against an abortion bill backed by the states powerful Republicans catapulted her to national political prominence, has told supporters and potential donors that she plans to announce next week that she will run for governor, according to Democrats in Texas and Washington.

title: Mariano Rivera, Center Fielder
description: Mariano Rivera will pitch one last time in Yankee Stadium on Thursday, and it could be the last relief appearance of his 19-year career. With the Yankees eliminated from the postseason, Rivera could accomplish one more thing in the final three games of the season against the Houston Astros: playing center field.

title: Little Girl at the Center of Spooky Mayhem
description: Part revenge fantasy, part psychological horror, Dark Touch owes something to the writings of Stephen King and even more to the jaggedly atmospheric cinematography of John Conroy (who worked most recently on the British television series Luther and Silk). Wielding his camera with jumpy precision, Mr. Conroy infuses even chaotic motion with stabilizing elegance.

title: Alienated, From His First Day in the U.S.A.
description: As Ibrahim, the unflappably upbeat and disastrously unlucky Lebanese immigrant at the center of The Citizen, the Egyptian actor Khaled Nabawy is invaluable. Resembling a duskier Benjamin Bratt, Mr. Nabawy adds much-needed weight and authenticity to a character whose cascade of misfortunes threatens to turn drama into farce at every moment.

title: Birthday Gift Comes With Unusual Attachments
description: In the French comedy Htel Normandy, Alice, a widow of five years with no interest in another love, is given a 40th-birthday gift by her girlfriends at the bank where they work: a stay at a luxe resort in Deauville during its art biennale. What her chums dont say is that they have also arranged for a man to romance her. (No professional escort, mind you, just a client who owes a favor.)

title: Fighting for a Cats Right to Scratch
description: The innocuous title may create the impression that The Paw Project is a cutesy compilation of YouTube cat videos, but its actually a heartfelt documentary about a subject that inflames cat lovers everywhere: declawing.

title: Finding a Suitable Match for a School Nerd
description: Theres no way to prepare yourself for how awful The Secret Lives of Dorks is.

title: Ray Charles Songs, Mason Jars and Mussels
description: Had I known that Tuesday was all-you-can-eat mussels night at Park and Sixth, I never would have dined there then. I like mussels but not enough to visit on an evening when mussels, along with items from the lunch menu, are served in place of the larger dinner menu.

title: Chasm Between the Very Rich and Everybody Else
description: The concentration of our countrys wealth among the very rich has gone from being an unsettling factoid to a rallying cry, and Jacob Kornbluths Inequality for All hands the bullhorn to Robert Reich, the labor secretary under President Bill Clinton. Rather than through a harangue or a lament, Mr. Reich ties together his talking points with a reasonable-sounding analysis and an unassuming warmth sometimes absent from documentaries charting Americas economic woes.

title: Paris Doesnt Need a Sideshow
description: PARIS  None of the big names on the bill for the opening of the Paris spring shows is French. Theres Jun Takahashi of Undercover (Tokyo), Alexander Wang of Balenciaga (New York) and Dries Van Noten (Antwerp). Rick Owens has lived in Paris for years, but we Americans still claim him as a California guy.

title: The Broker-Free Sale
description: With inventory hitting new lows, the housing market in New York City has taken a dramatic turn in favor of sellers. Buyers face fewer options and stiffer competition. And that can get homeowners thinking about the value of their increasingly expensive broker.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Nostalgia Burns Bright in a City Renewed
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  This city of contemporary buildings recalls a mini-Dubai, but is planted in the middle of the Asian steppe and mixes cutting-edge architecture with traditional pastimes.

title: Senators Push to Preserve N.S.A. Phone Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Intelligence Committee appears to be moving toward swift passage of a bill that would change but preserve the once-secret National Security Agency program that is keeping logs of every Americans phone calls, Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who leads the panel, said Thursday.

title: Virginia Dwans Big Gift to the National Gallery
description: Since the late 1960s, the dealer and philanthropist Virginia Dwan has quietly donated art to museums all over the country. Among her gifts are Duchamps famed L.H.O.O.Q., a reproduction of the Mona Lisa with a mustache and beard in pencil, which has gone to the Norton Simon Museum in Los Angeles, and Double Negative, one of Michael Heizers monumental pieces of land art in Nevada, which she has given to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. Ms. Dwan also donated six photographic images by Mr. Heizer to the Whitney Museum of American Art, and works by Robert Smithson and Sol LeWitt to the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

title: Judge Orders Pay for Illinois Lawmakers
description: CHICAGO  A Cook County judge, in a ruling made public Thursday, held that Gov. Pat Quinns order this summer to withhold state legislators wages was unconstitutional.

title: Mayoral Rivals Entangled in Debate on Citys Rules for a Circumcision Rite
description: There are the predictable issues facing the candidates running for mayor of New York: jobs, education, crime.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: A Promising Start at Air Products
description: Activist investor William A. Ackman has quickly dislodged Air Products and Chemicals underperforming boss, John McGlade. The win brought him a sharp gain of $100 million on his 10 percent holding in the natural gas firm as investors initially reacted to the news.

title: New Yorks Air Is Cleanest in 50 Years, Survey Finds
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday that his administrations efforts at reducing air pollution had resulted in New York Citys having the best air quality in more than 50 years.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Italy: Bones Found Amid Shipwreck
description: Divers involved in the recovery of the cruise ship Costa Concordia found several bones on the seabed on Thursday, but the authorities cautioned that DNA tests would be necessary to determine whether they were the remains of the last two unrecovered bodies from the shipwreck that killed 32 people last year. The search for the two missing victims resumed Monday, a week after the capsized ship was righted during a complex salvage operation 20 months after the liner crashed into two granite reefs just off the tiny Tuscan island of Giglio. Experts have yet to go inside the parts of the ship that remained submerged for months after the shipwreck in January 2012. The captain, Francesco Schettino, went on trial this month on charges of multiple manslaughter, causing a shipwreck and abandoning the vessel before all of the ships 4,229 passengers and crew members were safe.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: As Merkel Is Showered in Glory, Hollande Trudges Through Drizzle
description: PARIS  It has been a hard week to be Franois Hollande.

title: Unlikely Debate on Gay Rights in California Town
description: PORTERVILLE, Calif.  The mayor of Porterville did not give it much thought when a local gay activist in this remote Central Valley farming town asked her to proclaim June a month of gay pride. But when the mayor, Virginia R. Gurrola, settled into her seat at City Hall to sign the proclamation, people were pouring out of the chambers and into the hallways, citing Scripture in opposition to what she had thought of as a simple ceremonial gesture. Her four fellow City Council members announced they would not join her in signing the document.

title: Panthers Hope for Fresh Phase With New Owners
description: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  It was 90 degrees outside as the Florida Panthers skated through training camp drills at their practice rink this week. Such temperatures are common here during the season, which, according to some theories, is why the Panthers have been so bad for so long, and why so many N.H.L. careers came here to die.

title: S.E.C. Sues Former Chairman in Looting of Educational Company
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday accused the former chief executive and chairman of an American-listed Chinese education company of stealing $41 million from investors.

title: Chile Hunt for Justice Winds Up as Enigma
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The Chilean courts have long been after Ray E. Davis, a former American Navy captain, accusing him of being involved in the murder of two Americans decades ago that inspired the award-winning 1982 film Missing.

title: Time-Shifted Viewing, Plans for Las Vegas and Bossy Little Girls
description: HERE is a look at highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the 10th annual Advertising Week, which took place this week in New York.

title: Republicans Facing a Test of Unity
description: WASHINGTON  As the Congressional showdown over President Obamas health care law threatens to shut down the government, conservative advocacy groups have emerged as central players  exerting outsize influence, investing tremendous time and resources, and turning the long-shot budget fight into a do-or-die battle that has pitted Republicans against one another.

title: Reporting Irans News, but Speaking for One Side
description: TEHRAN  So there was Irans semiofficial Fars News Agency, once the dedicated defender of the Israel-bashing, Holocaust-denying former Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, being singled out for praise on Thursday by The Wall Street Journals staunchly conservative, Israel-defending, Iran-distrusting editorial page.

title: Why Conservatives Should Reread Milton Friedman
description: Its easy to think that our continuing impasses over the federal budget stem from deep differences in principle between conservatives and progressives over the role of capitalist enterprises in our society. Progressives favor substantial constraints, through taxation and other sorts of regulation, whereas conservatives think that, as Milton Friedman put it in his classic Capitalism and Freedom, there is one and only one social responsibility of business  to use its resources and engage in activities designed to increase its profits. But if we look more deeply into Friedmans view, the difference between his conservative economics and progressive views shrinks considerably.

title: Fishless in Seattle
description: SEATTLE  Not long ago, dispirited by national politics mired in mean and a hopeless hometown baseball team, I sought a long days refuge in the natural world. But it was not a frozen flank of Mount Rainier or an island in the inland sea that gave me the break I was looking for. It was an overcrowded perch in the heart of a metro area of nearly three million people.

title: Have a Nice Day, N.S.A.
description: AT the opening of the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, Dilma Rousseff, the president of my country, Brazil, delivered a scolding speech in response to reports that the National Security Agency has monitored electronic communications of Brazilian citizens, members of government and private corporations. Like a displeased school principal, Ms. Rousseff seemed to speak directly to President Obama, who was waiting in the wings to deliver his own speech.

title: My State Needs Obamacare. Now.
description: FRANKFORT, Ky.  SUNDAY morning news programs identify Kentucky as the red state with two high-profile Republican senators who claim their rhetoric represents an electorate that gave President Obama only about a third of its presidential vote in 2012.

title: Is Obamacare Working?
Massachusetts: Fishery Group Limits Herring Catch
description: The New England Fishery Management Councilon Thursdayapproved the regions first cap on the amount of river herring that can be caught by industrial trawlers. According to the rules, which must be approved and put into place by the National Marine Fisheries Service, the Atlantic herring fleet can incidentally catch no more than 311.4 metric tons of river herring and shad. The cap, which is the median of what managers estimate it caught over the past five years, will be implemented by zone and gear type. River herring and shad, whose populations are at historic lows, spend part of their lives at sea and run up rivers to spawn; hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent on dam removal projects to foster a revival of the runs, but fishermen and conservationists have long warned the species also need protection at sea. The council also discussed the National Marine Fisheries Services decision this summer not to implement all of the measures the council approved last year to protect Atlantic herring, citing funding issues; the group tabled a motion to prohibit midwater trawling in the region until those rules are put into place.

title: Another 100-Loss Year, but Astros Have Hope
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  You might think that Manager Bo Porter, after watching his Houston Astros stagger to 108 losses, might enjoy some time away from the team this winter. The Astros, whose season mercifully ends at home against the Yankees this weekend, have set a franchise record for defeats.

title: Whose Cheatin Heart Came First?
description: Sometimes a war has a clear culprit: Paris takes Helen to Troy; Japan bombs Pearl Harbor. But when it comes to what we used to call the battle of the sexes, its not easy to fix the blame. Leave it to the 18th-century French playwright Pierre Carlet de Chamblain de Marivaux to give it a go in La Dispute, the entertaining 70-minute comedy that opened Hartford Stages 50th anniversary season last week.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 26, 2013
Answers to Readers Questions About Job Hunting
description: The Times invited readers to ask Eilene Zimmerman, a Youre the Boss blogger, questions about job hunting. Ms. Zimmerman wrote The Timess Career Couch column for six years. This Q&A is part of How I Hire, a LinkedIn Influencer feature in which The Timess Business section is participating.

title: What Irans President Said, Is Said to Have Said and Says He Said
description: In an interview with Charlie Rose of CBS News broadcast on Thursday, Irans new president, Hassan Rouhani, rejected accusations that he had not clearly acknowledged the historical reality of the Holocaust in remarks to CNN earlier this week.

title: Answers to Readers Questions About Hiring the Right Candidate
description: The Times invited readers who work as managers or own their own businesses to ask Jay Goltz, a columnist for Youre the Boss, questions about hiring. Mr. Goltz employs more than 100 people at his five Chicago businesses. This Q&A is part of How I Hire, a LinkedIn Influencer feature in which The Timess Business section is participating.

title: Bosss Kindness Repaid With a Burst of Violence
description: It was at church where John Choi met the man accused of shooting him.

title: The Cup May Stay, but Theres No Going Back on Speed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The future of the Americas Cup was one victory from becoming Emirates Team New Zealands responsibility: one victory from returning to New Zealand, with the Italian team Luna Rossa Challenge expected to be its challenger of record.

title: Sudan Erupts in Deadly Protests as Gas Prices Rise
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  This time, it was not the organizing by activists on Facebook and Twitter that made people take to the streets in such numbers. They did not need it. The anger was already widespread enough.

title: Rabbi Linked to Kickback Scheme at Charity
description: In August, the board of one of New York Citys most respected social services organizations drew widespread attention when it fired its executive director, William E. Rapfogel, because it believed he had been taking large kickbacks from its insurance broker.

title: JPMorgan Urged to Pay More in Mortgage Deal
description: The Justice Department is moving closer to striking a multibillion-dollar settlement with JPMorgan Chase over questionable mortgage practices, after authorities urged the bank to raise its offer and the banks chief executive took the rare step of meeting with Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in Washington to discuss the deal.

title: Food Stamp Regression in the Statehouse
description: While Congress is making up its mind on how much to slash from the food stamp program, some states are moving on their own to punish the poor by changing eligibility and other rules governing food stamps in ways that could deny vital assistance to needy people.

title: Some Progress on Syria
description: The resolution to rid Syria of its chemical weapons, agreed to by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, is a useful, if imperfect, step toward a credible international response to a bloody war that has killed more than 100,000 Syrians.

title: A Republican Ransom Note
description: On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew sent the House a very serious warning that, for the first time, the United States would be unable to pay its bills beginning on Oct. 17 if the debt ceiling is not lifted. House leaders responded on Thursday with one of the least serious negotiating proposals in modern Congressional history: a jaw-dropping list of ransom demands containing more than a dozen discredited Republican policy fantasies.

title: Prison-Based Gerrymandering
description: The Census Bureau has steadfastly resisted calls to end the practice of counting inmates as residents of their prisons instead of the cities and towns where they lived and to which they typically return. The bureaus new director, John Thompson, seems at least open to ending this wrongful practice.

title: James van Sweden Dies at 78; His Designs Urged Lawns to Grow
description: James van Sweden, an influential landscape architect who drew inspiration from the grand masters of painting to create vivid, naturalistic landscapes that seemed to explode with grasses and wildflowers, died last Friday at his home in Washington. He was 78.

title: Plutocrats Feeling Persecuted
description: Robert Benmosche, the chief executive of the American International Group, said something stupid the other day. And we should be glad, because his comments help highlight an important but rarely discussed cost of extreme income inequality  namely, the rise of a small but powerful group of what can only be called sociopaths.

title: $300 Million in Detroit Aid, but No Bailout
description: WASHINGTON  Two months after Detroit became the largest city ever to file for bankruptcy, top Obama administration officials will be there on Friday to propose nearly $300 million in combined federal and private aid toward a Motown comeback  only a fraction of the billions the city owes and a reflection of the budget and political limits on President Obama.

title: Iranian President Softens Condemnation of Holocaust
description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran appeared to walk his condemnation of the Holocaust back a notch on Thursday, one day after he provoked a politically fraught uproar in the United States and at home with a qualified castigation of one of historys best-documented genocides.

title: 19 Are Charged in a Plot to Cheat on Commercial Drivers License Tests
description: They wanted to drive school buses or trucks with heavy loads but had not passed the commercial drivers license exam. So these would-be drivers tapped into a network of cheats who used secret codes to provide answers to test-takers in exam rooms where security guards were bribed to look the other way, according to a complaint filedon Wednesdayin Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Swimmer Is Fighting a Ruling: She Is Not Disabled Enough
description: EXETER, N.H.  Racked by sudden spasms in her shoulders, back and hands  the things she most relies upon to offset her paralyzed legs  the American swimmer Victoria Arlen failed to qualify for the final in the 100-meter breaststroke at the Paralympics last summer. But she persevered in the freestyle, going on to become one of the competitions breakout stars. When Arlen returned home to New Hampshire with four medals and a world record, Exeter threw her a parade.

title: Wounded by Broken Memories
description: How can something be this delicate and this strong, so elusive and yet so tenacious? That question radiates from John Tiffanys stunning production of Tennessee Williamss Glass Menagerie, which opened on Thursday night at the Booth Theater and promises to be the most revealing revival of a cornerstone classic for many a year to come.

And the collective minds of the constructor, Will Shortz and Frank Longo, who helps Will with some of the grid fixes.

One by one, each team went up, announced its pick and placed a sticker with the picks name on the board. It was an ordeal, and now the board is on display in the teams training room.

They warned that the target is likely to be exceeded in a matter of decades unless steps are taken soon to reduce emissions.

title: In Store | A New York Flagship for the Maker of the Ultimate American Motorcycle Jacket
description: The Perfecto, a zippered leather motorcycle jacket with a distinctive single star stud on each epaulet (it is sometimes referred to as the One Star), might be the most iconic piece of American outerwear there is. Bruce Springsteen, the Ramones, Andy Warhol, the Beastie Boys and Lady Gaga have all worn the jacket, which was invented by the American outerwear manufacturer Schott NYC. James Dean wore his everywhere, helping get the jacket banned in some American high schools for its rebellious connotations. But nobody is more identified with the garment than Marlon Brando, who paired his with faded Levis and a scowl in The Wild One.

title: A Stranger on Lenox Avenue
description: On the evening of Sept. 21, Prabhjot Singh, an assistant professor in the International and Public Affairs program at Columbia University in New York and the co-director of a community health care program in Harlem, was walking near his house in Harlem. Mr. Singh is a Sikh man of Indian origin and wears a long flowing beard and a turban. Around 8 p.m., a group of young black men on bicycles confronted Mr. Singh on Lenox Avenue and shouted racist slurs at him, shouting, get Osama and terrorist. The young men proceeded to punch his face and upper body.

title: A Move for the Essex Street Market
description: Theres a point at which even the most emphatic preservationist must acknowledge the indulgence of nostalgia. Not every building is in every instance worth saving; not every vanished way of life is worth enshrining. If you believe that cities ought to maximize their options for affordable living space rather than accommodate the best-off, then arguments for keeping things as they are often remain incompatible with arguments for how things ought to be. And yet, mourning is so often the reflex that overcomes us, whenever we hear that a certain patch of land in New York will dramatically alter, a certain structure will go to dust.

description: The panel of experts unveiled its latest assessment of climate research, reinforcing its earlier conclusions that global warming is real and that it is caused primarily if not exclusively by man-made emissions.

description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland agreed on Friday to sell a stake in its branch network for 600 million, or $966 million, to a consortium of investors led by Corsair Capital and Centerbridge Partners.
