description: Last Saturday, Michael McDuffee had his first beer since 1994. It was a cold beer, refreshing. It was a long time coming.

title: In Ratings War, G.M.A. Beats Today for Full Season
description: As he pushed Good Morning America through a heated ratings competition with NBCs Today show, Ben Sherwood, the president of ABC News, had three goals: first, to win just one week; second, to win one of the television industrys so-called sweeps months; and third, to win for a full television season. He called it the trifecta in conversations with colleagues.

title: Judging an Actor by His Cover
description: Perhaps it was audacious of James Franco to co-write, direct and star in an adaptation of William Faulkners fractured classic As I Lay Dying. But Francos real gumption, it seems, came when he appeared alone on the cover of the movie tie-in edition of the book. The Time Out New York film critic Keith Uhlich brought the cover to wide attention on Twitter, where he posted an exasperated expletive along with a photo of the book and his own agonized, palm-covered face. Nearly 350 people retweeted Uhlichs image, one of them writing: At least they didnt change the title to As I, James Franco, Lay Dying.

title: Debut Novels
description: THE MEASURES BETWEEN USBy Ethan Hauser  Bloomsbury, $26.

title: Inside the List
description: Captain Kleenex: If you had to guess which novelist would be first to team up with the P.B.R.  thats Professional Bull Riders Inc., as if you didnt know  you might not put your money on Nicholas Sparks. The best-selling author of Hollywood-friendly love stories like The Notebook and Message in a Bottle, Sparks is so reliable a tear-jerker that one Irish newspaper reviewed his latest book under the evergreen headline A New Weepie From Captain Kleenex. But the book in question, The Longest Ride  which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1  happens to feature a cowboy in one of its two romantic plotlines: Bull riders, a character realizes early on, oozed sex appeal. So this summer the P.B.R. announced a cross-marketing effort to promote both the book and the sport. Nick did an awesome, awesome job, Ellen Newberg, the groups vice president of event marketing, told me. The depiction of professional bull riding and, clearly, the amount of research he did, its amazing. The story is very relatable to what actually happens on the tour.

title: Editors Choice
description: DOCTOR SLEEP,  by Stephen King. (Scribner, $30.) Now grown up, Danny, the boy with psycho-intuitive powers in The Shining, helps another threatened magic child in a novel that shares the virtues of Kings best work.

title: Paperback Row
description: SPILLOVER: Animal Infections and the Next Human Pandemic,  by David Quammen. (Norton, $16.95.) Sixty percent of the infections that plague humankind  influenza, H.I.V. and Lyme disease, to name a few  are zoonoses, which jump from wildlife to humans. Quammens sprawling scientific adventure tracks these diseases from the jungles of Central Africa to the rooftops of Bangladesh and the caves of southern China, and warns that such crossovers are bound to occur with more frequency, and possibly greater virulence.

title: Family Compounds, by Elevator
description: Some parents dream of owning a home where their adult children and grandchildren also can live. For those with the means, that translates into a family compound, with several generations living in their own houses within the same property line. But here in New York City, creating such expansive homes can be prohibitively expensive. Nevertheless, a lucky few are building multigenerational compounds in the sky.

title: Young Catcher Can Help Tell Ending to Riveras Story
description: The young man who caught Mariano Riveras final pitches at Yankee Stadium was born the year after Rivera made his debut in the minor leagues. John Ryan Murphy, known as J. R., No. 66 in your Yankees program, grew up a Red Sox fan in Bradenton, Fla., though he came of rooting age when the Yankees and Rivera owned major league baseball.

title: TV Talk: The Fall Season
description: Bill Carter and Brian Stelter, reporters at The New York Times, assess the latest offerings by television networks to score primetime hits in the fall season.

title: Burden of Proofing
description: Will nobody cut Rannie Bookman some slack? Her mother constantly judges her. (Your sisters never find dead bodies!) Her teenage son, Nate, is just as faultfinding. (What are you, some kind of corpse magnet?) Even Rannies new lover, a strapping ex-cop named Tim, has the nerve to tell her how to live her life. (Youre not Nancy Drew. Youre a copy editor. Stick to that.) How dare they all rebuke her! Then again, might they have a point? Theres a coldblooded killer on the loose in Manhattan, a criminal whos fed up with Rannies meddling ways and whose criticism may come at the edge of a knife. If she doesnt watch it, curiosity just might kill the copy editor.

title: Senior Moments
description: In Lucinella, an eccentric little novel published in 1976, Lore Segals title character, a writer, confesses: Im no good at plotting. What I love is to get right down to the excruciations.

title: Bitter Fruit
description: In 1976, Dr. D. Carleton Gajdusek won a Nobel Prize for identifying a fatal disease in a remote tribe in Papua New Guinea. By the time of his death in 2008, Gajdusek had achieved another kind of notoriety, having been imprisoned for sexually abusing one of the dozens of native children he had adopted. Hanya Yanagiharas suspenseful first novel, The People in the Trees, is based loosely on this true story, with a number of horrifying twists. From the start, she sets her narrative dial to creepy, and challenges to the extreme the notion that a protagonist needs to be likable. Yet thanks to her rich, masterly prose, its hard to turn away from Dr. Norton Perina, her antihero inspired by Gajdusek. Some might say hes a sociopath, and not even the charming kind (see Tom Ripley).

title: Crosscurrents
description: A few miles up the road from my home, on a sandy beach in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu, there is a crumbling fort that extends into the Bay of Bengal. The fort was built in the 17th century; over the years, it has been controlled by Mughal rulers from the north, by the French and by the British. Farther down the coast, past a string of fishing villages, sits the former French colony of Pondicherry, its wide boulevards and elegant villas overlooking the shimmering waters of the bay. A few miles away is an ancient Roman trading outpost. And two and a half hours beyond sits the former Danish port town of Tranquebar, its yellow fort blending into the sand, its rusty cannons pointing at the ocean.

title: A Sea Lion Cuts A Rug
description: Fine rum and chocolate, mmm. Conan the Barbarian vs. Conan OBrien.

title: The 9.15.13 Issue
The Apocalypse Market Is Booming
description: When I was a kid, one of my first literary obsessions was the 1953 sci-fi classic Childhoods End, by Arthur C. Clarke. As the novel opens, a race of aliens called the Overlords has appeared. Rather than decimating humankind, they foster unprecedented peace and prosperity. Only decades later does their true purpose emerge: to recruit Earths children into a single cosmic entity called the Overmind, which represents the summed consciousness of all the civilizations in the universe. What begins as a utopian collaboration ends with the planet itself evaporating in a pulse of light.

title: Correcting the Crackpot Next Door
description: I frequently encounter scientific evidence misused and misinterpreted to advance ideological viewpoints. As a scientist, what is my ethical obligation to confront pseudoscience and antiscience attitudes? Is there a difference in how I should engage relatives, co-workers or the Internet community? AMY HENRY,CHICAGO

title: Two-Wheeled Greek Chorus
description: I called her the anorexic biker. My sisters and I didnt know the womans name, but for years we saw her riding on our streetin Washington: grinding up the hill past our house, then coasting down to Massachusetts Avenue, then beginning the same climb again. She would go up and down our street for at least an hour every day. She was out there in all kinds of weather, always wearing headphones and a backpack, often chewing gum.

title: Paradise, Paved
description: Who wants to spend the night in a Walmart parking lot?

title: Who Made Speed Dating?
description: At a matchmaking event he organized in 1998, Rabbi Yaacov Deyo brought along a gragger, the noisemaker Jews use during Purim. That night, in a Peets Coffee & Tea in Beverly Hills, the Orthodox rabbi twirled his gragger to signal when it was time for the single men and women present to switch partners and spark up a conversation with the next stranger. We thought 10 minutes for each date, because that was just an easier number to use in a busy coffeehouse, Deyo says. This entirely practical measure would inspire matchmakers all around the world  Jews and Gentiles alike.

title: Collateral Damage
description: In the 40-odd years that America and the Soviet Union faced off in the cold war, the people who presumed to run the world started with the knowledge that it was too dangerous, and possibly even suicidal, to attack one another. But the struggle was fierce, and what that meant in practice was that the competition played out in impoverished places like Cuba and Angola, where the great statesmen vied, eyed and subverted one another, and sometimes loosed their local proxies, all in the name of maintaining the slippery but all-important concept known as the balance of power.

title: Sins of the Brothers
description: The personal is political, the countercultural upheavals of the 60s claimed, but in Jhumpa Lahiris new novel, The Lowland, which takes its inspiration from an Indian variant of that upheaval, it is the political that is always personal. Udayan, the younger of two brothers in the eastern Indian city of Calcutta (now Kolkata), gets drawn into a radical left movement called Naxalism, its name derived from Naxalbari, a tiny village to the north of Calcutta where impoverished peasants rose up against the police and landlords in 1967, sparking off dreams of a nationwide insurgency that would replicate Maos earlier revolution in China. But Udayan is killed by the police, and his older brother, Subhash, apolitical, passive, but responsible, returns home from graduate school in the United States to console his parents. Finding himself confronted with his brothers pregnant widow, Gauri, and her ill treatment by his grieving parents, Subhash marries her and brings her to Rhode Island. Gauri gives birth to a girl, Bela, while also pursuing an academic career of her own in philosophy. By the end of the novel, when Bela is almost 40, the reader will have encountered four generations of this particular family.

title: Fire and Ice
description: In 1828, an Icelandic servant named Agnes Magnusdottir was convicted of killing her employer and another man, then burning their bodies. Pending ratification of her death sentence in Denmark, which then controlled Iceland, she was interned for many months on an isolated farm. Hannah Kents fictional take on this promising material was written, she explains in an authors note, to supply a more ambiguous portrayal of a woman who has commonly been seen as a witch, stirring up murder.

title: A Brutal Peace
description: All wars require a heroic narrative  to inspire soldiers to risk their lives and, afterward, to make them or their survivors feel they have not suffered or died in vain. Never has a heroic narrative been more durable than for the deadliest conflict of them all: World War II. It was the Good War, fought by the Greatest Generation, who bravely stopped Hitler, put the evildoers on trial at Nuremberg, restored democracy to a grateful Europe and brought it to a feudal Japan.

title: Hey Kids, Lets Put On a Show
description: Many public schools across the country reopened this month hanging by fraying threads. With arts programs already slashed, staffs have been cut even further in cities from Los Angeles to Washington. Suburbs  long considered a haven from such scarcity  arent necessarily faring much better. And certainly not the once-model suburb of Levittown, which suffers the particularly bad fortune of being in Pennsylvania, where schools have been starved of late. There, as Michael Sokolove notes in his stirring chronicle of the flourishing drama program at a Levittown high school, Gov. Tom Corbett suggested that state colleges short on funds should drill on their campuses for natural gas.

title: It Started in Naples
description: Every so often you encounter an author so unusual it takes a while to make sense of her voice. The challenge is greater still when this writers freshness has nothing to do with fashion, when its imbued with the most haunting music of all, the echoes of literary history. Elena Ferrante is this rare bird: so deliberate in building up her story that you almost give up on it, so gifted that by the end she has you in tears.

title: Skills Practice | Summarizing an Article
description: Welcome to Week 1 of our new Skills Practice series. Though we plan to work with the New Jersey teachers Jonathan Olsen and Sarah Gross and their students this year, just as we did last year, were still perfecting a format that works for both of their schools, so this edition is just an experiment. Please tell us what you think, below.

title: Handling the Grandparents Unsolicited Parenting Advice
description: Last Friday, in the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming, we posed the question: How Did You Handle Grandparents Unsolicited Parenting Advice?

title: Ex-Bear Stearns Chief Questions JPMorgans Mortgage Deal
description: Alan D. Schwartz, the former chief of Bear Stearns when it collapsed in 2008 and was absorbed by JPMorgan Chase, told Andrew Ross Sorkin that a proposed $11 billion settlement with the Justice Department doesnt feel like it makes sense, but it makes good headlines.

title: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: In Belgium, a Museum About the People Who Left It
description: A museum that explores the topic of migration is scheduled to open in Antwerp, Belgium, on Saturday. The Red Star Line Museum, located in the former warehouses of the Red Star Line shipping company, tells the story of the company, now defunct, and of the people who sailed from the port city of Antwerp on its ships.

title: Whats Also Under the Bridges
description: Theres more to the Dumbo Arts Festival than the Kabakovs and their Ship of Tolerance. A sampling:

title: All That We Hold Dear
description: In a recent New Yorker article about his time as a Google Glass Explorer, Gary Shteyngart discussed the challenge of setting a novel in the current moment, given the speed of social upheaval and technological advances. To write a book set in the present, circa 2013, he declared, is to write about the distant past. Dara Horns ambitious fourth novel, A Guide for the Perplexed, bears this exact burden: it is set partly in contemporary Egypt, post-revolution, and much of its plot involves a technology not unlike Google Glass itself.

title: Scientific Americans
description: You have turned your back on the common man, on their elementary needs and their restricted time and their intelligence, H. G. Wells wrote in a 1928 letter to James Joyce, after reading sections of Finnegans Wake. Do I get much pleasure from this work? No. Do I feel I am getting something new and illuminating as I do when I read . . . Pavlovs badly written book on Conditioned Reflexes? No. In other words, science involves new illuminations, messiness, even creative destruction, but literature is something else entirely: the common reader needs clarity, simplicity and a hopeful outlook, a sense that, in Wellss words, progress is not inevitable but interesting and possible.

title: Brogue States
description: The title story of Kevin Barrys new collection records the thoughts of a teenage girl struggling against the urge to cut herself. Instead of working or traveling, as most Irish kids do on their gap year before college, Sara holes up alone in a country house built by her father, a radical architect who had reinterrogated the concept of walls. His cool-father texts are unhelpful, as is the fact that he pointedly left the designer knives in their block in the kitchen space.

title: Writers Retreat
description: Imagine an 18th-century London town house, once a fashionable address but recently home to successive huddled masses: Jewish refugees, Irish then Bangladeshi then Somali immigrants. Now fill that house with 30 foreign writers who have fled oppression and violence, all asylum seekers specially chosen for favored treatment. Call them fellows. Hang identity cards, with their mug shots petrified in plastic, around their necks. Appoint a chairman whose paranoia and megalomania recall, in madcap picayune, the dictators who tortured and imprisoned many of them. Outfit the house with security cameras that scan the corridors, the surveillance tapes complemented by the human watchfulness of ever-solicitous volunteers. What you have is the premise for The House of Journalists, the former BBC reporter Tim Finchs clever debut novel.

title: Clinton Aides to Help in McAuliffe Fund-Raising Efforts
description: Friends of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have come out of the woodwork to help raise money for Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia who is close with the former president and served as chairman of Mrs. Clintons 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Today in Small Business: Postal Arbitrage
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Sept. 27, 2013
description: Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine join Charlie Herman on WNYCs Money Talking to discuss JPMorgans possible $11 billion settlement to end numerous investigations into how the bank handled mortgage-backed securities. Thats more than what Google earned last year and more than two and a half times as much as BP paid to settle after the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Is this the last chapter in the story of the financial crisis?

title: Image of the Day: Sept. 27
F.T.C. Votes for Inquiry Into Patent Businesses
description: WASHINGTON  Stepping into a volatile debate in the technology sector, the Federal Trade Commission on Friday said it would use its subpoena power to begin an investigation of so-called patent trolls, businesses whose primary purpose is to stockpile patents and use them to sue other companies.

title: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Tests Crash Avoidance Systems
description: Until now consumers who bought frontal crash prevention systems  including forward collision warning and automatic braking  had to take the word of automakers that the systems did something besides pump up the price. But today the first ratings of 74 vehicles with such systems were released by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a group financed by the insurance industry.

title: Crossword Contest Wrap Up and Winners
description: SPECIAL POST  More than 5,300 solvers sent answers to Mike Selinkers Letterboxes crossword in last Sundays New York Times. As crossword contests go, this one wasnt so hard. About 95% of the answers were correct.

title: U.N. Investigates More Alleged Chemical Attacks in Syria
description: LONDON  As the pace of efforts to scrutinize Syrias chemical weapons stockpiles quickens, United Nations inspectors said on Friday that they were investigating reports that the weapons were used seven times in Syria, including three after an attack on Aug. 21 on the outskirts of Damascus, the Syrian capital, that set off an international crisis.

title: Immigrant Influx Tests a Minneapolis Hospital
description: About 20 percent of Hennepin County Medical Centers patients were born in other countries, and interpreters are called on to help more than 130,000 times a year.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: An expanded ranch in Manalapan, N.J., and a colonial in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dior: Visual Feast in the Fashion Jungle
description: Imagination exhilarates, and thats what Raf Simons of Dior does for the fashion industry. He did that in mens wear for years. But now, after less than two years at Dior, he has everyones attention.

title: What We Resist Persists
description: A few days ago, it dawned on me that for the past several weeks I had been feeling vaguely anxious, uneasy and sad.

title: Iris van Berne Transforms Backstage at Hussein Chalayan
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Iris van Berne before (left) and after (right) makeup by Aaron de Mey and hair by Anthony Turner.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Chelsea studio; a duplex on the Upper West Side; and a Prospect Heights apartment with a terrace.

title: Pakistan, Citing Religious and Social Values, Bans L.G.B.T. Web Site
description: The Queer Pakistan Web site was meant to be a virtual refuge for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people in a religiously conservative country where homosexuality is illegal.

title: Japans Leader Gives No Ground in Islands Dispute
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on Friday rejected any concession in a standoff with China over a group of islands claimed by both countries, declining to even acknowledge that the islands are disputed.

title: A Tussle Over Service Dogs
description: Landlords and owners are faced with difficult decisions when considering medical waivers allowing dogs in no-pet buildings.

title: Do You Have a Doctors Note?
description: What does it take to get a dog into a no-pet building?

title: Is Health Care Reform Creating More Part-Time Work?
description: Republican critics of the Affordable Care Act often argue that the reform law has caused a big uptick in the number of part-time workers. The A.C.A. requires companies with 50 or more employees to provide health insurance to those working 30 hours or more a week, or pay a penalty. The theory spun by Republicans is that employers are maneuvering to escape that penalty by reducing the hours of most workers to below the 30 hour threshold. The critics say thats why many job-seekers cant find full-time work and many job holders are finding their hours reduced. As Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, said on the floor of the Senate recently, Obamacare is a big reason were turning into a nation of part-time workers.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Ian Burumas Year Zero
description: This week, Ian Buruma discusses Year Zero: A History of 1945; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Diane Ravitch talks about Reign of Error: The Hoax of the Privatization Movement and the Danger to Americas Public Schools; Gary J. Bass on The Blood Telegram: Nixon, Kissinger, and a Forgotten Genocide; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: L.S.U.s Mad Hatter Delights Fans or Drives Them Daffy
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  On a cruelly hot August day, Les Miles, wearing purple shorts and a black vest over a white, long-sleeve T-shirt, sat at a table in his office after practice. He was eating what his secretary, Yael Lofton, said was the same lunch he had eaten nearly every day of his eight-year tenure as Louisiana States football coach: a Cobb salad with grilled chicken and ranch dressing, washed down with diet iced tea.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Ian Burumas Year Zero
description: This week, Ian Buruma, Diane Ravitch and Gary J. Bass.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in New York; Edinburgh; Albuquerque
description: A Taste of Iceland,New YorkA celebration of Icelands music, food and culture will take place from Oct. 3 to 6 in New York. Some festival events are free, including a concert featuring emerging Icelandic musicians at Le Poisson Rouge in Greenwich Village. Culinary events, held in conjunction with the North Nordic Food Festival, feature meals prepared by Gunnar Karl Gislason (above), chef at Dill restaurant in Reykjavik; master classes in new Nordic cuisine; and a Nordic Christmas cooking class.

title: E.A. Sports and Collegiate Licensing to Pay $40 Million to Compensate Athletes
description: E.A. Sports and Collegiate Licensing Company are set to pay $40 million to settle their roles in a high-profile lawsuit seeking compensation for college athletes.

title: Big Ticket | A Hint of Europe for $13.579 Million
description: A four-bedroom penthouse, one of four that crown the Touraine, a new luxury condominium with distinct European overtones at 132 East 65th Street (at Lexington Avenue), sold for $13,579,371.82 and was the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records. The listing price for the 3,695-square-foot simplex, PH4, was $13,675,990, and the monthly carrying charges are $6,631.

title: Isabel Marant: Spring 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Big Bang Reinforces Its Status as Biggest Hit on Network TV
description: The Big Bang Theory left no doubt about what show is truly the biggest hit on network television, opening its new season Thursday night with overwhelming ratings, the best premiere in its seven-year history.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: The San Francisco Department of Public Health released a map that shows just how many full-time minimum wage jobs youd need to rent a two-bedroom apartment in San Francisco at fair market rates. The number of jobs ranges from three to eight.

title: Why More Climate Science Hasnt Led to More Climate Policy  Yet
description: Its worth offering a bit more context on a point I raised in my morning post on the new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change:

title: Eating the Color Purple
description: They say eat your greens, but this week Martha Rose Shulmans Recipes for Health provide ways to eat purple, cooking up eggplant in five new ways.

title: New Albums by Drake and the Weeknd
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss artistic personae, new theories of the hip-hop mainstream and the ongoing story of the Aubrey-Abel axis.

title: Sonia Rykiel: Spring 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: When Do Family Rules Change for Teenagers?
description: But I hate going to their house. The other kids ignore me and its boring, my 9-year-old complained when I told her we were going to a dinner party with my old high school friends and their families.

title: Shortcuts Seen by Firm Doing Security Checks
description: The calls and e-mails from top executives came toward the end of each month, former managers at USIS recalled. The company needed to swiftly complete investigating security clearances for the government in order to reach its monthly revenue goal, the managers said they were told. Finally, there was an order: Flush everything youve got.

title: Putting an Estate Value on the Assets Unique to You
description: MICHAEL JACKSON and J. D. Salinger would seem to have had little in common beyond being famous, reclusive (to different degrees) and the subject of much speculation about their personal lives. But in death the King of Pop and the author of The Catcher in the Rye have become sources of fascination and speculation among estate lawyers and the people charged with putting a price on hard-to-value assets, like royalties that continue paying after they are gone.

title: Book Review Podcast: The World After War
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Adam Hochschild reviews Ian Burumas Year Zero: A History of 1945. Mr. Hochschild writes:

title: Never-Ending Story
description: The conversation about race that public figures periodically claim to desire, the one that is always either about to happen or is being prevented from happening, has been going on, at full volume, at least since the day in 1619 when the first African slaves arrived in Jamestown. It has proceeded through every known form of discourse  passionate speeches, awkward silences, angry rants, sheepish whispers, jokes, insults, stories and songs  and just as often through double-talk, indirection and not-so-secret codes.

title: Power of 10 | The Secrets of an A-List Divorce Attorney
description: Divorce is becoming crazier, according to the Los Angeles lawyer Laura Wasser, though that could have something to do with the clients she has represented, including Kim Kardashian, Maria Shriver and Ashton Kutcher. Men have a reputation for being scoundrels, but Wasser said she increasingly sees women behaving badly. Wives end up cheating with the math tutor or the swim coach, then snapping, You deserve it! You neglected me!

title: A Guide to the New Exchanges for Health Insurance
description: Given all of the rhetoric about the Obama administrations health care law, its not surprising that many consumers are confused about how the new insurance exchanges will actually work. Some states that oppose the law have gone as far as intentionally limiting the information that trickles out to its residents.

title: Investors and Fed Talk Past Each Other
description: Last weeks announcement by the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, that the central bank wouldnt immediately begin tapering its asset purchases seemed to be just what markets were hoping for: stock and bond prices both rallied on the news, increasing the net worth of millions of Americans  at least until the specter of a fiscal cliff again raised its ugly head in Congress.

title: Nostalgia Meets Virtual World
description: The hip-hop festival Rock the Bells began in 2004 as a rebuke to what was then commercial in hip-hop: boasts about luxury consumption, the drug trade and nights in strip clubs. Rock the Bells promoted, instead, the storytelling, social consciousness and complex wordplay of the 1980s and 1990s, with headliners like Wu-Tang Clan and A Tribe Called Quest. But then hip-hop turned yet another corner. With the Internet gaining on radio as a way to build audiences, storytelling and complex concepts  not just easy hooks  made a resurgence among younger rappers.

title: An Exhibit of All That Alaa Says
description: The title of the exhibition says it all: Alaa. No extra words of puffery, not even his first name (Azzedine). Just his surname, all vowels and one rising consonant, a word people have been saying in Paris for 35 years with respect, love and kinship: uh-LIE-aah.

title: Dizzying Search for God Particle
description: Although you have to be knowledgeable in physics and cosmology to fully grasp the concepts laid out in Mark Levinsons documentary Particle Fever, this movie about one of the greatest scientific ventures in history is a mind blower. Visually snazzy, the film follows the search for the theoreticalHiggs boson, a k a the god particle, by scientists seeking the origins of matter. It follows the multinational teams who conceived and built the Large Hadron Collider, an 18-mile-long supercollider used in the preliminary discovery of the particle, near Geneva.

title: Humans at Helm: Is Any Flight Safe?
description: Cellphone videos and such have made images of airplane calamities fairly familiar, but often they are seen only as scary snippets on the news. The Smithsonian Channel went with an alarmist title, Terror in the Skies, for the series it beginson Sundaynight, but the program serves up much more than just alarming videos of crashes, near crashes and in-flight chaos.

title: Pictures of a Day Lodged in Memory
description: If you were around in the early 1960s, you probably have at least one shared communal experience lodged in your memory: the recollection of where you were when you first heard news of the Kennedy shooting in Dallas. On the half-century anniversary of the assassination, the International Center of Photography brings usback to that moment in a documentary exhibition calledJFK November 22, 1963: A Bystanders View of History, which opens Oct. 4.

title: Interpreting Rite in 2 Parts
description: Do we need another Rite of Spring? In this centennial year of the transgressive 1913 original, its hard not to greet every new take on this rabble-rouser with that question. Of the dozens of interpretations to emerge, how many wring something new from Stravinskys staggering score, or subvert the expectations of their own time? And how many are just obligatory tributes to a ballet that the history books have deemed important?

title: An Opening Gala, Then a Premiere
description: In his second season as the Philadelphia Orchestras music director, the French Canadian conductor Yannick Nzet-Sguin has already galvanized this ensembles audiences and inspired its musicians. New Yorkers mostly know Mr. Nzet-Sguin, 38, from his appearances with the Metropolitan Opera. He brings his orchestra to Carnegie Hall for a gala concert to open the season.

title: 140 Character Assassination
description: The question of the moment is whether the sane Republicans will, out of fear for their own political skins, defer to the insane Republicans and allow a government shutdown, or the much scarier possibility of debt default. Amid this drama, however, its worth remembering that even the sane ones are pretty much off the deep end, all too willing to buy into crazy conspiracy theories. Remember how Jack Welch accused Obama of cooking the jobs numbers?

title: The Week in Pictures for Sept. 27
description: Pictures include unlawfully painted bike lanes in Manhattan, oyster planting in the Bronx, and environmentalists in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn.

title: Notes From Canada, a Career and the Distant Future
description: Deltron 3030

title: Popcast: New Albums by Drake and the Weeknd
description: The new-model rapper Drake, a k a Aubrey Graham, and the new-model R&B singer the Weeknd, a k a Abel Tesfaye, are both from Toronto, and have had linked careers: in late 2010, the highly visible Drake rapidly spread the word about the publicity-shy Mr. Tesfaye through a viral blog post, and one of the best tracks on Drakes 2011 album Take Care was Crew Love, with Mr. Tesfaye delivering bad vibes in a high and vulnerable voice.

title: Giants Snee and Baas Out Against Chiefs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants offensive line, coming off a dreadful performance in last Sundays 38-0 loss at the Carolina Panthers, will be missing two starters when the 0-3 team visits the 3-0 Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday.

title: Rights Groups and Clinics Sue Texas Over Provisions in Its New Abortion Law
description: National womens rights groups and Texas abortion clinics filed suit on Friday in federal court in Texas, seeking to block provisions of a new state law that they said would have dramatic and draconian effects on womens access to the procedure.

title: The Slave to His Star
description: Near the end of April 1863, on the eve of the first muster of African-American regiments in the North, William Slade, the head servant in the White House, sent Abraham Lincoln a petition from Washingtons black community recommending officers for the districts first regiment of black troops. Sixty-seven men signed the petition, addressed to Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton, including members of the Israel Lyceum of Washington City, an African-American debating society. A letter from Slade to Lincoln accompanied the petition, acknowledging that he and the other men wanted Lincoln to see the petition at the earliest practicable moment.

title: Explorations in Identity and Pleasure
description: A century and a half after Gustave Flaubert wrote Madame Bovary, and 50 years after the advent of the sexual revolution, popular art still shrinks from truly reckoning with female desire. After a flurry of 1960s art-house erotica (I Am Curious (Yellow)) and quasi-feminist camp (Barbarella), women-centric movies in the main have returned to status quo-bolstering narratives of marriage, melodrama and moral guilt. Which makes the near-simultaneous arrival of two new films that explore varieties of female sexual experience suggest the stirring of a newly liberated cinema.

title: Maison Martin Margiela: Spring 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Waking Up at Walmart
description: This weeks Look features photographs of people who have the spent the night in their vehicles in Walmart parking lots in Arizona (Walmart welcomes this practice, with the idea that overnighters will shop at the store). The images were taken by Nolan Conway, who previously captured for the magazine people in McDonalds restaurants all over the country and young children being smeared with sunscreen. I put some questions to Conway about his most recent series.

title: After Rout in German Elections, Social Democrats Consider Coalition With Merkel
description: BERLIN  In the first step of what could be a long road to building a new German government, the defeated Social Democrats agreed on Friday to enter into talks with Chancellor Angela Merkels conservatives over a possible coalition, naming fair wages, good jobs and a strengthening of the countrys social system as key points.

title: Coconut Dulce de Leche With Pineapple
description: Melissa Clark uses coconut milk to make an intensely flavored and dairy-free dulce de leche.

title: With Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has found plenty to occupy himself since his N.B.A. playing days  acting, coaching, writing some best-selling books, serving as a cultural ambassador for the United States. He was in Manhattan this week to promote his new childrens book, Sasquatch in the Paint, the first installment in a planned trilogy.

title: Off the Charts: Big Government States
description: States with a larger government presence tended to vote Republican in the 2012 election, while states with a smaller government presence tended to vote Democratic.

title: Still Waters Meet Their Sparkling Counterpart
description: For David Hagedorn and Michael Widomski, friends for many years, the hardest parts about falling in love were shaking off the fantasies each had harbored about how love would arrive and admitting to themselves and each other that what they had was the real thing after all.

title: Restoring the Thrill to Dulce de Leche
description: BACK BEFORE DULCE DE LECHE became ubiquitous in the dessert world, I had my first taste at my friend Zos house. It was a recipe she had learned from her Chilean ex-mother-in-law and couldnt wait to make for me. The thick caramel pudding was nutty, smooth on the tongue and unlike any other Id had.

title: In Republican States, More Government Jobs
description: FAMILIARITY, it is said, breeds contempt. Or perhaps, it is dependence that breeds resentment.

title: Documentary Keeps It Completely Real
description: Over the 12 years it took to make Let the Fire Burn, about the radical group Move and its 1985 bombing by the Philadelphia police, the director Jason Osder  like any good documentarian  filmed interviews with crucial people.

title: Total Immersion, on Screen and in Life
description: Early on in the third season of Homeland  which begins on Showtime on Sunday  the actor Rupert Friend, as the enigmatic black-ops agent Peter Quinn, hunches, shirtless, over a homemade explosive device. There is a stillness to Mr. Friends performance, a noiseless stoicism that only amplifies his characters inscrutability: whatever Quinn is up to with that bomb (and in that moment, its fruitless to even guess), it seems extraordinarily unlikely that hell miss his target.

title: Lady Murasakis Masterpiece and Its Update
description: Filled with romance, conflict, sex, adventure and the occasional malevolent visitor from the spirit world, the new print show at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College has so much going on that it would take a book to cover it. Actually, more than one  and its not surprising.

title: Is It Going Away to College if College Is Close to Home?
description: From When College Is Close to Home, What are the Boundaries? in the Styles section:

title: When College Is Close to Home, What Are the Boundaries?
description: I was the last person people thought would stay in their hometown for college, said Laura Johnson, a senior at Macalester College who lives in a house a half-hour walk from her home in St. Paul. Even my parents wondered why I wasnt going away.

title: Judge Orders New Jersey to Allow Gay Marriage
description: A New Jersey judge ruled on Friday that the state must allow same-sex couples to marry, saying that not doing so deprives them of rights that were guaranteed by the United States Supreme Court in June.

title: J.C. Penneys Troubling Stock Sale
description: J.C. Penneys stock sale reflects a particular sort of dimness about discounts. The troubled U.S. retailer is struggling to get prices right in its stores and isnt faring any better in the markets. It is selling over $900 million of shares at $9.65 each, after spending a similar sum to buy them back two years ago while paying nearly $37 apiece. Capital misallocation is a new bad sign for J.C. Penney.

title: Works in Conversation With Photography
description: Although he came of age as an artist in the tumultuous 1960s, Chuck Close did not adopt the most radical innovations of that era in his work. Instead, Mr. Close chose to work in portraiture, one of the most traditional art genres, using it as a vehicle to explore how photography relates to painting, and how these mediums both represent and affect our view of the world and ourselves.

title: Lacking Rules, Insurers Balk at Paying for Intensive Psychiatric Care
description: THE first time Melissa Morelli was taken to the hospital, she was suicidal and cutting herself, her mother says. She was just 13, and she had been transferred to a psychiatric hospital, where she stayed for more than a week. Her doctors told her mother, Cathy Morelli, that it was not safe for Melissa to go home. But the familys health insurance carrier would not continue to pay for her to remain in the hospital.

title: Moving Offstage to Seek Harmony
description: NEWARK  When theNew Jersey Symphony Orchestrabegan rehearsals recently for its seasonopener this weekend under the baton of its music director, Jacques Lacombe, one player who has been central to the ensemble was missing onstage  one so central, in fact, that everyone used to tune to his A.

title: After 45 Years, Freedom Salted With Hindsight
description: About 10 years ago, the choreographer Lar Lubovitch found himself watching a black-and-white film of an unusual dancer. It showed a slender young man curling up from the floor, then whirling around an empty room, as if discovering how his body moved for the first time.

title: Technology and the College Generation
description: As a professor who favors pop quizzes, Cedrick May is used to grimaces from students caught unprepared. But a couple of years ago, in his class on early American literature at the University of Texas at Arlington, he said he noticed horrible, pained looks from the whole class when they saw the questions.

title: Still Making Music Together, Far Apart
description: The partnership started with an ad in an English music magazine in 1967. Liberty Records was looking for songwriters, and Bernie Taupin, a farmworker and amateur poet from Lincolnshire, sent in a sheaf of lyrics, not expecting much. Around the same time a frustrated young blues pianist named Reg Dwight auditioned for the label. An executive didnt like Mr. Dwights material but tossed him a stack of Mr. Taupins lyrics and said, See what you can do with these.

title: Seven Days of Style | Lizzy Caplan Gets Randy, Saks Gets Smelly and Moschino Celebrates
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLESept. 21  27

title: Full Decision From New Jersey Court on Same-Sex Marriage
description: Read the full ruling from Judge Mary C. Jacobson on same-sex marriage.

title: Rossellini and Bergmans Break From Tradition
description: In the 10 days since she bore a son to film director Roberto Rossellini in Rome, actress Ingrid Bergman has become the center of a spirited controversy, The New York Times noted on Feb. 12, 1950. Indeed, Bergmans decision to leave behind both Hollywood and her husband, Dr. Petter Lindstrom, to make a low-budget film in Italy with the most audacious filmmaker of the day had already touched off shock and outrage in the American press. That the boy, Renato, was born out of wedlock only increased the furor.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photos from India, Pakistan, Syria and Kenya.

title: Death, Up an Apple Tree
description: The incarnation of death, who materializes early in On Borrowed Time, is no hooded specter with a scythe in a skeletal claw. Rather, in Paul Osborns 1938 play, death is mildly personified as Mr. Brink, a gentlemanly fellow sporting a natty tan suit and a homburg hat. But he still means mortal business.

title: Nicholas Kirkwood: Plucking a Commoner From an Exalted Family
description: In todays parade of outrageous shoes, Nicholas Kirkwood is the maddest hatter of all.

title: So, Its Your Father, or Me. Decide.
description: In the vintage home-movie prologue to the writer-director Stuart Zichermans debut comedy A.C.O.D., a boys ninth birthday party is ruined by the profane screams of his parents before he can even blow out the candles. Then, in a madcap montage, the divorcing parents, played by Catherine OHara and Richard Jenkins, do what modern-day parenting books explicitly forbid: They bribe their children with gifts and force them to choose whom they will live with, while assassinating each others characters and introducing a dizzying number of new partners and stepsiblings.

title: Gaming With Chrome, and Bypassing Windows 8
description: Gaming on a Google-Powered Notebook

title: A Road Trip Through Cajun Country
description: Sampling big flavors and lively culture on a drive through southern Louisiana.

title: Ominous Signs, Then a Cruel Attack
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  THIS was the attack we all knew was coming.

title: Photo Booths, the Partys Hot Spot
description: The party was for VFiles, the online fashion hub and store, and as expected, cameras were everywhere. In addition to the half-dozen photographers assigned to cover the Fashion Week affair, guests posed for selfies and snapped pictures of the rapper A$AP Rocky and the artist Mykki Blanco.

title: Elements: Texture at Paris Fashion Week
description: Explore the notion of texture in the first of thematic visual diaries from Paris Fashion Week.

title: Zalaznick, Once a Programming Force at NBCUniversal, Is Leaving
description: Lauren Zalaznick, whose leadership at Bravo turned that cable network into a lucrative asset for its parent, NBCUniversal, is leaving the company, Steve Burke, the chief executive of NBCUniversal, told the staff in a memo released on Friday.

title: Hyundais Brother Act
description: The redesigned Santa Fe comes in two versions: a muscular midsize crossover and a Sport model that trains its sights on best-selling compacts.

title: Athletic Socks that Give a Foot Bragging Rights
description: It took Winston Robson, 15, nearly a solid day of lawn-mowing and a little bit of luck to buy one of his most prized possessions: a pair of $60 limited-edition socks.

title: Microeconomics: A City in Miniature
description: For years, Randy Hage has been snapping photos of storefronts in changing New York neighborhoods, and then making scale models of them.

title:
U.S. and Iran 
Agree to Speed
Talks to Defuse
Nuclear Issue
description: WASHINGTON  The long-fractured relationship between the United States and Iran took a significant turn on Friday when President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani became the first leaders of their countries to speak since the Tehran hostage crisis more than three decades ago.

title: Weekend Reading: JPMorgan Settlement in Sight
description: After another week of intense negotiations, the Justice Department and JPMorgan Chase continue to inch closer to a multibillion-dollar accord over questionable mortgage practices. No one can be certain how much the bank will have to pay, but everyone seems to have an opinion.

title: The New iPad App Youll Want Grandma to Download
description: Ustyme is the kind of app the iPad was made for. Two users, connected online and by video, can read or play games together in an experience that is as close to really being together as Ive yet found online. Particularly for a young child interacting with an adult at a distance, ustyme created a shared experience in a way Skype and FaceTime never could.

title: Dancing, Dining and Daiquiris in Cajun Country
description: Whenever I visit Cajun country, in southwest Louisiana, the land of crawfish, gumbo, gator steaks and les bons temps personified, my first stop is at a cultural icon that, in itself, elevates this region to the status of an American touristic treasure: the drive-through daiquiri hut. This was my intention in mid-July; however, the plane was late, and I had pressing business to address midday  sampling boudin balls (deep-fried rounds of pork and seasoned rice). Boudin in these parts is what lobsters are in Maine, or crabs in Baltimore. And you find them everywhere  in butcher shops, in delis, at food stands, even at gas stations. More on these  and the daiquiris  in a moment.

title: Review: 2014 Hyundai Santa Fe
description: Live large in Santa Fe even if your home is in Duluth. Hyundais three-row crossover is a very serious competitor. Tom Voelk checks out a loaded Limited model in Driven.

title: Dogfish Head Brewery to Open an Inn
description: The popular Dogfish Head brewery in Delaware has announced that it plans to open its first hotel, the Dogfish Inn, in spring 2014.

title: The Ghosts of Amsterdam
description: It only recently occurred to me that one very fine if not exactly intentional purpose for historic preservation is to keep dead people alive. Having spent the past several years living in Amsterdam and researching a book about its history, I now find that virtually anywhere I walk in this city, whose center has been so tenderly and smartly maintained, I am jostled by ghosts.

title: From Grapes to Goat Cheese on the North Fork
description: Settle into a rural pace on this trip out to the eastern end of Long Island.

title: Looking for the Hamptons? Go the Other Way
description: At the end of the line, the very last stop on the Long Island Rail Road, there is a huge rusted anchor. Beyond it, there is water and there are boats. The ferry to Shelter Island chugs back and forth, a purposeful ship among the flighty sailboats.

description: Grunge is still influential 25 years after it first appeared on the runway at Perry Ellis.

title: Documenting a Massacre in Kenya
description: Tyler Hicks, a Times photographer, narrates a look at his photographs from inside the Westgate mall in Nairobi, Kenya, after assailants opened fire.

title: A Nightly Dinner Out Thats Like Therapy
description: It never fails, Harry Rosen said on Wednesday evening as he enjoyed another fine meal by himself in another top-rated Manhattan restaurant.

title: Swift Movement Is Seen on Syria After U.N. Action
description: The diplomatic drive to purge Syria of its chemical weapons accelerated Friday, as the full 15-member United Nations Security Council approved a breakthrough resolution to ensure Syrian compliance, and the organization responsible for carrying out the destruction of those munitions announced a timetable that starts Tuesday, sooner than some had expected.

title: Answers to Some Questions About Health Care Exchanges
description: Its a little like an election: Most people dont focus on it until they prepare to vote. Now that the new health care exchanges are about to open, potential buyers of the new plans are trying to understand the law. Your Money columnist Tara Siegel Bernard has answers to some of the most perplexing questions and is standing by to answer more from readers. You can find her full column here.

title: Songs Between Trains
description: Youre trudging back to Brooklyn, utterly worn out. The last thing you want to do is wait for the train, and you hope as you head underground that the L will arrive immediately. But theres a violinist in the station and shes playing the most soothing, beautiful music.

title: House Republicans Should Knock it Off
description: The health care obsessives in the Senate, led by Ted Cruz and Mike Lee, have spent days trying to portray Democrats as out of touch with the public. The Senate Democrats are not listening to the millions of Americans who are being hurt by Obamacare, Mr. Cruz said this morning in his last stand in this particular round of the budget battle.

title: Llewyn Davis Concert to Benefit Recording Preservation
description: When Town Hall agreed to host a fund-raiser for the National Recording Preservation Foundation on Sunday, its executive director, Lawrence Zucker, was thinking about 22 boxes of old recordings sitting in a warehouse in New Jersey.

title: A Wedding Party of Five
description: If love, food and family are lifes simple ingredients, then putting them together in one place, at one table, can be celebration enough. And so it happened on the second night it was open at Marcos, a restaurant in the space formerly occupied by  Frannys pizzeria on Flatbush Avenue in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The owners, Francine Stephens and Andrew Feinberg, moved Frannys up the block in April and opened this chic, understated trattoria in its place, naming it for their 5-year-old son. They kept only the brick walls and the pew from a Crown Heights synagogue that formed a banquette by the kitchen, now featuring a wood-fired grill and a rotisserie. On Tuesday, neighbors waited outside for the dressed-up farm fare without the pizza, while a family of five came to mark the low-key occasion of their backyard Brooklyn wedding, delighting in the warmth of something old, new and true.

title: Cosmos-Rowdies: That 70s Rivalry, Updated
description: It was once one of the fiercest rivalries in North American soccer.

title: Obamas Statement on Iran
description: President Obama said he spoke with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran by phone, the first direct contact between leaders of Iran and the United States since 1979.

title: New York Sues Teachers Union Over Deal on Disciplinary Hearings
description: Three years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York Citys teachers union celebrated an agreement to end the use of rubber rooms, the much-ridiculed holding pens where teachers accused of wrongdoing or incompetence would report for years on end, doing no work but drawing full salaries.

title: Renovated With or Without Family Room
description: Automakers, logo designers and plastic surgeons all adhere to an unshakable credo: make it bigger.

title: Vestas Joins With Mitsubishi for Offshore Turbines
description: LONDON  The Danish wind turbine manufacturer Vestas received a financial lift on Friday as it announced a joint venture with Mitsubishi Heavy Industry of Japan to develop offshore wind energy.

title: New Spanish Budget Free of Austerity Measures
description: MADRID  Confident that Spain is emerging from a prolonged recession, the government on Friday presented a budget for 2014 that was largely free of the unpopular austerity measures of recent years.

title: Daniel Peddle, Casting Director, Can See for Miles and Miles
description: It was the day after the Givenchy fall mens show in June, and the casting director, an exhausted Daniel Peddle, was in Paris at a SeventhArrondissement cafe.

title: The Unstuffy Taco
description: There is only one good way to eat a taco, and that is to eat it as soon as it has been assembled. No waiting, no fanfare and certainly not wrapped to go. Its all about immediacy, devouring it while it is still in prime shape.

title: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2014 RTW
description: Paris

description: If the Moon Rises by Papa

title: First-Round Picks Pay Off in Jets Pass Rush
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A complex formula may explain the success of the Jets defensive line, explain how four large men can get past five larger men with such apparent ease. Such an explanation might require a chalkboard or an applied sciences degree.

title: A Government Shutdown, by the Numbers
description: A look at the costs, closings and other ramifications of a government shutdown.

title: A Break From the Wildlife, With Family
description: Cristin Samper, a tropical biologist, is the president of the Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs four zoos and an aquarium in New York City, including the Bronx Zoo, and oversees conservation programs around the world. Before taking the job last year, he directed the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History in Washington. Born in Costa Rica and raised in Colombia, Dr. Samper, 48, was formerly chief adviser for biodiversity to the Colombian government. On weekends, he relishes downtime with his wife, Adriana, 42, a lawyer, and two children, Carolina, 7, and Martin, 4. Dr. Samper and his family live on the Upper East Side, where their apartment overlooks Carl Schurz Park.

title: Getting Their Trucks in a Row, Europeans Revisit the Convoy
description: Researchers in Europe are working on a concept that will be familiar to anyone who has seen films about the bands of travelers who settled the American West. The project is developing an electronic communications system that enables a wagon train of tractor-trailer trucks and cars to make semiautonomous road trips possible  without the complexity of efforts like Googles driverless vehicles.

title: Before Appetizers Are Served, a Quick Diagnosis From the Valet
description: LOS ANGELES  The check engine light of the BMW had been glowing for a few days when its owner pulled up to the valet drop-off at Ink, the much-discussed restaurant opened here two years ago by Michael Voltaggio, a Top Chef reality show winner.

title: Add Another Small Sporty Pickup to the Endangered List
description: TESTED 2013 Toyota Tacoma X-Runner

title: Expires 2013: Models That Wont Return
description: Every fall, the new-car season brings fresh models and industrywide optimism, but its also the time when automakers are forced to acknowledge whats not selling as discontinued models disappear from company Web sites and dealership lots. With few exceptions, a canceled car is a slow-selling car.

title: Fill, Empty, Stack, Hold: Art With a 6-Sided Object
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  As a prop, the cardboard box  like that old standard, the folding chair  holds myriad theatrical possibilities. It can be a container for smaller things, a building block for larger ones. It can be hoisted, flung, crumpled, collapsed, climbed inside of, jumped on top of. It calls up metaphors like boxed in and outside the box. And, while mundane, it has a certain intrinsic mystery: whats inside?

title: At Christian Dior, the Perfect Black Pump
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Diving Into the Past, They Land in the Present
description: At first, an Earth, Wind & Fire concert is all about Verdine White. If you want to go in this direction, you can go a long way. American music used to be about bands; bands are powered by rhythm, clarified by precision and enlivened by extravagance, the sound of the strong and the strange. Mr. White, Earth Wind & Fires bassist and one of its three longtime touring members, is all of that: discipline and impatience, generative past and impulsive, wasteful present. Hes in the class of bass players who will not be denied, who play as if they wanted to wrestle down the music and bite it.

title: Jolted to Attention by Dior
description: PARIS  Most good days here you sort of feel you are on a collision course, and its not only the traffic or a pair of naked protesters at Nina Ricci (well, it was warm in the tent) or the bystanders who have come to watch the freak parade. No, its the clothes that constantly work you over.

title: Obama on the Looming Shutdown
description: The president delivered a strong message to Congress not to shut down the government and the economy and to think about the concerns of the American people.

title: Few Words, but Sound Abounds
description: Cape Breton, the island at Nova Scotias northeastern tip, is a windswept, rainy, hardscrabble, isolated, workaday and majestically beautiful place in We Have an Anchor, a film by Jem Cohen that was presented with live musicians playing the score on Thursday night. It began a three-night run at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater. Images were shown on up to five screens, and the score was performed by the seven-member ensemble of indie-rockers who had composed it. The event was presented by the Next Wave Festival in association with the Wordless Music series.

title: Senate Urges House to Allow Vote
description: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, urged the House to allow a vote on the Senate budget bill that would prevent a government shutdown.

title: Theres Always a Market for a Few Surprises
description: PARIS  It is starting to seem cruel, season after season, to keep asking young maverick designers to remember to make clothes that women will want to wear in real life.

title: Hispanics Grow Cool to G.O.P., Poll Finds
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A new survey shows that Hispanics, the nations largest minority group, have grown increasingly negative toward the Republican Party during the political battle over changing immigration law and lean surprisingly liberal on social issues like gay marriage  a combination of factors that presents a steep challenge for Republicans in trying to win back Hispanic voters.

title: More on Dysfunctionology: Minority Rules
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Another Tryst
description: Television has featured some high-stakes extramarital affairs of late, with the presidency (Scandal) and the very security of the United States (Homeland) among the things at risk. The garden-variety affair at the heart of Betrayal, a new drama that ABC offers on Sunday night, seems ordinary by comparison, at least what we see of it in the pilot.

title: Senate Vote Kicks Stopgap Budget Measure Back to House
description: WASHINGTON  The Senates approval on Friday of a stopgap spending measure that would keep the federal government open without gutting President Obamas health care law now sends the fight back to the House, just days from a potential Oct. 1 government shutdown.

title: Feeling For | The Doge Table, an Icon of Postwar Italian Design, Gets a New Home
description: Like his architecture, Carlo Scarpas furniture designs were elegant, substantial and beautifully detailed. A case in point: his Doge table, with its crisp steel base and jewel-like exposed brass screws. The table was the first piece made by Simon, a company that was founded in 1968 by the legendary entrepreneur Dino Gavina, who died in 2007. A champion of postwar Italian design who once called production a medium that can be used as a vehicle for stupidity or for civilization, Gavina turned out meticulously designed, luxurious furniture by Scarpa, Kazuhide Takahama, Enzo Mari and other influential names, and reproduced iconic Surrealist pieces like Meret Oppenheims Traccia table, with its gilded birds legs, and Man Rays Les Grands Transparents mirror. The good news for design fans is that the Simon brand has been acquired by the pioneering Italian furniture manufacturer Cassina. The line, which will be folded into Cassinas I Contemporanei collection, will be available in the United States in November.

title: In Tehran, Phone Call Between Presidents Is as Good as a Handshake
description: TEHRAN  Night had fallen here in the Iranian capital as Hassan Rouhani, the new president of Iran, sent a message via his now-famous Twitter account: He had just gotten off the phone with President Obama, who had called him.

title: The Chick-Magnet Dreams of a Hollywood Guy
description: A lot of lists of should-be-better-known movies include Modern Romance, Albert Brookss comedy about a narcissistic, neurotic, insanely jealous film editor doing his best to torpedo his relationship with a good woman in early 1980s Los Angeles.

title: Culture Warrior, Gaining Ground
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  A generation after he was squarely pummeledas elitist, antiquated and narrow-minded, the education theorist E. D. Hirsch Jr. is being dragged backinto the ringat the age of 85  this time for a chance at redemption.

title: Lost People, Populating a Forgotten Play by Inge
description: I dunno how to live, says the man in the rumpled evening wear, having struggled back to consciousness through a hangover haze. He peers out from exhausted eyes in confusion and pain, and although his mind may still be fogged by alcohol, you have the sharp, sad sense that hes never before understood his own unhappiness with such piercing clarity.

title: Rise in Deadly Attacks on Shiites in Iraq Stirs Anger at Government
description: BAGHDAD  As Satar Jabar mourned the death of his mother last week, three explosions struck the funeral tent, killing nearly 100 people, including his young son and two of his brothers.

title: Collaboration on the High Seas
description: Students and entrepreneurs work together on a cruise around the world.

title: Like a Rolling Revue, the Art Is Coming to Town
description: BARSTOW, Calif.  Hours late, the Station to Station train blew into town here this week to absolutely no fanfare, despite being covered in discofied flashing lights. The caravan, nine retro cars, discharged dozens of svelte young people in good pants and expensively shaggy haircuts, along with one guy in Google Glass. Its likely that no one sports such high technology here, an economically depressed rail and military city of 22,000, about two hours northeast of Los Angeles. Once a regular stop on Route 66, with the vintage Stardust and Sands Motels to show for it, Barstow is now mainly just a place to pass through on the way to Las Vegas. But on Sunday night, the Station to Station crew was staying put, ready to turn Barstow into a cultural destination, if only for a few days.

title: A Cruise on the S.S. Brainstorm
description: ABOARD MV EXPLORER  Somewhere on the Mediterranean, a robot was taking shape.

title: The Natural History of American Design
description: The trove of rare photographs, textiles, design manuals and garments on display in An American Style: Global Sources for New York Textile and Fashion Design, 1915-1928, which opens today in the Focus Gallery at the Bard Graduate Center, calls attention to a relatively unknown effort after World War I by the American Museum of Natural History to inspire and energize New York fashion designers. The initiative granted the designers unfettered access to the museums ethnographic collections of Native American, Mesoamerican, Andean and South American relics. Curators opened up the museums specimen storage rooms and lent artifacts, like beaded Native American dresses from the Blackfoot tribe, to design firms and department stores for inspiration. The goal was to develop a distinctly American (as opposed to European) design language, but the museum ultimately abandoned the project and its fleeting dream of building a separate museum devoted to non-Western textile arts and industrial design, modeled after Londons Victoria & Albert Museum.

title: Station to Station, on Tour
description: Station to Station, an art show traveling across the country by train, visits Barstow, Calif., before heading to Oakland, its final stop.

description: When Timothy Leary died in 1996, he was eulogized as the godfather of the drug-fueled Sixties counterculture.

title: Washington as Reader, Not Soldier
description: MOUNT VERNON, Va.  If you make your way into the inner sanctum of the imposing new research library that opened here at George Washingtons Mount Vernon on Friday, past its handsome reading room and through its rare-book suite, into a small oval chamber sparsely stocked with Washingtons own books, you might be tempted to accept conventional wisdom: Washington was first in war, first in peace, and first in the hearts of his countrymen  but, as a reader among the Founding Fathers, he was one of the last.

title: Women, the Loud, the Few
description: The first thing you notice is all the screaming. Icona Pop is a Swedish duo, Caroline Hjelt and Aino Jawo  singers both, but shouters more. Their hit is I Love It, inescapable for the last year, at home at indie dance parties and sports arenas alike. The hook is nave and cheeky and, depending on your angle, exuberant or petulant: I! Dont! Care! I love it!

title: A House Visited by Hurricane Sandy, Now Hosting High Jinks
description: Plastic orange netting stretches along the front of what was once a couples dream house. It is meant to keep people out, but it is more like a beacon. This, the net whispers, youve got to see.

title: The Shifting Mandala
description: RACING through our school lobby on the way to recess, my sixth-grade classmates and I stopped short. Usually, we would barrel onto the street for our 20 minutes of sunlight, but a Buddhist monk dressed in brilliant saffron robes caught our attention. He was creating a mandala. In this ancient art form developed by Tibetan Buddhist monks, millions of grains of multicolored sand are painstakingly poured into complex patterns. After hours of work, the sand painting is only one square meter yet symbolically portrays our entire universe in its shifting complexities.

title: Michael Ward, Survivor of 85 Bombing by Philadelphia Police, Is Dead at 41
description: When the boy ran from the house, he was burned over a fifth of his body and so malnourished that at 13 he looked like a child of 9.

title: Guns at School? If Theres a Will, There Are Ways
description: CLARKSVILLE, Ark.  The slim, black 9-millimeter handguns that the school superintendent David Hopkins selected for his teachers here weigh about a pound and slip easily into a pocket. Sixteen people, including the janitor and a kindergarten teacher, wear them to school every day.

title: The Captain Ahabs of the House
description: How many more rounds of this must America take?

title: Wright Sits With Injury to Thumb
description: When a changeup struck David Wright in the helmet in the third inning Thursday, he fell hard and landed on his right thumb. Wright did not sustain a concussion, Manager Terry Collins said, but his thumb was bothering him enough that the Mets decided to sit him for Fridays game against the Milwaukee Brewers, which the Mets lost, 4-2.

title: Congress Cracks Up
description: Our challenge today is to explain how Congress evolved into our national nutcase.

title: Shelbys Great Raid
description: In the aftermath of the Unions capture of Little Rock, Ark., on Sept. 10, 1863, the Confederate general Sterling Price led 8,000 rebels on a dejected march toward the southwest corner of the state, near Arkadelphia. Once there, the soldiers settled into their camps with the enthusiasm of a chain gang. Out on the edge of town, on a near-empty creek bed, Col. Joseph Orville Shelby, known as Jo, his arm in a sling, staked out a fittingly bleak campsite.

title: Russian News Sites Protest Detention of Journalists With Greenpeace Activists
description: A Russian court on Thursday ordered that 22 members of the Greenpeace team that protested Arctic drilling by trying to scale a state-run oil rig may spend up to two months in detention in a Murmansk jail, while investigators decide whether to charge them with committing an act of piracy.

title: The Silence of the Leaves
description: The other night, one of the dogs rolled over in its sleep and fell off the bed. The crash woke me up, though it didnt seem to disturb the dog. The moon was shining, even brighter for the veil of clouds around it. It was one of the restless hours  a few minutes after 2  when thoughts come alive the way forks and knives used to do in the old cartoons after the humans had gone to bed.

title: After Violence Interrupts Progress, a Struggle Ensues in Denver
description: DENVER  When Terrance Roberts, a barrel-chested former leader of the Bloods street gang, campaigned against street violence here, his words carried weight. As a Blood, Mr. Roberts was once shot in the back, and he served time in prison for several felony convictions.

title: Mariano Riveras Saving Grace
description: It might not have been the ending Hollywood would have written  it wasnt the World Series, and the Yankees lost  but it was powerful anyway. At the stadium on Thursday night, Mariano Rivera, baseballs greatest relief pitcher, said goodbye.

title: Reimagining a Boardwalk, This Time in Concrete
description: One of the enduring symbols of Hurricane Sandys fury  and there were many  was the havoc wreaked on the five-mile Boardwalk at Rockaway Beach in Queens, which was variously banged up, destroyed or swept away. For months after the storm, the parks department raced to ready the beach for the summer season, repairing concession areas and creating safe entry points.

title: Israel: Violent Intifada Anniversary
description: Hundreds of Palestinians clashed with Israeli security forces across the West Bank, East Jerusalem and Gaza on Friday as Palestinians marked the 13th anniversary of the outbreak of the second intifada, or uprising. In the West Bank, protesters hurled rocks and firebombs at Israeli forces, who responded with tear gas, rubber bullets and the limited use of live fire, according to an Israeli military spokeswoman. In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians marched toward the border with Israel and threw rocks at Israeli forces by the fence. In the central Gaza Strip, Hamas organized a demonstration led by masked gunmen carrying rockets. Dozens of Palestinians were injured, according to Palestinian news reports. The military said five Israeli soldiers had been injured by rocks.

title: A Diplomatic Apology for City Traffic
description: In the first conversation between the leaders of the United States and Iran since 1979, President Obama had a lot of ground to cover.

title: Police Continue Search for Suspect in L.I. Shootings
description: More than 100 law enforcement officers continued to search on Friday for a man who the authorities say shot two men at his former workplace in Nassau County, killing one and seriously wounding the other. The suspect, San Ho Kim, 63, fled after the shooting.

title: Collaborating Across Cultures
description: When Sidiki Conde and I get together to write a song, the process begins with a formal greeting and a hug. Good morning, says Sidiki. How are you? Im fine, I say, How are you? as if were testing the English language out to see if it works. Weve known each other since 1999, when I began taking djembe lessons with Sidiki. Since then weve worked in each others bands and discovered we share an uncanny musical connection, despite our vastly different cultures. The language Sidiki and I are most comfortable using with each other is the language of pure sound. We stumble through conversations in English, but the guitar, drum and our voices have no trouble communicating. That is the realm in which we meet and its the soil our songs spring from.

title: Now, the Hard Part
description: President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran showed leadership this week in committing themselves to resolving the dispute over Irans nuclear program. On Friday, they capped days of promising gestures with a phone call  the first direct contact between top American and Iranian leaders in more than three decades.

title: Toward Marriage Equality in New Jersey
description: A state judges welcome ruling on Friday that New Jersey must allow same-sex couples to marry was legally sound, full of common sense and a strong signal to the New Jersey Legislature to renew its efforts to make such unions legal.

title: Court Backs Owner of Site Occupied by Protesters
description: A federal judge has ruled that the real estate company that owns Zuccotti Park, where Occupy Wall Street protesters encamped in 2011, cannot be sued by protesters and journalists who were critical of the polices response to those protests.

title: For Love, Not the Game
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Amanda Blumenherst emerged from the customs zone at San Francisco International Airport last week after a work trip to France with two suitcases, a carry-on and her golf clubs. After four years as a golfing vagabond, she was steering her luggage cart toward the van that would take her to her next stop: domesticity.

title: Three Sisters (Not Chekhovs)
description: Its September, and schools in. Lets talk to some teachers, shall we?

title: In Proposals, Lhota Aims to Promote Job Growth
description: Joseph J. Lhota, seeking to flesh out a policy platform that received relatively little scrutiny during the mayoral primary in New York City, released an economic plan on Friday that aims to focus more attention on manufacturing and to reduce business and property taxes.

title: Exxon to Extend Health Care to Married Same-Sex Couples

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) LINCOLN (2012) Daniel Day-Lewis, below, in the role that won him his third Oscar for best actor, portrays Abraham Lincoln as he struggles to abolish slavery while the Civil War rages in this drama directed by Steven Spielberg from a screenplay by Tony Kushner. Sally Field plays Mary Todd Lincoln, his wife, who is grieving the death of their son Willie; Tommy Lee Jones is the abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens, who, along with his fellow Republican radicals, is demanding a vote on a Constitutional amendment; Hal Holbrook is Preston Blair, a party conservative who prefers peace talks with the Confederacy that evade a decisive solution. And David Strathairn is William Seward, Lincolns secretary of state, who is willing to trade patronage jobs for votes in Congress. The genius of Lincoln, finally, lies in its vision of politics as a noble, sometimes clumsy dialectic of the exalted and the mundane, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Our habit of argument, someone said recently, is a mark of our liberty, and Mr. Kushner, whose love of passionate, exhaustive disputation is unmatched in the modern theater, fills nearly every scene with wonderful, maddening talk. Mr. Spielbergs best art often emerges in passages of wordlessness, when the images speak for themselves, and the way he composes his pictures and cuts between them endows the speeches and debates with emotional force, and reminds us of what is at stake. Lincoln, he added, is a rough and noble democratic masterpiece  an omen, perhaps, that movies for the people shall not perish from the earth.
