title: The Progress Against Global Poverty
description: My Sunday column looks at something that has been happening over time so that we havent given it the attention it deserveseven though it may be the most important thing going on in history right now. Im referring to the decline of extreme poverty. When I was in college, a majority of the worlds people lived in extreme poverty, and the proportion will have dropped to virtually zero by the time I retire. Thats astounding progress, and its also reflected in mortality rates. When I was in college, around 15 million kids a year were dying annually. Now the figure has dropped to a bit more than 6 million, and in my lifetime the figure will drop below 1 million. Illiteracy is also on its way out. Look, we will still face immense problems  the US is a good example of how even a rich country can have a severe problem with an impoverished underclass  and some kinds of poverty will be with us for decades or centuries to come. But the kind Ive reported on in so many places, where illiterate parents have eight children who die young and are always on the edge of famine or disability, that kind of extreme poverty may be on its way out, along with river blindness, malaria, trachoma and other ailments.

description: At the Viktor & Rolf spring 2014 show, as covers of Pink Floyds Another Brick in the Wall and Britney Spearss Baby One More Time resounded overhead, the designers varsity-inspired collection was paired with sophisticated, toned-down makeup. Pat McGrath kept the face nude and dewy  adding that dewy is the new matte  and focused on a strong, boyish brow, using a variety of brow pencils and powders. Were making the brows darker, filling them in, she said. Were taking out the arches. To experiment with a strong brow off the runway, she recommended using products only one or two shades darker than ones natural brow color. The hairstyle, which Luigi Murenu created and described as a bit masculine in the front, also erred on the side of slightly subversive. The heightened roots were shellacked back into rockabilly stiffness, while the length of the hair was flat-ironed stick straight. Murenu summed it up as a street look but more glamorized. Its cool, its punky  not unlike the collection.

title: Dont Dress Your Toddler Like a Hipster
description: After watching my 3-year-old consider and reject 14 pairs of sneakers, I was just about beat and ready to call it a day when he spotted a pair of Crocs, the clunky and unfortunate footwear trend I was hoping would pass before my children caught wind of it. Of course, he loved them. And because it was nearing 8 p.m. and I was weak from hunger, I consented to purchasing the ugliest pair of shoes I swore I would never spend money on. And there was my son, sporting a style he loved, and I loathed.

description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A powerful car bomb ripped through a busy marketplace in Peshawar, the regional capital of northwestern Pakistan, early Sunday, killing at least 38 people in the third major attack in and around the city in the past week.

description: Luis Perez loves taking photographs. He shoots mostly on an iPhone, snapping gorgeous pictures of sunsets, vintage cars, old buildings and cute puppies. But when he arrives at a photo shoot, people are often startled when he pulls out a long white cane.

description: LONDON  Attempting to demonstrate that Britains Conservatives are on the side of working people, Prime Minister David Cameron on Sunday announced the acceleration of a program to increase home purchases.

description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ysaunny Brito before (left) and after (right) makeup by Aaron de May and hair by Anthony Turner.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (Showtime) MASTERS OF SEX Michael Sheen and Lizzy Caplan star as Dr. William H. Masters and his collaborator, Virginia Johnson, the groundbreaking researchers who sought to demystify arousal during the dark ages before the sexual revolution, in this new series based on Thomas Maiers biography Masters of Sex. He was a brilliant, obsessed and often imperious surgeon determined to make his name by decoding the physiology of pleasure. She was a former nightclub singer and sexually liberated woman with a desire for a career and a deft touch with people. Together they spent thousands of hours watching others masturbate and copulate while wired to monitors. They also had lots of sex with each other, though Johnson told Mr. Maier that at first she didnt want Masters  she wanted a job. Eventually, Masters left his wife to marry Johnson; they, too, later divorced. Though it takes liberties with facts and interpretation, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, the show does an elegant job of reframing their strange, complicated and at times deeply cynical partnership into a twisted but intriguing love story. Its enjoyable, she said, mainly because the actors are so good. Michael Sheen (above, with Nicholle Tom), who is best known for playing likable charmers like Tony Blair and David Frost, is convincing as a driven and stilted egotist, a man who has compassion for patients and almost no time for his infertile, unhappy wife, Libby (Caitlin FitzGerald). As Virginia, a twice-divorced single mother of two, Lizzy Caplan (Party Down, Bachelorette) is dazzling in a role that isnt easy: Virginia is sensual and sexy, strong-willed and good-humored, a modern woman trying to forge her own way in a world that is still backward about sex and the role of women. And, like sex, Ms. Stanley added, Masters of Sex gets better as it goes on.

title: Dueling Narratives in Iran Over U.S. Relations
description: Irans foreign minister said on Sunday that there was a real chance to reach an agreement with the United States over his countrys nuclear program, as long as Washington was prepared to end sanctions and recognize Tehrans right to peaceful nuclear enrichment.

title: Virtual Teamwork: Double Duty for One
description: The conventional video game controller is threatened with displacement, or at least diminished appreciation, in our Candy Crush Saga- and Angry Birds-obsessed era of finger swiping on cellphone screens. In the controllers defense stand those who say that the 16-button, twin-stick controllers  enticing and alienating as they may be  give players a sense of minimally acceptable, precise control.

description: Paris

title: Robert Barnard, Award-Winning Writer of British Crime Cozies, Dies at 76
description: Robert Barnard, an award-winning British crime writer known for skewering hypocrites, snobs and prigs in his cast of characters as energetically as he dispatched murder victims, died on Sept. 19 in Leeds, England. He was 76.

title: Philippine Standoff Ends, but Fighting Goes On
description: MANILA  Sporadic fighting continued Sunday in Zamboanga City, the embattled southern Philippine city where government officials a day earlier had declared an end to a three-week standoff with separatist militants.

title: China Sends a Real Estate Mogul to Prison
description: BEIJING  To millions of Chinese, the enterprising banker from the gritty northern province of Shaanxi is known by the nickname House Sister, and it is not exactly a term of endearment.

title: Tibetan Dies After Setting Himself on Fire
description: BEIJING  A Tibetan man in Chinas western Sichuan Province died on Saturday after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese policies in the region, according to Tibetan exile groups and Radio Free Asia, a news service financed by the United States government.

title: N.F.L. Protects the Pocket as Black Quarterbacks Transcend It
description: A reporter called recently and said he wanted to talk about a golden era of the black quarterback. A record nine African-Americans started at quarterback in Week 1 of the N.F.L. season, signaling to some that this was the beginning of a dynamic new day in the N.F.L.

title: Akris: Spring 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Paris: Pleated City for Chlo and Cline
description: What started as a ripple in New York, with Proenza Schoulers silver pleated skirts, has turned into an all-out spring trend, as both Phoebe Philo of Cline and Clare Waight Keller of Chlo showed pleated looks in their shows on Sunday. Raf Simons also made a statement in his Dior show with pleats.

title: Senate Action on Health Law Moves to Brink of Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate is expected to reject decisively a House bill that would delay the full effect of President Obamas health care law as a condition for keeping the government running past Monday, as Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, expressed confidence that he had public opinion on his side.

title: Greece Arrests Senior Members of Far-Right Party
description: ATHENS  Moving to drain power from one of the most violent rightist organizations in Europe, the Greek government conducted an extraordinary crackdown on the neo-fascist party Golden Dawn over the weekend, arresting six members of Parliament, including the leader of the group, and at least 15 other people.

title: Kipsang Sets World Record at Berlin Marathon
description: In late September, Berlin has become a kind of autobahn for marathon running, with seemingly no limits on speed, no strictures on the swift wonder of putting one foot in front of the other for 26.2 miles faster than any competitor who has come before.

title: Families Drive Cloudy 2 at Weekend Box Office
description: The lone family-friendly new release at the North American box office over the weekend, the animated comedy Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2 (Sony), dominated a crowded field of films aimed at adults to finish at No. 1 with estimated ticket sales of $35 million.

title: Once-Calm Area of Iraq Is Shaken by Bombings
description: BAGHDAD  Several explosions, some of them from suicide bombers, struck the heart of Iraqs northern Kurdish region on Sunday, setting off chaos and gunfights in the streets of the capital, Erbil.

title: Some Bipartisan Support for Repeal of Medical Device Tax
description: The House voted in the early hours of Sunday to rescind a tax on medical devices that pays for a part of the health care law and delay the health care law by a year as conditions for financing government operations and avoiding a shutdown.

title: Glow Art Festival Illuminates a Beach
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  It took an entire week for Janet Echelman  along with a team that included a composer, landscape architects, lighting technicians and a bulldozer crew  to construct her art installation in the sand along the beach here. They dug a crater and strung enormous, handmade fishing nets overhead that were illuminated with colored light. It was the most expensive piece at this years Glow, this citys all-night, interactive art festival.

title: Nowhere to Run: Public Housing Elevators Remain Crime Magnets
description: The 13-year-old girl walked into the elevator on a Sunday summer morning, pressing the button for her floor. As soon as the elevator door in the South Jamaica Houses in Queens slid shut, a man who had followed the girl draped his left arm around her, pulling her close.

title: Health Insurance Exchanges Scramble to Be Ready as Opening Day Nears
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Rocky King, the executive director of Oregons new health insurance exchange, has done everything in his power to tamp down expectations for its opening on Tuesday.

title: George Bignotti, Master Mechanic of the Indianapolis 500, Dies at 97
description: George Bignotti, the record-setting chief mechanic of major American oval-track racing and a pioneer in making the successful transition from front-engine roadsters to sophisticated rear-engine Indianapolis 500 cars, died Friday at his home in Las Vegas. Bignotti, a native of San Francisco, was 97.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Musicians Reject Latest Contract Offer
description: The players of the Minnesota Orchestra voted on Saturday to reject managements latest contract proposal, the fourth since April 2012. The previous contract expired last year on Oct. 1, and the players have since been locked out, a standoff that killed the orchestras 2012-13 season.

title: Resignations in Italy Put Government in Crisis
description: ROME  Prime Minister Enrico Letta said that he would call for a confidence vote in Parliament, most likely on Wednesday, to clear up the political uncertainty surrounding his fragile government after the sudden resignation of five ministers belonging to Silvio Berlusconis center-right party.

title: In BP Trial, the Amount of Oil Lost Is at Issue
description: HOUSTON  With billions of dollars in penalties at stake, the civil trial of the British oil company BP begins its second phase on Monday, which will set the amount of oil that spilled into the Gulf of Mexico from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon rig explosion that killed 11 workers and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Wave-Inspired Eyelids at Kenzo
description: To complement Kenzos beach-themed collection, the makeup artist Aaron de Mey used a bright white stripe on the upper lash line to evoke the crests of waves. De Mey used a fine, angled brush to apply the bold potion from a M.A.C. Paint Pot. The finish is not at all chalky, he explained. Its very matte. The shape of the line is blunt at the ends, to get a slightly more aggressive, punk feeling. De Mey offered advice for applying liquid liner, an ever-daunting beauty task, at home: Start the line in the middle of the eye, and then pull it outwards, and wing it. Always look towards the end of the eyebrow to give you direction. Then start the line again at the very inner corner, and bring it to the center to meet. Thats a good way to balance it.

title: Chiefs Deflate Giants Momentum, Sending Them to Another Loss
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Giants patchwork offensive line had played reasonably well. The teams running game, while not overpowering, was not a hopeless liability for the first time this season. Eli Manning had time to throw, even if his receivers were dropping some passes. The Giants, for a change, did not have a ton of turnovers, and their defense, which had yielded only one touchdown, had recovered a fumble and intercepted two passes.

description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

description: Lydia DePillis has an interesting piece interviewing Paul Stebbins  a CEO who was very involved with Fix the Debt  in which Stebbins acknowledges that business is part of the problem in Washington, and proceeds to illustrate, unintentionally, just why that is. You see, if hes any indication, big business is completely clueless about both the economics and the politics of the situation.

description: LONDON  On his nationwide tour of N.F.L. stadiums a few years ago, Adam Goldstein sampled just about every delicacy tailgaters cooked up: cheese steaks, jambalaya, bratwurst, clam chowder and once, to his dismay, raccoon fajitas.

description: ALBANY  With a little more than five weeks until voters decide whether to authorize up to seven full-scale casinos around New York, the states Roman Catholic bishops on Sunday warned of social problems linked with gambling, but did not tell residents how to vote on Nov. 5.

description: Shortly before New York City Opera put on what will most likely be its final performance on Saturday night, Julius Rudel, the maestro who helped build and lead the company in its heyday, sat in his Manhattan apartment and, surrounded by mementos from the troupes glory days, expressed his dismay at its probable impending demise.

title: Bahrain Dissidents Said to Get Prison Sentences
description: ISTANBUL  A court in Bahrain handed down sentences of between 5 and 15 years in jail for 50 people on Sunday whom the authorities accused of belonging to a protest movement seeking to overthrow the government, human rights activists said.

description: Scenes from the concert in Central Park.

description: MINNEAPOLIS  The day began with three teams vying for two American League wild-card berths. For the Cleveland Indians, it ended with a begoggled Nick Swisher drenched in Champagne in the visitors clubhouse at Target Field, a bottle of it in his hand, standing on soggy plastic while looking for somebody to hug.

title: Spy Activities
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Put on your dark sunglasses, turn up your trench coat collars, and join me as we meet our minder, Ian Livengood, who is currently out standing in his field. And if you werent able to make it to the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament held at Will Shortzs table tennis club, fear not: the Monday through Thursday puzzles you solve this week are the very same ones that the contestants solved there, but without the ping pong.

title: The Mets Recall the Past, Then Look to the Future
description: Fans flocked to Citi Field on Sunday to celebrate Mike Piazza and the best of the Mets past.

title: Still Meaty, Film Festival Lightens Up
description: A Ben Stiller comedy in the New York Film Festival? Well, why not? Four years ago, amid complaints that the festival expressed a snobbish, ivory-tower contempt for movies as popular entertainment, such a possibility seemed unthinkable.

title: A Rare Cutting From a Garden of Another Era
description: Alma Whittaker, the large, spinsterly botanist who carries Elizabeth Gilberts new book, The Signature of All Things, on her strong shoulders, is a born scholar. She knows every species of plant on her fathers vast estate. Calculus puts her into fits of ecstasies. She reads in many languages, the older the better, even if this knowledge can be a hindrance. When Almas mother faints, the daughters mind leaps from Latin (bring me sal volatile) to chemistry (ammonium carbonate) to archaic chemistry (spirit of hartshorn) to Pliny the Elder (hammoniacus sal) before she can make herself clear to the plebeians on her staff. Smelling salts! is what she meant to demand.

title: Experimenting Begins as the Music Starts to Play
description: Atoms for Peace signaled what theyd be up to just a few minutes into their opening song, Before Your Very Eyes, at Barclays Center on Friday night. The bands most mobile musicians, the singer Thom Yorke of Radiohead and the bassist Flea from the Red Hot Chili Peppers, had already begun what would be a full set of nearly nonstop, merrily unsynchronized dance moves: Mr. Yorke with jittery head, shoulders, hands and feet, and Flea with rubbery long legs and limber hips. The dance music they were making for themselves wasnt taking anything for granted.

title: Musical Celebration With the Highest of Aspirations
description: NEWARK  Im not a big fan of gala opening nights, which tend to be all about fancy dress, floral arrangements, celebrity guests and a feel-good repertory that extends from canon fodder to bonbon. On Friday evening at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra kicked off its 91st season with a gala program that aimed higher, showing that its possible to impart a meaningful artistic experience without spoiling anyones fun.

title: Giddy Freedom (a Little Mambo!), as Well as Pianistic Elegance and Wit
description: Work began in earnest on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall for the New York Philharmonic after a weeklong flirtation with film music and Wednesdays season-opening gala. But there were many moments during this first subscription concert, in which Alan Gilbert conducted works by Ravel, Bernstein and Tchaikovsky, when the musicians seemed to be having far too much fun to justify the word work.

title: American Team Wins Venice Cup in Indonesia
description: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, which ended Sunday, the American teams won two events and were second once.

title: A Big, Booming Show With Space for Reflection
description: The great virtue of Massive Attack V Adam Curtis, a 90-minute concert and film that opened at the Park Avenue Armory on Saturday night and runs through Friday, is the space afforded you to listen and think. I mean space in the physical and metaphorical sense. The Armory is huge, and the echoey, bass-heavy, slow-moving sound of the British band Massive Attack, playing live behind a few of the 11 surrounding screens, feels pretty capacious, too.

title: Just for Fun
description: Scenes from the New York City Ballet program at Lincoln Center.

title: An Impish Faun, Swans, and a Lively Card Deck
description: Animals, playing cards, seasons: in all three items in the Just for Fun program at New York City Ballet on Friday, dancers continually portrayed something other than themselves. The program, at the David H. Koch Theater, encouraged you to see ballet as an art of representation.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 30
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Public Advocate Runoff on Tuesday
description: On Tuesday, Oct. 1, New York City will hold a runoff primary to choose a Democratic nominee for the office of public advocate, because no candidate received 40 percent of the vote or more in the Sept. 10 primary. The two candidates are Letitia James, a city councilwoman, and Daniel L. Squadron, a state senator.

title: India and Pakistan Talk, but Tensions Are High
description: LONDON  The leaders of Pakistan and India held their first official meeting in New York on Sunday, leaving with renewed promises of mutual restraint in Kashmir but little real hope for a fresh start in relations.

title: A Swing and a Jaunt Around the Globe
description: When the Fall for Dance Festival works, it seems as if youve taken a trip around the world. The second program was unveiled on Friday night at City Center. The voyage started in India with the company Nrityagram and ended uptown with the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: Fall for Dance
description: Images from the festival at City Center.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Cline Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Sept. 30
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes construction spending for August, the Institute of Supply Managements manufacturing index for September and auto sales for September (Tuesday); the ADP employment report (Wednesday); initial jobless claims for the latest week, the Challenger report on job cuts, factory orders for August and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index (Thursday); and the Labor Departments employment report for September.

title: Editing Wikipedia Pages for Med School Credit
description: Medical students at the University of California, San Francisco, will be able to get course credit for editing Wikipedia articles about diseases, part of an effort to improve the quality of medical articles in the online encyclopedia and help distribute the articles globally via cellphones. While professors often incorporate Wikipedia work into classes, hoping that student research can live on online, the university and others say this is the first time a medical school will give credit for such work.

title: Apple Passes Coca-Cola as Most Valuable Brand
description: APPLE is the new most valuable brand in the world, according to a closely followed annual report.

description: Accounts

title: House Republicans Demand Senate Appear
description: Republican members of the House assembled on the steps of Congress and said the Senate should have opened a special Sunday session ahead of a looming government shutdown. A woman passing by responded.

title: U.S. Plans to Unveil New Insurance Options
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans on Monday to announce scores of new health insurance options to be offered to consumers around the country by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association and the United States Office of Personnel Management, the agency that arranges health benefits for federal employees, according to administration officials.

title: China Ban on Items for Nuclear Use to North Korea May Stall Arms Bid
description: BEIJING  During the George W. Bush era, North Korea and Iran were joined together as the Axis of Evil, but with President Obamas phone call to President Hassan Rouhani of Iran last week, that pairing  already out of favor in some quarters in Washington  was no longer so tight. It is virtually impossible, analysts say, to imagine Mr. Obama reaching out anytime soon to the leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, who has already tested a nuclear bomb and threatened to stage a nuclear attack against the United States.

title: For Journalists, More Firepower to Protect Sources and Secrets
description: Earlier this year, federal investigators secretly obtained two months of phone records of reporters and editors at The Associated Press, including calls on their home phones and cellphones. They did so without providing notice to The A.P., which could have asked a judge to quash the requests, or at least negotiated the scope of the investigation. It was an extraordinary incursion into the operations of a news organization, but the Justice Department did not violate any laws, which manages to be both comforting and shocking at the same time.

title: British Game Maker Behind Candy Crush Seeking I.P.O. in U.S.
description: The game maker King has conquered the mobile gaming world from its home base in London. Now, King, the company that created Candy Crush Saga, has its eye set on becoming a top technology initial public offering  across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Talk of Dynasty Adds to Buzz Surrounding Young Blackhawks
description: CHICAGO  On the first day of Chicago Blackhawks training camp, the questions came hard and fast. They were not about line pairings or the familiar early-season talk of expectations. These queries were larger in scope, more historical in perspective: Are the Blackhawks a budding dynasty?

title: Citys Web Site is Redesigned for First Time in a Decade
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has spent much of his three terms shepherding New Yorks march into the Internet age. He has encouraged the creation of new apps for finding public bathrooms and avoiding dangerous bike routes, among others. He has deployed a squad of data-crunchers to streamline everyday services. And one of his dearest wishes has been to transform the city into a second Silicon Valley.

title: Memorable End for Two; Forgettable Year for Yanks
description: HOUSTON  There was little emotion left to squeeze from the Yankees by the time the Houston Astros put on their show to honor Mariano Rivera on Sunday.

title: Jean Anyon Dies at 72; Wrote Ghetto Schooling
description: If I had a gun Id kill you, the teacher said. Youre all hoodlums.

title: Intel and Sony Ambitions for Internet TV Services Meet Skepticism
description: Television services delivered via the Internet by companies like Intel and Sony could someday transform how Americans watch TV shows. But the services have to get off the ground first, and there are new doubts about whether that is going to happen.

title: Amid Nuclear Issue, Israel Said to Arrest Iranian Spy
description: JERUSALEM  Israel announced Sunday that it had recently arrested an Iranian spy who had photographed the United States Embassy building in Tel Aviv, among other things, in what appeared to be a serendipitous catch as Israel scrambled to ward off any speedy international embrace of the new Iranian leadership.

title: Marcella Hazan, Author Who Changed the Way Americans Cook Italian Food, Dies at 89
description: In his early days as a rising star chef, Mario Batali received a letter from Marcella Hazan after he had made risotto in a saut pan on his television show, Molto Mario.

title: Rei Kawakubo Says a Lot With Nothing
description: PARIS  It is a familiar scene, cartoonish in its intensity. One by one, on a plywood runway that rises at the center like a bridge through a garden, the models come out and stop under a spotlight swinging on a metal arm. It sweeps each womans outfit with light as the music, at first classical, dissolves in static.

title: The Glass-Floor Problem
description: WHEN it comes to the economic malaise facing America, the biggest problem is not the widening gap between rich and poor, but the stagnation of social mobility. When the income gap of one generation becomes an opportunity gap for the next, inequality hardens into social stratification.

title: The House Rushes to a Shutdown
description: This time, it wasnt just a few Tea Party hotheads who drove the United States government to the brink of shutting down. Early Sunday morning, all 231 House Republicans (along with 17 Democrats) decided that crippling health care reform was more important than keeping the governments doors open. It was one of the most irresponsible votes since the last shutdown in 1996.

title: Psychotherapys Image Problem
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  PSYCHOTHERAPY is in decline. In the United States, from 1998 to 2007, the number of patients in outpatient mental health facilities receiving psychotherapy alone fell by 34 percent, while the number receiving medication alone increased by 23 percent.

title: Nixon and Kissingers Forgotten Shame
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  BANGLADESH is in fresh turmoil. On Sept. 17, its Supreme Court decided that Abdul Quader Mollah, a leading Islamist politician, should be hanged for war crimes committed during the countrys 1971 war of independence from Pakistan. When he was given a life sentence by a Bangladeshi war-crimes tribunal back in February, tens of thousands of Bangladeshis took to the streets demanding his execution. Since then, more than a hundred people have died in protests and counterprotests.

title: Our Outlaw President?
description: WASHINGTON  THE United States government is likely to shut down nonessential services tomorrow, after House Republicans voted before dawn yesterday to attach a one-year delay of President Obamas health care law (and a repeal of a tax to pay for it) to legislation to keep the government running. The Democratic-led Senate is expected to refuse.

title: Shrinking List of Video Games Is Dominated by Blockbusters
description: Big video game makers, like their cousins in books and music, have scrambled in recent years to adapt to the digital technologies buffeting their business. Tens of millions of people now play games on smartphones and tablets, usually for a sliver of the cost of playing on a game console.

title: In Trial, Romania Warily Revisits a Brutal Past
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Remembered as a brutal sadist by inmates who managed to survive the prisons he once ran, Alexandru Visinescu bubbles with violent fury. Get away from my door, or do you want me to get a stick and beat you? the 88-year-old former prison commander screamed recently when a reporter called at his fourth floor apartment in the center of this capital city.

title: Tennessee Turns Smiths Giveaways Into Touchdowns
description: NASHVILLE  All that is new and supposedly improved about the Jets this season  the starting quarterback, the offensive philosophy, Rex Ryans coaching staff  was viewed at LP Field on Sunday with a fair amount of skepticism: the theme music to The Benny Hill Show accompanied their pregame stampede out of the tunnel.

title: Writing Off Lives
description: The prison population in the United States has declined modestly in recent years after three decades of growth. This is partly the result of saner sentencing policies for nonviolent drug offenders, who are more likely to be given probation and drug treatment than in the past.

title: The Fault in Those Web Site Stars
description: Having consumers review restaurants, contractors or even doctors is a healthy concept. The problem, as New Yorks attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, explained last week, is that some of those online reviews are fakes, written by people who are paid for them. And that, he said, is worse than old-fashioned false advertising. He announced agreements with 19 companies to stop manufacturing fake reviews. The companies also agreed to pay a total of $350,000 in penalties.

title: In Florida, the Front Lines of a High-Pitched, Bite-Size War
description: MARATHON, Fla.  Much has changed since 1929 when newcomers to Florida, fed up with swarms of mosquitoes, erected a bat tower in Sugarloaf Key, hoping the bats would succeed where they had failed. Badly outnumbered, the bats abandoned the tower, leaving the monumental task to the locals.

title: Birth Control and a Bosss Religious Views
description: The Obama administrations rule requiring employer health plans to cover birth control without a co-payment has given rise to a slew of lawsuits by private companies claiming the mandate attacks religious freedom. Three federal appeals courts have ruled on the issue, with two correctly rejecting that view as without legal foundation. Given the conflicting rulings, it is a good bet the Supreme Court will agree to address this issue in the next term.

title: Grand Theft Auto Franchise Playfully Flicks Mud at Its Birthplace: Scotland
description: Since its introduction 16 years ago, the wildly popular video game franchise Grand Theft Auto has been set in some of the most recognizable cities in the United States. There were New York, Miami and San Francisco, and in the fifth installment, released to great fanfare this month, Los Angeles.

title: For the Washington Area, a Second Lightning Strike
description: WASHINGTON  A temporary shutdown of much of the federal government, disruptive though it might be, would probably have only a modest effect on the governments cost of doing business and would do minimal damage to the economy over all. But not so for the capital region.

title: Kreider Will Begin Season in Minors for Rangers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Their preseason over, the Rangers on Sunday trimmed their roster to 24 players, and there were a few surprises.

title: S.E.C. Again Takes On Mark Cuban in Insider Case

title: Left Behind At Chickamauga
description: For the title of his definitive book on the Battle of Chickamauga, the historian (and Disunion contributor) Peter Cozzens took three words from the diary of a Union soldier who fought there. This Terrible Sound, as described by Pvt. Alva Griest of the 72nd Indiana Infantry, did not refer to the ear-splitting cacophony that usually prevailed on a Civil War battlefield  the roar of cannons, the crack of muskets and the shrieks of a charging enemy  but a worse, more heart-rending sound that haunted him for years afterward. Like every other soldier, federal and Confederate alike, who spent the night of Sept. 19, 1863, on the front lines, Griest was deeply affected by the groans from thousands of wounded in our front crying in anguish and pain, some for death to relieve them, others for water. Oh, if I could only drown this terrible sound, and yet I may also lie thus ere tomorrows sun crosses the heavens.

description: The Senate voted 54 to 46 on Monday to remove the most contentious elements of a budget bill favored by Republicans, sending back to the House a measure that would keep the government running and leave President Obamas health care law intact.

description: Judging from the markets and the blame-laying happening in Washington, there will be no last-minute deal to save the country from a government shutdown.

description: Backed by near-unanimous critical praise, incessant social media conversation and intense coverage on every form of talk show, Breaking Bad soared to its highest ratings ever  and one of the top ratings of all time for a drama on cable television  in its finale Sunday night on AMC.

title: Westerners Smuggled Letters Offer Glimpse of Egyptian Prisons
description: CAIRO  The prisoners were stripped and beaten, and their heads were shaved. They slept packed like sardines on concrete floors of cells infested with cockroaches. One said that an open wound on his arm was left oozing, that a cellmate suffered a heart attack without getting medical attention, and that another prisoner was 11 years old.

title: Powerful North Indian Politician Is Convicted of Siphoning Funds
description: NEW DELHI  A longtime political heavyweight from northern India, Lalu Prasad, was found guilty on Monday of participating in a scheme that siphoned off public money for more than a decade, ending a trial that was seen as a watershed in Indias struggle with corruption.

title: Obama Says He Isnt Resigned to a Shutdown
description: As a midnight deadline for Congress to finance the domestic and military operations of government, President Obama has largely remained on the sidelines  in wait and see mode as one aide put it  as Congress prepares for the latest go-round in the debate over financing the government and Mr. Obamas signature health care law.

title: Republicans Reject Prospect of One-Week Extension
description: Though Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, briefly floated the idea of a one-week stop-gap measure to fund the government and avert, at least briefly, a government shutdown, House Republicans repeatedly rejected the idea as they walked into their closed-door conference meeting Monday afternoon.

title: Need Birth Control Advice, Fast? Text Planned Parenthood
description: When teenagers or young adults need advice from an organization like Planned Parenthood, they tend to think they need that advice now  not the next time they can grab an educator after health class, not the next time they are alone and can call a hotline, and certainly not at their next appointment for reproductive health services, if they even have such an appointment. This is now as in, the condom broke; my periods late; or I told him to pull out and he didnt.

description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Magdalena Jasek before (left) and after (right) makeup by Val Garland and hair by Orlando Pita.

description: As our colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, smuggled letters from three North Americans detained during Egypts security crackdown last month offer a rare outsiders perspective on longstanding Egyptian prison conditions.

title: Knicks Pick Up Their Option on Woodson for 2014-15
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Knicks Coach Mike Woodson ponders how to get his star player, Carmelo Anthony, the ball in space. He works to make sure J. R. Smith stays disciplined  on and off the court. Woodson searches for the correct workload for Amare Stoudemire and his aging, tender knees.

description: WASHINGTON  Neither President Obama nor Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel mentioned Hassan Rouhani after their meeting at the White House on Monday morning.

title: F.A.A. Panel Backs Easing of Device Rules
description: Airline passengers should be allowed to use their personal electronic devices to read, play games or enjoy movies and music, even when planes are on the ground or flying below 10,000 feet, according to recommendations an advisory panel sent to the Federal Aviation Administration on Monday.

title: Nielsen Deal For Arbitron Is Complete
description: Nielsen Holdings announced on Monday that it had completed its $1.26 billion acquisition of the radio ratings company Arbitron, a deal that Nielsen says will allow it to monitor eight hours a day of the publics media consumption across television, radio and a range of electronic devices.

title: An Ex-Trader, Now a Sociologist, Looks at the Changes in Goldman
description: There once was a time, before JPMorgan Chases woes dominated headlines, when Goldman Sachs was the symbol for Wall Streets dark side. Its depiction as a bloodsucking vampire squid in a Rolling Stone article captured the publics imagination. And Why I Am Leaving Goldman Sachs, a damning resignation letter published as an opinion article in The New York Times, also touched a nerve.

title: Obama Confident, but Wary of Economic Fallout
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama expressed confidence on Monday that he was right to defy House Republicans demands as the hours ticked away toward a government shutdown. Yet offsetting the bravado at the White House was fear of what Octobers unfolding events could mean for the economy.

title: Big Bids and Bigger Crowds at Long-Awaited Lambrecht Auction
description: PIERCE, Neb.  It was early in the bidding, and the auctioneer was still warming her pitch, trying to stir up the crowd of thousands pressed against her mobile stage, a flatbed trailer in a soybean field.

title: India and Nokia in Tax Dispute Before Microsoft Deal
description: LONDON  The tax authorities in India froze Nokias assets there last week in a dispute over tax payments, but Nokia, the Finnish cellphone company, said on Monday that it had regained access to its Indian bank accounts.

title: Obama Not Resigned to a Shutdown
description: On Monday, President Obama said that he was not at all resigned to a government shutdown, and indicated that he expected to speak with Congressional leaders in the coming days.

description: ALTON, Iowa  It has come on like a tidal wave, washing across the Corn Belt from Minnesota to the Texas panhandle, a disease that few farmers had seen until five years ago.

title: Iran Signals Cultural Thaw With Oscar Choice
description: Irans hostile political attitude towards the United States isnt the only thing that has been in flux since a new president, Hassan Rouhani, took office in August. There are also signs of an incipient cultural thaw, made most evident this weekend when the countrys film selection committee chose to submit Asghar Farhadis The Past as its candidate for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film.

description: Carrie White, played by Chlo Grace Moretz, coming home from the prom.

title: Weekend Gun Report: September 27-29, 2013
description: The number of children accidentally shot and killed by adults or other children in America is higher than previously reported, according to a front-page story in yesterdays Times. A review of hundreds of child firearm deaths by Michael Luo and Mike McIntire found that accidental shootings occur roughly twice as often as records indicate because of idiosyncrasies in how such deaths are classified by the authorities: more than half of the 259 accidental firearm deaths of kids under age 15 identified by The Times in eight states were not recorded as accidents. Such shootings are routinely classified as homicides, a common practice when one person unintentionally shoots another.

title: Should Slowing Trade Growth Worry Us?
description: Ive spent most of today both under pressure to get an assignment out the door and under the weather; still sniffling, but the piece has been emailed off, so a bit of time for the blog. Except I feel like taking a vacation from both the shutdown and Obamacare. So lets talk about trade  specifically, a recent post by Gavyn Davies, Why world trade growth has lost its mojo, which expresses deep concern over the fact that in recent years trade hasnt grown much faster than global GDP. He suggests that hidden protectionism may be partly to blame, and that this may have large economic costs.

title: Bloomberg Says City Opera Is On Its Own
description: Updated, 6:48 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not riding to the rescue of New York City Opera, which has said that it plans to file for bankruptcy and dissolve itself if it fails to raise $7 million by the end of Monday.

title: Polls in Overtime on Affordable Care Act
description: Several national and state polls have been released in the days leading up to the open enrollment period of the Affordable Care Act (A.C.A.). Heres a roundup of their findings:

title: Old Atrocities, Now Official, Galvanize Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  So many people were buried alive by bulldozers in the barren fields around the Pul-e-Charkhi Prison on Kabuls outskirts that guilty soldiers later said it was like an earthquake as their victims tried to claw their way out.

title: The Board of Elections: An Ongoing Disgrace
description: Elections in New York City are an ongoing disgrace.In a city whereeverything is supposed to happen faster than anywhere else (hence the New York minute), the Board of Elections took more than two weeks to count votes after the primary election on September 10  finally finishing on Friday, September 27. Thats an eon by todays standards, and its an embarrassment.

title: For Markets, a Shutdown Is Usually a Ripple
description: As a government shutdown draws closer, many analysts are looking to past shutdowns for some guide as to what might happen  particularly in the markets. The precedent is not all that frightening, according to data put together by Joseph P. Quinlan, chief market strategist at U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management. The chart below shows how much the Standard & Poors 500-stock index moved from the beginning of the shutdown to the end. The last time it happened, in early 1996, the market actually ended up slightly.

title: CBGB Festival Is Expanding in Its Second Year
description: My Morning Jacket, the Wallflowers and Grizzly Bear will perform free concerts in Times Square on Oct. 12 as part of the second annual CBGB Music and Film Festival, the events organizers said.

title: BMW Recalls 76,000 Vehicles for Brake Booster Problem
description: BMW will recall about 76,000 vehicles from the 2012-14 model years that are equipped with turbocharged 2-liter 4-cylinder engines because of a loss of power brake assist, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Cuckoo Finches Come Up With a New Con
description: Scientists have discovered still another trick in the portfolio of brood parasites  the birds that deceitfully lay their eggs in the nests of other species, that way increasing their own numbers by duping other mothers into raising their young.

title: Reid Denounces House Republicans Over Health Law
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, has made little secret of his disdain for Tea Party Republicans, saying they will own the blame for any government shutdown.

title: Turkish Premier Announces Proposals Aimed at Kurds
description: ISTANBUL  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced a package of measures on Monday that appeared intended to revive the stalled peace process with the countrys ethnic Kurds, who have fought a decades-long insurgency against the Turkish state.

title: New Government Shutdown, New Rules
description: In November 1995, Newt Gingrich, then speaker of the House, led an effort that resulted in a shutdown of the federal government. Now, Congressional Republicans have done the same.

title: On the Verge | Pasadena, a Place With Many Hidden Charms
description: Everyone knows that Los Angeles is having an art and fashion renaissance. But the transformation of Pasadena, its eastern neighbor, has happened under the radar. Developed in the 1880s as a winter retreat for the East Coast elite, the sedate college town at the foot of the San Gabriel Mountains has long been an antipode to Hollywood, a place with family-friendly neighborhoods, numerous Ph.Ds from the Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Caltech, and a general air of all-American normalcy. Fashion types usually only come out for the monthly Rose Bowl Flea Market. Pasadena is so uncool that Rodarte designers Kate and Laura Mulleavys address there is often cited as evidence of their status as fashion outsiders.

title: 3 Teams, 27 Games, 2 Losses
description: Although baseballs decision to go with two wild-card teams in each league has a gimmicky feel to it, there was nothing dubious about the way the top three American League wild-card contenders played down the stretch as they vied for a spot in the postseason.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Washington, Iraq, Italy and Syria.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (ESPN) HAWAIIAN: THE LEGEND OF EDDIE AIKAU In this 30 for 30 entry, the director Sam George chronicles the life and times of Mr. Aikau, the Hawaiian surfer and lifeguard who made a name at Waimea Bay by riding monster waves said to reach heights of 40 feet  and in the process inspiring bumper stickers that said Eddie Would Go. He died in 1978, when, as a crew member on a Polynesian voyaging canoe that was following an ancient route between Tahiti and Hawaii, he paddled on his surfboard for help after the vessel had capsized south of Molokai.

title: Britain Plans to Require Community Service for Long-Term Unemployment Benefits
description: LONDON  Jobless Britons could be forced to do community work to keep their unemployment payments, Britains top economics minister said Monday, announcing the latest in a series of moves to tighten benefits rules and crack down on welfare dependency.

title: Sampling a Humpback's Breath
description: Researchers from the Provincetown Center for Coastal Studies pursue a humpback whale to catch the spray from its blowhole, which turns out to have all kinds of good data in it.

title: In the Kitchen, Talk of Love, Life and Art
description: Who can say whether one of Shakespeares sisters was a frustrated writer, as Virginia Woolf imagined in A Room of Ones Own? But Peter Brooks daughter, Irina Brook, is by now an established director, albeit still firmly in her fathers shadow, so its easy to understand why Woolfs scenario would be too tempting for her to resist.

title: A Sew-Sew Labor Market
description: For years people like me have been engaged in a running argument with people who insist that the reason we have high unemployment is that American workers dont have the skills required for a 21st-century economy. Its normally implied, although not always stated, that were talking about technological skills, knowledge of science and math, and in general the cutting edge.

title: A Wealth of Data in Whale Breath
description: MYSTIC, Conn.  On her trainers command, an alabaster-skinned beluga whale named Naku placed her chin on the deck of her outdoor pool and exhaled several times, emitting a hollow chuff sound with each breath. The vapor rose into a petri dish a researcher held over her blowhole.

title: Amanda Knoxs Retrial Begins in Italy
description: ROME  Amanda Knox, the American student who was convicted and later acquitted of killing her British roommate, went on trial again in Italy on Monday, but neither she, nor her former Italian boyfriend and co-defendant, Raffaele Sollecito, were in court.

title: Life Is Long, but Then So Are the Country Roads of Argentina
description: Stories of humanized hit men make for a small but well-trod patch of screenwriting terrain, but The Dead Man and Being Happy quickly transcends that territory to become a beguiling road movie. Directed by Javier Rebollo and written with Lola Mayo and Salvador Roselli, this reserved, tragicomic story of existential flight across Argentina is defined by its shifting, literary voice-over about the textured, wide-screen expanses crossed by its protagonist.

title: In Opening Prayer, Senate Chaplain Touches on Politics
description: When the Senate began its new legislative day on Monday as it customarily does with a prayer, the chaplain, the Rev. Dr. Barry C. Black, departed from his usual apolitical messages and asked God to help senators remember that all that is necessary for unintended catastrophic consequences is for good people to do nothing.

title: Defining and Demanding a Musicians Fair Shake in the Internet Age
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In the music business, they still talk about the Lars curse.

title: Breast-Feeding Services Lag Behind the Law
description: Under the Affordable Care Act, insurance companies are required to pay for breast pumps and counseling for new mothers to address breast-feeding problems. The aim is to encourage more women to breast-feed so their infants can reap the health benefits, including reduced risks of asthma, leukemia and Type 2 diabetes.

title: A Quake Shakes Loose an Island
description: A small island that appeared in the Arabian Sea off Pakistan after an earthquake last week most likely formed when the shaking released methane gas and water trapped in undersea sediments. The gas and water forced part of the seabed to the surface, experts said.

title: Triple Play: Week 26 Results
description: There did not seem to be any rush to win the National League batting title. Michael Cuddyer of the Rockies hung on to win with a .331 average, but he hit .250 for the week (4 for 16). The Braves Chris Johnson, meanwhile, was 2 for 19 and finished at .321. Andrew McCutchen of the Pirates, the top choice with nearly 40 percent, was 5 for 19 but finished at .317.

description: All it takes for an easy, breezy getaway is a classic carryall  so roomy you can take it with you.

description: Kimberly Peirce, whose new film is a remake of Carrie, was profiled in this past weekends magazine. Here, she describes behind-the-scenes footage of a scene in which Carrie White, played by Chlo Grace Moretz, comes home after the prom (there is no audio in the beginning of the clip).

description: President Obama castigated House Republicans for failing to perform a basic function by not providing money for the government. He said a shutdown would harm the economic recovery.

description: In a mixed week at the box office for most Broadway shows, the new revival of The Glass Menagerie enjoyed unusually strong ticket sales after theater critics weighed in Thursday night with stellar reviews for the production and its cast, led by the two-time Tony Award winner Cherry Jones.

description: Whether its arepas, tortillas or pupusas, masa remains a Latin American cornerstone.

description: Without the tortilla, there is no taco. And, as the Mexican saying goes: Sin maz, no hay pas.

title: Peeling Off Layers to Find an Underlying Truth
description: Over the past few years, the Park Avenue Armory has built a reputation for thinking big. Outsize art installations and immersive performances of music, theater and dance presented in the 55,000-square-foot drill hall often become the talk of the town.

description: Care to comment on a Popular Science article  say, These Magnetic Nanobots Could Carry Drugs Into Your Brain or FYI: Do Animals Have Orgasms?

description: The Timess Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the unexpectedly high viewership for the Breaking Bad finale.

title: A Noticeable Thawing at Saint Laurent
description: Since we last met at Saint Laurent and the ongoing reinvention of the storied Parisian label by Hedi Slimane, the tides have turned remarkably in the designers favor. Coverage in fashion magazines of his fall collection, shown in February, has been overwhelmingly positive, prompting grunge features in W, Vogue, Elle, Harpers Bazaar, and thats just in the United States.

title: Traditional Folk Frolic, With Old-Time Fervor and Youthful Yelps
description: The folk revival of the 1950s and 60s was a tangle of contradictions from the start, and half a century later, those contradictions have only multiplied. They were just part of the charm of Another Day, Another Time, a concert on Sunday night at Town Hall spun off from Inside Llewyn Davis, a film by Joel and Ethan Coen that is set in Greenwich Village in 1961 and loosely derived from the peregrinations of Dave Van Ronk.

title: Warner Bros. Agrees to Deal for Financial Backing
description: LOS ANGELES  Warner Brothers and RatPac-Dune Entertainment said that they had agreed to a deal under which Warner will receive financial backing for as many as 75 films over four years or more.

title: What the F.A.A. Is Considering on Devices
description: Q. What are the changes that the F.A.A. is considering?

title: Battles Without End
description: In his deeply affecting 2009 book, The Good Soldiers, David Finkel gave us a harrowing and unnervingly intimate picture of the Iraq war as seen by members of an Army battalion sent to Baghdad during the surge in 2007. This was not Washingtons macro war, but the micro war on the ground, made up of specific acts of bravery and tragedy experienced by the soldiers of Battalion 2-16 as they patrolled streets riddled with sniper fire and improvised explosive devices that would claim the lives and limbs of their comrades.

title: Body of Suspect in L.I. Shootings Is Discovered in the Hudson River
description: The body of the man who the authorities said shot two people at his former workplace on Long Island was discovered on Monday in the Hudson River, the Putnam County Sheriffs Department said.

title: Looking for Lincoln, and an Early Fish Fossil
description: Last year, moviegoers saw our 16th president star in two different films. This year, two software-wielding history buffs are seeing Abraham Lincoln in different spots in the same photograph.

title: Art Collections a Click Away
description: When Judy DeFord, a retired high school art teacher in Seattle, received an e-mail from Catherine Person Gallery recently, she saw a familiar name on its list of artists. It was a former student of hers, Allyce Wood.

title: Portuguese Voters Punish Leaders Party for Austerity Policies
description: MADRID  The main party in Portugals governing center-right coalition suffered a heavy defeat in municipal elections over the weekend as voters punished the government of Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho for the tax increases and spending cuts it has carried out since coming to power two years ago.

title: German Politician Faces Plagiarism Accusations
description: BERLIN  A German university is looking into allegations that Frank-Walter Steinmeier, a leading Social Democrat and a former foreign minister, plagiarized parts of his doctoral dissertation.

description: Following is the of President Obamas remarks from the White House briefing room on Monday afternoon, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

title: Passion, Principle or Both? Deciphering Art Vandalism
description: LONDON  Taking scissors to a van Gogh landscape, smearing paint over a Rembrandt, setting fire to a Leonardo drawing  even imagining such acts can make the stomach clench. Well never own these masterpieces, cannot touch them, may never see them up close. Yet their destruction prompts outrage.

title: NBC Scraps Hillary Clinton Mini-Series
description: On the same day that a filmmaker announced he was abandoning plans for a CNN documentary on Hillary Rodham Clinton, NBC Entertainment pulled the plug on its planned mini-series on Mrs. Clinton.

title: Obamas Statement Before Shutdown
description: President Obama urged House Republicans to pass a funding measure, saying it would be the height of irresponsibility to shut down the government.

title: With Accusations of Sabotage, Venezuela Expels 3 U.S. Embassy Officials
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Stepping up hostilities with the United States, President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela expelled the top American diplomat and two other embassy officials from the country on Monday, accusing them of supporting plots to sabotage the countrys electrical grid and the economy.

title: Hitting Pay Dirt on Mars
description: It looked to be uniformly bland, which is why scientists chose it as the first rock to be examined up close last year by the Mars rover Curiosity: a run-of-the-mill volcanic rock, something to test and calibrate the rovers instruments.

title: Two Marine Corps Generals Are Forced to Retire Over Fatal Security Breach
description: WASHINGTON  Two senior Marine Corps generals have been ordered to take early retirement after being found responsible for errors in judgment and failure to provide adequate security at a base in southwestern Afghanistan that was the scene of a deadly  and humiliating  insurgent attack last year that killed two Marines and destroyed six Harrier attack jets.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Withdraws From Two Carnegie Hall Concerts
description: Updated, 7:40 p.m. | MINNEAPOLIS  The Minnesota Orchestra announced on Monday that it was withdrawing from its two concerts at Carnegie Hall in November, because it has not been able to come to agreement on a new contract with its players.

title: The World as They Knew It
description: Long before people could look upon Earth from afar, completing a full orbit every 90 minutes, the Greeks and the Romans of antiquity had to struggle to understand their worlds size and shape. Their approaches differed: the philosophical Greeks, it has been said, measured the world by the stars; the practical, road-building Romans by milestones.

title: A Little More Legroom, Priced as an Upgrade
description: AS the director of data for a company called Routehappy, John Walton might be forgiven for putting the very happiest spin on a major airline trend, roping off parts of the coach cabins  or selling the better seats ad hoc  to accommodate those who want more comfort (or, to put it another way, less knee-crunching misery).

title: House Schedules Next Vote on Stopgap Measure
description: The Houses latest volley in the war over President Obamas health care law will come to a vote around 8 p.m., leaving the Senate just four hours to respond before much of the government shuts down.

title: Despite Cries of Unfair Treatment, JPMorgan Is No Victim
description: The governments legal pursuit of JPMorgan Chase strikes many people on Wall Street as unfair.

title: A Lizard That Slithers
description: Scientists have identified four distinct species of Anniella, legless lizards in California, including Anniella grinnelli, the Bakersfield legless lizard. This species, which has a purple belly, is found mostly in the southern San Joaquin Valley. The findings were reported last month in the journal Breviora by Theodore Papenfuss and James Parham, who used DNA testing to distinguish the species, which they named after natural historians who documented Californias biodiversity.

title: Sounds of Britain, Old and Newish
description: For much of his career, Benjamin Britten, whose centennial is being celebrated this year, disliked the music of Elgar, which he deemed too conservative. Britten often made snarky comments about that eminent British composer, declaring about Elgars Symphony No. 1, for example, that only in Imperial England would such a work be tolerated. But during the last few years of his life, Britten had a change of heart and began to appreciate Elgars music, conducting various scores and recording The Dream of Gerontius and Introduction and Allegro.

title: The Herman Miller Archive Unearths a Lost Moment in Design History
description: Over the summer, the furniture manufacturer Herman Miller started Why, a digital platform that features designer interviews, discusses current design issues and mines a company archive that is rich with material from and about the legendary figures who helped make Herman Miller a leader in postwar American design.

title: Aleksandra Kurzak Withdraws From Rigoletto
description: The Polish-born soprano Aleksandra Kurzak is withdrawing from the Metropolitan Operas production of Verdis Rigoletto this fall because she is expecting a baby with her partner, the tenor Roberto Alagna, the Met announced Monday. The role of Gilda will instead be shared by two sopranos making their Met debuts ahead of schedule: Irina Lungu , a Russian soprano, and Sonya Yonche, a Bulgarian Soprano. Mr. Alagnas marriage to the soprano Angela Gheorghiu  the pair were marketed as operas love couple at one point  ended in divorce.

title: Congressman Proposes New Rules for Music Royalties
description: The music industry is gearing up for yet another fight over one of its most intractable issues: radio royalties. Only this time, it involves the online world as well.

title: Just Let Instincts Take Over
description: PARIS  It isnt because they are women that Clare Waight Keller of Chlo and Stella McCartney have designed some of the sanest clothes for spring. It is because they arent beholden to a female archetype. They can design based on instinct.

title: A Tale of Two Countries, and Promises Broken
description: The choreographer Boyzie Cekwana is from South Africa. The choreographer Panaibra Canda is from Mozambique. The title of their collaboration, The Inkomati (dis)cord, refers to a 1984 nonaggression pact between their neighboring countries, and to promises that werent kept. The work is an attempt to find a common language in which a shared past of violence and lies might be expressed. And, as performed at New York Live Arts on Wednesday as part of the French Institute Alliance Franaises Crossing the Line festival, it is an effort to communicate that past to people who presumably know little of it.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: McAfees Gadget to Foil the N.S.A., and a Change in the I.P.O. Game
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Storytelling Coming to Life at the Library
description: The French choreographer Fanny de Chaill doesnt fight whimsy, she relishes it. In New York for two presentations courtesy of Crossing the Line 2013, the interdisciplinary arts festival, Ms. de Chaill hosted The Library, an unconventional storytelling experience held last week at two libraries. On Thursday, in collaboration with the visual artist Philippe Ramette, she unveiled Passage  lacte/Acting Out, a movement installation, at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn, showing that one of Ms. de Chaills talents is finding intimacy in public spaces.

title: A Not Entirely Lost Mets Season
description: It was around the middle of May. The Mets were something like 15 games under .500, and even the games they were winning were a slog. For even the truest Mets fan, the season was already long and getting longer by the inning. The trials of the modern Mets, which began with the called third strike in the ninth inning of Game 7 of the 2006 National League Playoffs, and extended through the collapses of 2007 and 2008 and then to the modern era of the their beautiful, cursed new ballpark, Citi Field, seemed endless.

title: At a Festival, Molly Danced but Didnt Cut In
description: CHATTAHOOCHEE HILLS, Ga.  Plastic mushroom statues outnumbered hay bales last weekend on a horse farm near here, about 25 miles southwest of Atlanta. A stage designed as a massive facade of books with titles like Beauty and the Beat and The Story of Us sprouted in the center, with seven smaller stages scattered over 500 acres of rolling countryside.

title: The Back and Forth Over the Shutdown and Debt Ceiling
description: Tracking the legislative efforts to end the shutdown of the federal government and to prevent breaching the nations debt limit.

title: Obamas Message to the Middle
description: President Obamas demand this afternoon that Congress do its fundamental job and keep the government open will have no more influence on hard-liners in the House than it ever has, even with only a few hours left until the midnight shutdown. But he made an interesting choice by beginning his remarks with the effects of a shutdown. That suggested that his real audience was not just the public, but moderate House Republicans, who could use a reminder of what is about to happen to them.

title: Polls Show a More Negative View of G.O.P. Over Shutdown
description: With a possible government shutdown just hours away, new national polls find bad news for Congressional Republicans: they are rated more negatively than President Obama in handling budget negotiations, and more Americans would hold them responsible if a shutdown occurs.

title: Hotels Fight Comparison Shoppers With Lower, Locked Rates
description: For hotels, they are some of the most maddening of customers  those who repeatedly book and cancel rooms at no cost in search of the best deal. While the customer ends up with a low rate on a good room, the snubbed hotel is left with an empty room and no revenue.

title: Ford C-Max Hybrid Owners Get Rebate for Disappointing Mileage
description: DETROIT  Ford Motor Company has started mailing checks to owners of the C-Max Hybrid to compensate them after lowering its fuel economy rating.

title: Kenzo Puts in a Word for Fish
description: PARIS  On a gray Sunday morning in Paris, when there is little traffic and the only signs of life on the streets are a few ambitious joggers, an excursion to the suburb of Saint-Denis for the Kenzo show did not sound so bad. The designers, Carol Lim and Humberto Leon, had set up their runway in a glass-ceilinged hall the size of a railway station in La Cit du Cinma, a film studio complex recently opened by the director Luc Besson. At the entrance is a trailer-size model of the Brooklyn Bridge. And there were cookies.

title: Roomy Carryalls That Are Ready for Takeoff
description: All it takes for an easy, breezy getaway is a classic carryall  so roomy you can take it with you.

title: A Vivier Shoe Retrospective, Buckles and All
description: PARIS  Roger Vivier, the designer shoe label that has done more than the Pilgrims to make buckles a fashion statement, is the subject of a new retrospective here that opened on Monday night at the Palais de Tokyo. Curated by Olivier Saillard, the director of the Muse Galliera that reopened across the street last week, the show is a shoe spectacular, whimsically tracing the history of the brand from Mr. Viviers years at Christian Dior in the 1950s through the current incarnation of Roger Vivier, which has been designed by Bruno Frisoni since 2003.

title: Besieged by Chirping Crickets in the Terminal
description: AS a partner and co-C.E.O. at CohnReznick, Im meeting with clients, visiting our offices or going out on business development calls all the time. Last year I flew about 200,000 miles just in domestic flights alone.

title: Olympics Loom Large Over N.H.L.
description: A full schedule after a lockout-shortened season, a new divisional setup, outdoor games galore, the Chicago Blackhawks seeking their third Stanley Cup in five years. Those are all solid story lines for the 2013-14 National Hockey League season, which begins with three games on Tuesday. But make no mistake, much of the season will be about the Winter Olympics.

title: Obama Calls Boehner Ahead of Budget Deadline
description: Just hours before the government was set to shut down, President Obama called House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio, according to a spokesman for Mr. Boehner. But it did not appear they resolved much of anything.

title: Perry Capital Cuts Stake in J.C. Penney
description: The hedge fund Perry Capital pared its stake in J.C. Penney by nearly half as the troubled retailer announced plans last week to raise as much as $932 million in fresh capital.

title: Procedural Vote Quells Fledgling Republican Revolt
description: The Houses most conservative Republicans, with some help from a handful of moderate Republicans, tried Monday evening to bring down the Republican leaderships latest effort to link further government funding to a knock on President Obamas health care law.
